<review# 286,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,8/12/2013,2/10/2014,69,206,4,7,6>Food vs Service; the battle begins.First let me say that I lived in Germany - as most military brats in this area have at some point or another.  If you're nostalgic for oddly decorated places that smell like beer and have live polka playing, look no further than the German Pantry. Aside from some serious service pitfalls (noted in other reviews) this place was a score. I saw from other reviews that we would need a reservation, even though it was just 2 of us going at 6pm, I thought I should be on the safe side. Good thing, too. This restaurant goes ahead and reserves tables for the entire night when you make a reservation - so the table next to us was slotted for a 7:30 reservation and remained empty the entire time even though people at the door looked genuinely pissed off at not being seated in a room full of empty tables.  I don't know if the reserved tables were an homage to European slow food, but I seriously doubt it, given how rushed we were throughout the night.  We specifically told the server that we were taking our time and didn't want to order our entrees immediately after our apps so that we could luxuriate a bit. She was undeterred. She just came back every 5 minutes until she wore us down. We ordered the meat and cheese plate and landjaeger for apps - both were really good, though they took some time to get to us. Overall, good quality cheeses, smokey salami, braunschweiger and seriously amazing whole grain mustard - served with some sort of ritz cracker.  Immediately on the heels of the apps were our entrees. I opted for a  piping hot weinerschnitzel (don't I always) - which is a breaded veal cutlet served with lemon with 2 sides, I chose german potato salad and red cabbage.  My husband had 2 wursts, spaetzle and red cabbage. We were both really happy with our meals. I loved the schnitzel, it was perfectly cooked and I was thrilled to see they had it made with veal instead of the typical pork. The red cabbage was perfectly vinegar-y, and the potato salad was spot on. The whole thing was made better by the old guys playing polka and incoherently shouting out lyrics in German throughout my meal.  We'll be back here eventually - and we'll make reservations.

<review# 288,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/30/2013,2/8/2014,40,56,2,6,4>I knew the owners of this establishment cared about the product they sell and the customer experience during my first visit. I was approached by a young man who asked me whether or not I've been in before. I told him no and he proceeded to give me the 411 on the cupcake selection they had that day. On the surface, a cupcake looks like a cupcake. But if you take a good look into the different cupcakes and the ingredients that go into them, you'll see that they are not like other cupcakes. No box cake mixes here. They even have the ingredients that are included in each cake under the name plates in the display case. I've probably had at least 15 different cupcakes from ethereal since they opened. You can taste the freshness in every bite. One day I walked in and picked up a few cupcakes for the family and the owner mentioned that they also have a breakfast cupcake that I need to try. So I returned the next day before work and picked up this cupcake that had a taste of pancakes, with a maple flavored frosting and topped with bacon. BACON! Besides that flavor town favorite, there are several other cakes including one of their cheesecake selections that are certified winners. These aren't the .50 cakes you'll find in farm fresh. These cakes will run you about 3 bucks a pop. But the quality and selection is well worth it. Treat yourself to a ethereal cupcake, you'll enjoy the experience.
<review# 289,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/13/2013,2/7/2014,34,86,1,7,4>This is my favorite Thai restaurant in the Norfolk area. My husband and I met up with a friend for dinner here when we first moved to town, and it has become our go-to for Thai food. We've tried others, and they just haven't measured up to the service and the food at Rama Garden. My husband love the drunken noodles - he gets them EVERY time. I have a few favorites - the pad thai is good, as is the panang curry. Their Thai iced coffee is well-balanced, not too sweet, but just sweet enough.The real draw for this place is the service. Every server I have had is nice, and nearly all of them are funny and witty. It is rare to find servers that actually seem like real people these days, since most times servers are not willing to put themselves out there for fear that they won't get their standard tip. To those people, I say it's worth the risk with friendly tables, which my husband and I are nearly all the time. The decor is unique, and feels well thought-out and put together, compared to some other local Thai restaurants that are not cohesive. The seating layout is good to ensure privacy to each table, which is also a gripe I often have with Thai restaurants. Overall, this is a great place for an affordable and DELICIOUS Thai food dinner. Don't forget the iced coffee! :)

<review# 292,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/16/2013,2/4/2014,13,39,,7,4>This place was pretty good. Service is really fast and attentive. So far this has been the closest I have had to the taste I miss so much in California. The tacos are really good and salsas have great flavor too. But what got me to come back here is the shrimp cocktail. This is a Mexican-style shrimp cocktail with tomato juice, spices, veggies, and of course lots of shrimp. I, of course, mix in tons of habanero hot sauce because I need a kick. I give this place 4 stars because the ingredients aren't all the same as back home. The flour tortillas taste low quality (store bought), and the cocktail, while good, is missing spice. But San Jose does the best they can with the limited ingredients available in Virginia Beach for a Mexican restaurant. This isn't the best Mexican food you'll ever have but it's probably the best you'll have at a restaurant in Virginia beach. A for effort, authenticity, consistency, and flavor. D for mildness, maybe I just need more heat! Doesn't anyone in VA beach like spicy food??
<review# 293,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,1/16/2014,2/3/2014,23,129,2,6,3>I would give this restauant more of a 3.5 star review. I came here last weekend for dinner on a Saturday night. The restaurant is situated in a strip mall with plenty of available of parking. My date had made reservations for 7:00pm, but there were ample empty tables where we didn't really need them. The place is beautiful and intimate. There are multiple dining areas: 2 large dining areas with the one in the front inclusive of the bar; a glass-doored room that can hold a party the equivalent of a business meeting; a door-less small room that you have to walk up a few stairs to reach which only holds 1 round table- presumably a "proposal" dinner table? and another larger glass-covered dining area that can hold a small social event. Our hostess led us into the large dining area towards the back where there were more patrons. Although we liked our dining arrangement, my date and I concluded that we would have preferred to eat in the other dining area next to the bar. Our server was gracious and hospitable. She took her time to explain the specials and to answer any of our questions. It was very easy to converse with her and have small talk outside of just food recommendations, etc. She was also quick to fulfill any of our requests. For example, when I went to use the restroom, she was nowhere near our table. By the time I returned to my seat ~3mins later, our meals were already packed into to-go boxes and stacked inside a brown bag onto the table, and my date was signing the restaurant bill. (Just in case people may think I'm one of those girls that "coincidentally" leaves the table to use the restroom right before the check arrives: my date and I had just before talked about ordering dessert, and I was still planning to eat more of my entree when I returned. We had free tickets to see a comedy show after dinner, but during our meal we had agreed we didn't necessarily need to see it and that we should take our time with dinner instead...I think my date had a change of heart in the end and didn't want us to miss the show.)In regards to the food, we ordered 2 appetizers, the fried oysters and the scallops. They were both tasty, but not mind blowing, "ya so gotta try this" type oral sensation. The I ordered the half duck entree with a yellow raisin and pistachio gratin/stuffing/mashed potato type side. When it came out, we were surprised that the portion was so large given it was duck. My date replied, "I think that's chicken. It can't be that big." We ended up making a bet that they didn't mess up my order...and sure enough, he lost. The duck was moist and had a great flavor to it. I really liked my yellow raisin/pistachio mix dish. It was more on the sweet side, and I have a huge sweet tooth. My date ordered the lamb shank with bleu cheese polenta. The lamb was cooked well, but I had higher expectations for it given the Yelp reviews on it. I'm not a fan of bleu cheese, but my date liked the polenta. We also ordered drinks to accompany our meals, and they were prepared well.Overall, my dining experience was pretty good. However, I would not drive all the way here from Norfolk where I currently reside. There are restaurants that are just as good of quality or better that are in a closer proximity than me. However, if you live in VA beach, it may be worth checking out once. I would come here expecting fabulous service but only above average food.

<review# 295,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/8/2014,2/1/2014,139,167,,9,6>This place deserves every five star review it has.  Went here with my husband this past weekend and had the best meal I've had since arriving in the area.  The space is itty-bitty, which only adds to the chic, hip, but relaxed vibe.  The aesthetic of the place was kind of "found object minimalist" so no part was over done, and it's amazing how lovely the lighting can be from one orange lamp.I started with the Lemon Thyme Hendricks Martini because, duh.  I mean, did you just read that?  I know.  And it's DELIGHTFUL.  My husband went straight for the vino.  Their offerings by the glass are slim, but their bottle selections have some reasonable options, and the wine chosen seem nicely curated.  My husband's Bordeaux was gorgeous.For an appetizer, we got an octopus dish that was UH-mazing.  Lightly steamed octopus, shaved fennel, a light broth, red pepper flakes, lemon and capers.  It was served with a couple of pieces of bread, and when our lovely waitress noticed me making a joking gesture to my husband indicating how much I wanted to sop up every last bit of the broth, she popped straight back and grabbed us some more bread.For entrees, my husband had the most pillowy and perfect gnocci in a spinach cream sauce, and I had perfectly cooked duck breast over quinoa and sunchoke pilaf, with a lovely sauce of caramelized shallots.We didn't go for dessert, but not because we weren't tempted -- one of the most delicious looking and subtly innovative dessert lists I've seen in a long time.Service was impeccable.  The food was gorgeous.  The atmosphere made me us feel like we were in a real, cosmopolitan city.  If more places like this keep opening in Norfolk, this city will become one of America's best kept little secrets.

<review# 304,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/24/2013,1/23/2014,119,199,9,9,10>A few years ago, the voters kicked Meyera out of her Mayor gig and named this huge free bookstore after her.Hang on a sec here....Let me pause for a moment and pay some homage...Meyera E. Oberndorf was truly a legend, one of the greatest Mayors in Virginia Beach, if not US, History.  Sure, there were some difficult times, some unrest at the Oceanfront and all of that...but consider the number of tourists that pass through here every year along with the fact that a huge share of the 'permanent' residents are only here for 2 years or so, the fact that the entire boardwalk wasn't up in flames every other weekend is a remarkable feat in and of itself!  Her Honor was never too busy to attend a ribbon cutting ceremony for a new business or city parking garage, her activities schedule was always jammed packed with ample opportunity to press the flesh with the electorate and their children.  In recent years, Meyera has had a bit of a rough go of it.  I did see her down at the oceanfront a few years ago at Blues at the Beach.  She was recently out of office, but looked relieved and relaxed in a peaceful sort of way.  And I'm glad, because she gave of herself, her energy, her drive, her passion...and I'm pleased that for at least a little bit of time, she was able to kick her feet up and enjoy what she helped build.So back to the big free bookstore.  If you live here, you can get some plastic that allows you to take things out of here and read them in the comfort of your own home...or better yet at Starbucks!  As Elwood Blues properly predicted in 1979: 'By the year 2006, the music known today as the blues will exist only in the classical records department of your local library.'  MEO has got tons of blues here, check it out (get it?  'Check it out?'  Library?  I made a funny!!!)!There is a cool little coffee shop here, a thrift store that sells used underwear..i mean used books.  Once you are done reading your treasures from Barnes and Noble, drop them off here so that they can sell them and make some money.  If you need help doing your taxes, that happens here too.Need help with your calculus homework?  I'm sure that someone roaming around can explain the Third Derivative for you.Now here is the really really cool part:It is all free!  No charge for parking.  In the summer, they've got Air Conditioning!Stop by here sometime and spend a few hours.  It's fun! As a great philosopher once said:Na, na, na Gonna have a good time Na, na, na Gonna have a good time Hey, hey, hey! This is Bill Cosby coming out with music and fun If you're not careful, you may learn something before it's done! Hey, hey, hey! 'And when you enter, think some warm thoughts for the matriarch for whom the place is named.  Put your politics aside for a minute and reflect on the difference that she made and how this place might be the best and most fitting tribute we can offer up.

<review# 318,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/30/2013,1/9/2014,122,469,,8,4>Mizuno is the best sushi restaurant in Hampton Roads. Bam. When a few yelpers made this statement to me they were unable to tell me why this was the case. Allow me to do so:1. Freshest fish. Anyone who is a regular sushi goer can taste the difference in fresh sushi and fish that's a couple days old. Every item we had here tasted like it was caught moments before consumption. We got the tuna poke taco appetizer and was blown away by the light flavor of the fish combined with all the different flavor profiles of the spice and lime. 2. Most creative rolls. I'm talking OYSTER rolls, crispy rice (think tator tot sushi), filet mignon rolls, beef slices, and combined with some of the most random but well thought out combinations of items I've ever had. Anotherwards, this isn't a place you would order a standard salmon roll. As examples, a couple of the rolls we ordered were the Oyster & Pearl (fried oyster, lump crab, asparagus, and scallion rolled with soy paper) and the S.P.E.A.R. roll (lump crab and avacado rolled in soy paper. Salmon & yellow tail on top. Ceviche sauce with crunchy). Which brings me to my next point: you won't need soy sauce to eat any of their sushi. It's THAT delicious.3. Innovative cocktails and great wine list. In addition to having an impressive sake and selective wine list, their cocktails are the real standout here. I ordered the kiwi cocktail and my friend ordered the mojito but they also have other fun options like the white lilly (with vanilla yogurt & sake!) and of course, a lychee-tini. I want to come back just to tick through their cocktail list. 4. Chic ambiance. From the moment you walk in you notice this is no standard sushi joint. From the open kitchen allowing you to view the sushi chefs to the glowing white 180 degree bar, you realize you are in a FANCY place. In fact, it reminds me of my trips to NOBU in NYC. Sushi Chic!5. On point service. It's weird that with all these winning features it's located in a strip mall (albeit a nicer strip mall). I always get lost and confused in all the different Hilltop shopping centers so when I called to verify the location, the hostess was very helpful in getting us there. And when we sat down, she asked if we found the place okay. I just thought that was a friendly touch. And everyone we encountered had that same friendly and helpful demeanor. Our glasses were never empty and our plates stayed cleared. Overall, this place has amazing energy from the time we walked in to the time we left. Everything was perfect. Ever since Sushi Aka closed down, I've been looking to put another sushi spot on my Top Hampton Roads Restaurants list and Mizuno will be filling that void. Can't wait to return!

<review# 322,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,12/20/2013,1/5/2014,121,170,,17,9>It's very possible that Chinese food in HR itself is a bit of an oxymoron.  I think what most of us know as 'Chinese' is not very Chinese at all. I'm lucky to have lived in Asia where each country has it's own version of Chinese as well. I've had Korean Chinese, Japanese Chinese, and even Chinese Chinese.  All were very different but incredibly delicious.  I wonder at times, however, how America ended up with dishes like Chop Suey and Egg Foo Young. I know; the question is more rhetorical than anything else.  Jade Villa and Judy's Szechuan has done an incredible job of introducing the HR palate to real Chinese.  Enter Peter Chang...I didn't know Peter Chang was coming to the area, but, boy, am I happy to see him.  Yes, HR needs him! I'm one of the those people who saw him on TV a few times.  I remember seeing him with Andrew Zimmern. His food looked amazing and unique. I was impressed with his dishes because I love Asian food, and Chinese is at the top of that list.  It's easy, too, for anyone who knows how to cook - All you need is a wok and you'll there.On my first trip to Peter Chang's, I went conservative. I saw a lot of unfamiliar items on the menu and didn't know exactly what to order.  Our waitress was a big help recommending dishes for us.  We started with an order of the Pan Fried Pork Dumplings, one order of Shrimp Dumplings, and the Beef Scallion Pancake.  The beef on the pancake was more a minced product instead of a sliced one as I expected.  They were still as advertised - All were delicious.The star of the first trip was what the waitress called 'Number 33'. This is Peter Chang's Seafood in Stone Pot.  The pot is of the 'dolsot' variety found in every really good Korean restaurant.  Imagine a stone bowl arriving to your table, steamed hot and still gurgling, filled with jumbo shrimp, scallop, sliced fish, squid, and mushrooms. These goodies were swimming in a curry cream soup.  It was amazing; the leftovers tasted even better the second day as the flavor had more time to meld.The second star of day one was the Mapo Tofu.  If you like medium-spicy, this is the dish for you.  A lot of the spice in this dish comes from chili oil, however.  It might be too oily for some, so if you don't like a lot of oil, go for something else.Trip two was a bit different than the first.  On this visit Peter himself actually recommended some dishes to us.  On this trip we started with the Dry Fried Eggplant.  They were nicely spiced and delicious; my new go-to appetizer.  We also had the Mapo Beef.  This was a great dish as well.  It was closer to Orange Beef without the orange, though, in my opinion.  I would pair the eggplant with a dim sum dish instead - maybe a noodle dish.Peter loves spicy, so he recommended the Chicken with Three Pepper on Hot Iron Plate (#36).  It, too, was a great dish.  If you don't like heat, though, don't order this dish.  It was really SPICY!  The one pepper that put this dish over the top was the Thai Bird Chili, I believe.  Frankly, I like heat, but it was too hot for me. The Shan City Pig Feet (#T2) was also super HOT.  Let me suggest that if you are not a chile-heat to avoid dishes with three-peppers.  They were both really tasty, but I learned my lesson.What did I like most about Peter Chang's?  First the menu is familiar but not the same as your run-of-the-mill Chinese restaurant.  His menu gives you to opportunity to try something new, something closer to real Chinese food.  More importantly, most of Peter's dishes are very approachable. HR needs more ethnic restaurants like this one.The fact that Peter's restaurant has a large number of big tables with lazy susans says a lot.  It says to me that he welcomes and expects large groups to eat here. Yes, that's very Asian and very Chinese. He believes, and rightfully so, that his food will attact people looking for a taste of home.  It's an even better opportunity for other lovers of Chinese cooking to try some more authentic, something Peter Chang. So, if you are looking for great Chinese food, something both familiar but unique, Peter Chang's is the place for you.
<review# 323,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/15/2013,1/4/2014,99,254,,5,1>What a great little find!Lots of really wonderful things about Crackers. For starters - I loved the ambiance. The place is tiny and there are only a dozen or so tables. They honestly could pack in another row of 2-seaters down the middle like so many other restaurants do, but I'm so grateful that they don't. The layout provides makes the tiny restaurant spacious enough to give you and your date (or friend, or whatever) privacy. The food was fantastic. I mean really fantastic. I started with the grilled asparagus with the lemon sauce. The asparagus were perfectly grilled to a crisp-tender point and salted just right. The lemon sauce was a perfect, creamy compliment. The panzenella had wonderful complimentary flavors - the bite of arugula paired with the sweetness of the beets and the acorn squash and the salty, crunchy bread. The waffle with fruit for dessert was the perfect ending. Crunchy and sweet, but not overly so. The staff was fantastic. The restaurant was slow when we arrived at 5:00 (opening) on Friday - and we were waited on by our hostess who was sweet and friendly, but also prompt and efficient. The guy tending the bar checked on us periodically and was friendly enough to make us feel welcome without being intrusive to our conversation. Best service I've had since I moved to Norfolk a year ago. Two minor things keep Crackers from being a 5-star experience for me. 1. While there was a fair amount of vegetarian options (YAY!) most were bread-based: Hummus and pita; bruschetta, fondue and bread, panzenella (bread) salad...you get my point. I'd love to see a couple of vegetarian items that emphasized vegetables and/or protein. A tofu lettuce wrap? A quinoa salad? A quesadilla with white bean spread for the vegans? 2. The parking lot is tiny, tiny, tiny. We arrived at the restaurant's opening at 5 and had no problem finding a space - but I'm not sure I'd feel comfortable trying to meet friends there after hours, because I don't think there'd be sufficient room for all of us to park. I know it's not the restaurant's fault -but it's still something patrons need to know before they go.

<review# 325,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/16/2013,1/2/2014,198,161,2,4,2>Let those creative juices flow!  At Color Me Mine there are dozen of pieces of pottery ranging approximately from $10 to $50.  Those pieces are anything from ornaments, mugs, vases, trays, figurines, piggy banks, toothbrush holders, soap dispensers.  This list goes on and on. The staff was accommodating to our group of 14 with ages ranging from 5 to 50.  We all had a good time painting.  The paint washes out of clothing so parents don't need to worry about kids ruining their clothes. Some of the staff members are not very outgoing but still very talented so if you need some help with painting tips or ideas, just speak up and ask because they are very knowledgeable.  I was slightly disappointed when we were 3/4 of the way through our painting session before they started making suggestions (after we started asking for help) for painting tips, techniques, and introducing useful tools. By that time it was too late for me to try their suggestions which would have made my little piece of art look a little more polished.  I'm looking forward to picking up my pottery after it comes out of the kiln.  The wait time for pick up is usually one week.  I should also mention that they stayed open after their regular business hours on Sunday for us and donated portion of what we paid back to our group.

It is our own natural haunted house right here in Virginia Beach.A newer educational area and restrooms are huge improvements in the past few years. Cabins are also available and although I have never seen inside they look quaint and would add to the experience. A campground is also available across from the main entrance on Shore Dr.The park rangers offer educational tours that can be scheduled. One of the coolest tours is the after dark which I would love to do and cannot imagine stepping on these trails in pitch dark.. YIKES!Our family has been a big fan of First Landing for years. A small entry is required to enter and the adventure is yours. I would personally recommend an annual pass. Whether your on foot, wheels , or holding a leash to a beast you will fall in love with this gorgeous area of Virginia Beach.

<review# 340,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/14/2013,12/18/2013,263,519,3,11,12>This afternoon I had the pleasure of stopping by Field Guide for the first time. This is David Hausmann and John Porter's new lunch spot located at 429 Granby St. in downtown Norfolk. You may recognize those names as David & John own local favorite The Handsome Biscuit and used to run The Boot.  The first thing that will catch your eye upon arriving is the large glass garage door. This opens to reveal a stand up counter and ventilates the entire restaurant on a nice day such as today. The interior of this old building has been redesigned with a very open and modern concept. There are 3 long semi diagonal tables for seating in addition to the standing counter at the entrance and finally a brushed metal counter in the back where you place your order. The rest of the design is very modern with some exceptional wood work done on the overhead lighting and on the right hand wall. It's amazing what you can do with lumber. The menu is exactly what I expected from David & John and in my opinion shows the same type of variety that you see over at their sister restaurant The Handsome Biscuit. There's a few salads, about a dozen very unique sandwiches and about half a dozen side dishes to choose from. I selected the 'Ms. Kodiak' sandwich which is smoked whitefish salad & avocado along with house made sweet potato chips and a golden relish. For a side I selected a serving of 'Chickpea, Broccoli, Roasted Red Pepper Pesto'.  I selected the house soda for my drink. I have one word for you my friends. "Superb!"While I was dining I was also given a desert, I'm guessing because they saw me take a picture of my sandwich.  It was an 'Oatmeal Cream Pie' which is two house made chocolate chip & cherry pecan cookies with a super fluffy cream cheese filling in between. I had to spit that with my guest. What a fantastic lunch! In my opinion this is another homerun for David and John. No question at all. Also in the very near future they're going to be expanding their hours and opening for breakfast as well. I'm really looking forward to seeing what they have in store for us then.
<review# 341,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/15/2013,12/17/2013,63,174,,12,5>Only seven weeks old this week, I think this new Asian-fusion restaurant is maybe the best example I've seen in a long time of an outstanding kitchen in search of an equally outstanding and consistent front end.  We visited Salt for dinner on a Friday night, and quickly fell in love with the clean, minimalist, geometric decor --- a play on understated Asian, without the wood and vegetation.  While our hostess was a little drab, we quickly warmed to our server Tiffany, who, it seemed, did just about everything except the cooking.  Server, bartender, hostess, bus person,  dish and glass washer --- and for all I know, when she disappeared into the kitchen she may also have been doing a turn at the stove.  Unfortunately, Tiffany appeared to us almost to be a one-person show during our visit --- a number of other employees, including a fellow in a blue shirt who seemed like he may have been the on-duty manager, were fairly idle behind the bar, hovering around what appeared to be the restaurant's sole data terminal.  The result, for us, was very attentive and professional service from Tiffany when she  wasn't washing bar glasses or mixing drinks, but an unfortunate lack of a number of little things in the service regimen that one would expect from a restaurant attempting to brand itself as upscale.  Silverware left unreplaced, glasses and side dishes placed on the wrong side of the service, gaps in the removal of plates and glassware (the timing on food delivery, however, was excellent), a delay in closing blinds when the sun sank into my wife's face, and a number of other small things gave us the impression that, if it hadn't been for Tiffany, Salt's front end might be a bit out of control.So if Salt's front end deserved maybe a 3 rating, our one dinner experience with their back end really made us want to stand up and cheer.  The "East Meets West" food and beverage theme reminds us a lot of another of our local favorite VB restaurants, and apparently at least some of Salt's kitchen staff did a turn in the kitchen of that other fine restaurant.  Our dinner choices included an outstanding Furikaki seared Ahi tuna served with a mouth-watering fresh crab salad, some OK pork Pot Stickers (the rice vinegar dipping sauce was a little weak), an excellent fresh grouper (pan-seared, but crispy and still moist on the inside - delicious) and the most fun and delicious Cioppino I've had the pleasure of devouring in a long time.  The Cioppino was served with an in-house baked olive Focaccia bread, which had a perfect texture and was just delicious.  Chef's seasoning was done with a very light hand on all our dishes, allowing the food ingredients to shine through and be appreciated.  The Cioppino broth especially, which can easily be overdone with tomato or garlic, was fresh, light and just wonderful.  And finally our shared dessert of a Brulee du Jour - a very good chocolate version - topped off a truly outstanding meal. So a restaurant only seven weeks into its existence may have a right to still be refining its front end, and we'll give it a  little while and return again.  But Salt's outstanding kitchen will no doubt make that 'little while' before our next visit a very, very little while, indeed.

<review# 349,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/8/2013,12/9/2013,83,62,1,5,4>My boy, Chester, lives down the street from this establishment and he took me here after showing me his new spot, The Wheelist. Granny's is located on 35th St, which is in the Park Pace section of Norfolk. This portion of Norfolk, for a long time, was an area you didn't want to hang out too long (or too often) as its streets were full of shady activity. Thanks to residents like Chester, Park Place is going through a revitalization and the maxim of staying away from here is quickly being eliminated. Granny's is a spot that helps to enforce this area's renaissance, and they're doing it with some good food.Granny's is a small spot - when you walk in the kitchen's in front of you. They serve a la carte and it's a good mix of southern and country cookin'. There is a lounge/bar area (which wouldn't look out of place at the Town Center in Pembroke) with plenty of televisions and a full bar. We came in on a Sunday evening, so there was plenty of football to be seen. My friends got the wings, which I believe were $0.50 apiece, so you can order as many or as little as you desire. I went for the baked chicken, which came with rice and two sides. It was a hearty meal since it was covered in gravy and I ordered French fries and mac 'n' cheese to accompany it. Granny's has a homey feel to it, accentuated by their friendly staff. There is a chill vibe throughout, which anyone can appreciate, although I foresee some friendly arguments between clashing NFL fans (the entire staff was wearing gear to support their favorite teams). Granny is back in the kitchen (definitely not an imaginary title) but she's running things both in the front and back. Say hi to her if she doesn't get a chance to greet you first because I believe it's well-deserved to compliment a place that has a good balance of delicious food and timely service.Better Block is happening on November 8th and 9th, so this spot could be one of the event's highlights. Head over and check it out if you're so inclined. But if you can't make it then then check out Granny's sometime soon if you want to try (or enjoy again) some good home cookin'.  JEV

<review# 351,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/3/2013,12/7/2013,49,45,,4,5>Boulevard Pizzeria is a great place to go if you're looking for a quick and cheap lunch. There are two specials. One of them is 2 slices of pizza and a drink. The other is all you can eat pizza and salad bar for about $5.99. If you opt for the buffet, it is pretty much self-serve once you order your drink. You can pick from about two or three different kinds of pizza (usually pepperoni, cheese, and sausage), meatballs, sometimes pasta, and a full salad bar that includes the GOOD stuff, pepperoni and peperocini. My other favorite meal to order here is their Greek salad. It is no baby side salad...the portions are HUGE. It would take me two sittings to finish it. I've also tried the lobster ravioli, which is another popular lunch special. It's good for the price!Service is okay. Don't expect much, but I've never had a bad experience here. You will be quickly seated and there's usually no wait.

<review# 353,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/11/2013,12/5/2013,77,61,2,4,2>Ah, smoke. When it's billowing from a house, it's dangerous. When it's coming from the engine of your car, it's a harbinger of doom. When it's the name of a restaurant, get your taste buds ready.This place opened with a lot of fanfare when it opened, and then I didn't hear much about it for a while. Smoked fish and homemade potato chips...aww yeah! A hot dog wrapped in brisket and everything else that could could kill the arteries of any super-sized man...I'm not ready...yet. Stop in for lunch, have a great dinner, talk to my girl Lexi about their beer selections, I swear you will enjoy yourself.

<review# 358,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/28/2013,11/30/2013,155,241,3,6,5>Undeniably, the best soul food restaurant I have encountered here in Hampton Roads. The space is filled with tufted comfy black leather chairs and glass tables. Which is much more preferable than the woman who gave birth to you.I've been to plenty of chicken and waffle joints to include Roscoes (multiple locations in Los Angeles and even Sylvia's in Harlem) and the chicken at Krush is simply amazing. The chicken had great flavor, it was well cooked and had a crispy exterior. Basically everything you'd want in a fried chicken can be found at Krush.The waffles were also fantastic though the butter wasn't real butter and the syrup was packaged neither of those two elements took away from the waffle itself.The sides were also the best I've had in a while. Hands down the best collards. They had a great smokey taste and weren't vinegary at all. The Mac and cheese was really good and the noodles were still whole (seriously .. This is a rarity) and the sautéed spinach was delicately flavored with a little salt and still bright green. I also got to try the candied yams and .. Oh boy! Were those tasty. Some people don't like them as sweet but I love em and prefer them that way. All in all this was a great food experience. If you're looking for the best fried chicken around, I highly recommend you check this place out.

<review# 362,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/18/2013,11/26/2013,13,167,2,8,5>Very glad to have another quality restaurant pop up on the radar.  Came here for dinner and lunch recently and both experiences were very nice.  If you've been looking for a quality/healthy lunch option downtown, this fills that void.  And if you're like me and just get sick of going to the same places, this is a great new option for dinner - I feel that this will become a great local spot.  It's super cozy - probably seats about 30 comfortably inside.  I'd recommend reservations, but there is a small bar you may be able to squeeze into if you're just walking by on a weekend.For lunch so far I've had the salmon salad, tried the tuna sandwich and the beet soup.  They were all great, but the standout was the beet soup.  It's coupled with a perfect pairing of goat cheese - great complimentary flavors!  For dinner, I've tried the snapper and polenta and the polenta fell a little flat; however, I did try the scallops and they were some of the best I've had - delicious!The menus are beyond simple, so it takes no time to choose.  Make a few things very well, great concept.  I'm imagining that the menus will be dynamic dependent upon what's in season (awesome!), so it's going to be a mad rush when they are making something great - for example, the lemon poppy seed tart with vanilla ice cream that we just devoured (see picture)!The interior is still a bit new, but I'd like to see more artwork.  There is a massive blank wall along the side where the two tops are that is screaming for an interesting piece.  I would also move the couch that sits too close to the lone six top.  When I was there for dinner, my girlfriend and I were both bumped in to a couple of times.  I think moving that couch and replacing its position with the corner shelving unit would solve the problem.There is also somewhat of a fishbowl effect going on with the large windows.  I could see some clean adjustable shades solving that problem.  There are some dining options outside; however, I could see this getting a little loud with the close traffic.  Some nice shrubbery creating a border could help stifle the noise a bit.Other than that, so glad to have this option - come out and support a nice new local spot!

<review# 365,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,8/5/2013,11/23/2013,26,148,3,4,2>Ok, let me be straight here.  It's a strong 3.5 but not a 4, according to the following restaurant rubric that I'm starting to refine:Five stars = "I dream about this place",Four stars =  "I can't wait to go back to this place"Three stars = "I'd definitely go back to this place if someone wanted ___ cuisine"Two stars = "I won't go back to this place for ___ cuisine"One star = "I wouldn't recommend this place to my enemy"The restaurant itself is located in an interesting quasi-industrial/residential area.  Easy to get to, with decent lot parking and streets nearby.  It was clean, nicely decorated and spacious.  The staff (one lady) was genuinely attentive and friendly. The food was tasty (admittedly, not a huge Thai connoisseur here), fresh and came out at a decent pace. I've had better satay, and the peanut sauce seemed to have settled (but was still good).  Veggies were fresh, and the tom yum was surprisingly good.  Pad thai was money, but the rice was a bit underdone (I'm calling it that, rather than old).  Portion sizes were ample.  Bathrooms were also clean, too.  Perhaps the ambiance was lacking due to the fact that I was only one of three tables there, and maybe I'm being a little harsh with the review.  But I can/will stand by it.  I don't think you'll be disappointed in the food if you go, but holding ALL restaurants to the same standard I find it difficult to put up there with the other 4/5-star ratings I've got out there.  Attentive service brought it up from a 3, but is not quite 4-star material the way I look at things.  And that's the way the cookie crumbles...

<review# 372,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,7/14/2013,11/16/2013,46,196,4,4,3>This is one of those places you go to when you are bored and want to have a small competitive adventure.  It's smelly, dirty and fun .  You have to go in the morning before the sun is too high in the sky and the stink has rising with the humidity.  The price has risen to ten bucks instead of the 8 bucks it was last year, that is per person if you are fishing or crabbing.  Four bucks if you just want to see what's biting and  to see fish heads steaming on vacated cutting boards and peeps tying chicken guts into their crabbing baskets.  We stop by a Farm Fresh on our way to grab the most disgusting chicken pieces with a mark-down sticker, usually wings or necks.We have four crab baskets, two each.  It's simple competition, who pulls up the most crabs.  We bring an orange Lowes bucket to drop our bounty into and some heavy twine to tie our chicken parts onto the baskets.The best part is the people on the pier, all kinds.  There are families who have been there since it opened at 4am with wheeled coolers full of crabs.  There are couples throwing out their fishing lines not sure if they'd catch anything and people like us, we don't like these tiny creatures, too much work to eat them,  it's just fun to catch them.  One guy was catching them and giving them to the family who was there at 4am.  We would have too but they left before we did.Bored, want an adventure?  Go catch some crabs.

<review# 375,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/25/2013,11/13/2013,119,199,10,15,12>STOP THE CAR!!!!The Beast was roaring down Pleasure House Road one day when out of the corner of my eye, I DIDN'T see the sign for the Memphis BBQ place that I never managed to go to.  In its place, though, was a sign that intertwined the flags of the Philippines and US.  More Pinoy in this part of town is exactly what the doctor ordered!  I roared The Beast into a spot and entered.The place is clean as a whistle!  Before you can let that fact sink in, though, you will be greeted by some of the nicest people to ever run an eating establishment.  Walk to the back and you will see a small buffet table set up with a smiling server standing behind it.  Tour Guide is actually a better term than server.  If you are new to Filipino Food, a white person that can't remember or pronounce the right words for the food, or maybe of Filipino Descent but never quite learned the food names (or how to use chopsticks....you KNOW who you are....), then this is the place for you!  Our Tour Guide will explain each dish without saying that ANY of it tastes like chicken.  I loaded up on Adobo, Pancit, BBQ, and a sausage.  No lumpia this trip, I didn't want to make a pig of myself.  At the top of the buffet table there was also a plate full of Turon!  Everything on my plate was worth eating.  I'd go back again and again again, no problem, no regrets.  Lunch for 2 was less than $14 because they have a 3 entree for $4.99 lunch special.  They have other combinations as well, and from listening to our Tour Guide speak with some other guests, there is no way that she is going to let cost get in the way of you filling your belly and enjoying the experience.  If you are the type that has a Lawrence Welk Pandora Channel programmed into the Lincoln Town Car,  Mariam's also serves up hamburgers, cheeseburgers, onion rings, chicken sandwiches, and various other flavors of Food for White People.  I have no intention of ever reviewing or tasting that food, though... but there was  a group of ladies at another table that were all about some burgers.  As I was leaving, they were ravaging the beef, flinging ketchup everywhere.  Guess the burgers and such are good as well.But let's get back to the star of the show.  The Pancit here is wonderful but different from the Pancit you can find at other places not too far away.  Not better, not worse, just different.  In a pleasant sort of way.  Same can be said for the other dishes I tried.  Don't consider Mariam's your New Favorite as much as another place to put into the weekly rotation!  There are now at least 3 Filipino Options for Lunch within a 10 minute drive of Little Creek NAB...and that probably raises the real estate values by at least 25%.If you are looking for some grub for your next big get together, Mariam's sells 16OZ of any entree for $4.99 and 32OZ for $9.99.  100 pieces of Lumpia will set you back $40.  Mariam's is now on my speed dial.  If I could figure out a way to make 911 calls ring at Mariam's, believe me, I would!But one other thing that I want to stress....the service!  The people that work here are truly some of the nicest and most genuine people that I've met in the restaurant business here.  The smiles are not forced, when they tell you to have a great day, they really mean it.  The entire experience felt more like going over to a friend's house for lunch than going to eat at a restaurant.  Although they've only been open 3 weeks, it seems that they have already drawn a crowd of regulars.Should you go?  Yes, of course you should!  When I'm in town, this will be a once a week place for me for sure.My little part of town is starting to get some great dining options all of a sudden!  Mariam's is certainly a cornerstone of that list of options, and I truly hope that they are around for the long haul.5 Stars!

<review# 377,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,10/29/2013,11/11/2013,163,183,4,9,7>Bike racks, bike racks, bike racks! Please and thank you! Such a clever name, Streats, oozes "hipster" and "trendy." With that aside, I felt like I wasn't in Norfolk any more. This place reminded me of a spot you would see in Brooklyn. From the Rothko-esque paintings to the awesome garage door, you could tell this was definitely well put together. Let's get down to the business! The food!  Affordable. Tapas style, with a select "dinner" size entrées. But with that in mind, it is still tapas style, so it can add up pretty quickly if you end up ordering pretty much the whole menu like we did. Started with the Dukkah, a grilled flatbread with oil and spices. Take a peek from my photos to see what it looks like. It's not much presentation wise but boy was it delicious! Pretty simple but definitely great :) a fellow elite, Julia, ordered the Chinese Marbled Tea Eggs, which both looked and tasted interesting. Our table had ordered the Meatloaf, the Chicken Satay, the Fish taco, the Kombu Dashi Udon, and the hot dog. All were good. But the fan fave was the chicken satay. The hot dog was apparently a little on the salty side and the meatloaf could use a little more salt and pepper. The udon was alright, it too could have used a little more spices to give it a bolder flavor. To cap our night, we had the tres leches, the hockey pokey ice cream and the special dessert of the evening, some variation of a cream puff. The toffee on the ice cream made it such a hit! If you must fulfill your sweet tooth, get the ice cream! Service was okay. He mumbled quite a bit and I could hardly hear him. Not awful by any means, but not overly impressive either. However, the gentleman who sat us was great! He was excited to seat us. Pretty good first time experience but nothing spectacular. We may come back real soon for another round of tastings. It also doesn't hurt that it's located within our bike route.

<review# 380,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/21/2013,11/8/2013,59,189,2,7,4>Buttercream Cupcake Cafe has the best cupcakes in the area, I promise.  They live up to their namesake.  The cake is so moist yet fluffy.  It is probably an insane amount of frosting, I'll admit.  But you won't regret it.I think I've tried all the flavors in the past year.  My favorite is the "Strawberry," as you can taste the pureness of the fruit in every bite.The "Banana Pudding" cupcake is quite messy, as it is filled with banana pudding and topped with a vanilla wafer.  Still, oh so good.The only difference in the "Wedding Cake" and the "Original Diva" are the colors of the frosting, so that's a throwaway flavor in my book.All the other flavors are so true to what they're supposed to be.  And I can appreciate that, once I get past the typos on the menus, the websites, and in the actual cafe.
<review# 381,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/26/2013,11/7/2013,96,146,,4,5>Where do I begin mon!I have heard of this place and never really looked into it, then after hearing from some coworkers that it was good i decided to try it out with my buddy. Well let me tell you, I am happy this place is so close to my work because this place is fan-Fking-tastic. The place is in a location where you would never expect a restaurant like this to be, right next to the DMV, in a building that looks like its full of suits.... but instead is full of fantastic food. This is Jamaican BBQ, its spicy, its tasty, its smoked and its not cheap to make and time intensive, so its not really cheap unless you are going to get just one item with sides. I had to try the brisket, pork and chicken and it cost me over 20$, this is not an issue for me however because I have been to BBQ locations in Richmond (classic BBQ) and paid this much if not more. Fact of the matter is... Good BBQ is not cheap to make!Every bite is awesome, various sauces at the table from BBQ to vinegar, spicy sauce ect, mix and match and  enjoy as every bite highlights a spice or flavor pulling you further into a food coma you wont want to wake up from....I sneaked a few Grilled String beans from my buddy's plate and let me tell you, HOLY String bean batman it was some good S^%#!I am hoping my fellow Yelp Elite members take note of this location and go check it out!, I would love to have a Yelp Event here to show case the wonderful food and staff. The place is kept clean, tables are cleaned off quickly and attentively, I hope they can expand their location or move into a place better suited to get the Attention they should get because this is one of the Hidden Gems in my area and I plan to come here more often in fact... we just named this "Payday Lunch"

<review# 383,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/6/2013,11/5/2013,66,117,5,6,5>Greek fest drinking game- drink every time someone, anyone says opa! or complains about the lines for the food. Within five minutes you'll get a sweet buzz!Been coming to this festival for a long, long time.  Is it a little overpriced?  Maybe.  Is the ground almost always wet the day we go?  Yes.  Is it hard to find a place to sit with your big honking tray of food?  Absolutely.  Is it worth it?  Damn right it is.You'll wind up spending at least $40-$50 on food alone for two people.  But it's a good amount of food.  Get the Lamb shank.  You'll feel like Fred Flintstone.  And its one of the most delicious herb and olive oil marinated hunks of meat that you'll ever have the pleasure of eating outside.  The Moussaka is always banging.  But always save room for the Loukamades.  Honey sweetened puffs of fried dough.  These things are naughty.  These things will make you get in a fight with your loved ones because you ate the last one.  And you have to eat them within a certain time span or else they lose all their magic and happiness.  We got an order to go and by the time we got home they weren't as puffy and light and happy anymore.  Still sweet and delicious, but just not the same.The arts and craft area inside the building is also great.  We always find some cool jewelry or art every time we come.  And you get to meet the artists and craft people which is cool too.This is a must do every year if you are in Hampton Roads.

<review# 385,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/16/2013,11/3/2013,122,469,,7,5>I'd been wanting to come here for awhile because I was intrigued about the history of the original building (that was built in 1906 for a real estate firm) and thought it would be a great place to go for my husband's birthday. The outside of the building looks like a cool, old school bank but we pretty much found that's where most of the original architectural integrity ended (aside from the original standing vault in the downstairs bar area). Inside, while everything was very polished and chic (as most of the interior had been completely restored from when the building was abandoned years ago), it just felt extremely formal and a bit stuffy. White tableclothes, lots of extra plateware, glassware, and silverware on the table, amuse bouche, and jazz musak playing in the background. Maybe this is typical of most steakhouses, I don't know; we kind of decided we don't like that vibe for the future. Now while they had an extremely wide and varied wine by the bottle list, we found their wine/glass to be lacking. I wasn't drinking because I'm pregnant and even if I wasn't I very rarely like committing to an entire bottle, preferring to switch up my wines as I go (even if it's not the "better value"). So when a restaurant doesn't have an ample wine/glass list, that always annoys me...especially for a high-end steak restaurant. He found they offered no Syrah's by the glass so he settled on a pretty decent Cab (Avalon from Napa). We started with the lump crabmeat cocktail served with butter and cocktail sauce. We basically didn't touch the cocktail sauce since it tasted like Heinz cocktail sauce from the bottle (seriously, they couldn't have made a nice in-house horseradish cocktail sauce?) and the actual lump crabmeat came out cold. I thought this was REALLY weird. Have you ever had cold crab meat? Not too appetizing. The butter didn't have any other garlic or seasoning to it either, so I found this appetizer to be pretty underwhelming and wished we had gone with the prosciutto wrapped motz.Fortunately from here our dining experience went uphill; I ordered the 6oz filet and my husband got the ribeye (thanks to many of the yelp reviews on here raving about it). We were kind of going back and forth trying to figure out whose was better, they were both SOOO DELICIOUS. My husband said this was one of the best steaks of his life. HIS LIFE, PEOPLE. I have to admit, hands off, they cooked the steaks to perfection and every bite was bliss. My filet was like cutting into butter and his ribeye had this amazing smoky flavor to it that I've never tasted from a ribeye before. Not TOO marbley either. We were both lost in our steaks for awhile. We also ordered the garlic spinach and the grilled portabella and onions as sides. The garlic spinach was decent (I've had better, however) but oh my god the portabella and onions was the best choice of the night. It really cut up the monotony of the steaks and added amazing textures and flavor profiles we wouldn't have otherwise gotten. If you get no other side, get the grilled portabella and onions. We were completely full but I had noted it was my husband's birthday in the reservation and was very impressed that they had prepared a small chocolate torte with a candle on it for him on the house. I love when restaurants do these simple but hospitable gestures. It, of course, was amazing.Overall, Byrd & Baldwin is really a class act. I venture to say it is the best steakhouse in Hampton roads. Additionally, we didn't find wait times to be excessive at all and we were there on a bustling Thursday evening. All the stuffiness upstairs in the formal dining isn't really our cup of tea so if you still want to try out their amazing steaks but you're looking for a less formal environment, then you need to eat downstairs in their basement bar area that has more of that 1906 architectural integrity and casual feel to it.
<review# 386,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/27/2013,11/2/2013,139,167,3,4,3>What a lovely, lovely studio.So, because I am big on the things that REALLY matter in life, when we first moved here a little bit ago, the first things I needed to look up were: 1) Where will I eat and drink?  2) Where will I see rad music?  3) Where will I get tattooed?  4)  Where will I get my hurr did and 5) Where will I get my yoga on?Tribal Yoga, of course, came up as one of the only yoga options on the peninsula outside of the gym.  That got me a bit nervous, I'll be honest.  But those fears were immediately eliminated upon entering the studio.  I was greeted warmly, shown around the facilities, and then let in to the studio.  The studio space itself was intimate without being claustrophobic, and nice and dimly lit the whole time during class.Both instructors I had were great.  I've been doing yoga for about five or six years, but never with much consistency for very long.  I always love coming back to it, and while there are always kinks to get out after a hiatus from "the mat," there's an extent to which it's a bit like riding a bicycle and it all comes back to your muscle memory fairly quickly.  At the beginning of my second class here I was kind of NOT feeling it and things were hurting and I was muttering a little under my breath, but by the end, GOD did I feel good.Their class times are perfect for the employed and are generally 1hr and 15min, with the exception of their two noon classes on Thursday and Tuesday which are 1 hour exactly -- perfect for a little lunch time yoga fix if you're in the area.  They also have a 9:30-10:45 time most days, which is perfect for the temporarily unemployed (like yours truly) and the permanently unemployed housewives among you.Both classes I've taken have been their "Tribe I" all levels class.  It really was a great all level class, with lots of modifications for making things more or less advanced.Overall, a really lovely studio, and not simply for being one of the only options in the area, but despite the lack of competition, a really stand-up place that could hold its own with the rest of them, even in more Yoga-fied metro areas, like the Bay Area or the Pacific Northwest.

<review# 388,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/25/2013,10/31/2013,37,327,,3,3>Ah the oceanfront.  I like this area.  We lived down here for years and when we come to the beach I prefer this area.  We love the boardwalk and bike paths.  I rarely walk on the store side of things.  But if you like junky stores with cheap stuff they have plenty.  And the streets are tree lined for some shade.  The beach is wide and plenty of room even on those busy weekends.  But when they do the festivals with booths on the boardwalk avoid!  It's crowded and packed.  Best when the boardwalk is wide open.  The water here is decent for boogie boarding.  Enough waves.  Better than Sandbridge area.  We don't like the rip tides here though.  They are strong and the kids can't go too far out.  Lifeguards here are on top of things, but there are drownings most years, so keep an eye on how far out you get.  The biggest downfall for the area is parking.  While there are a lot of lots, it's $10 on weekends.  We don't come down here at night, as it seems the crowd isn't so family friendly anymore.  We enjoy the day trips though.  It's great in spring or fall with no crowds and the kids can play in the sand and run around.  Summer gets crowded.  But it's still our favorite area for the beach b/c of all the restaurants and the boardwalk.
<review# 389,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/30/2013,10/30/2013,121,170,,2,4>I've luckily been able to visit here twice in the past few weeks.  I love the the fact that we have great gelato in Ghent.  The area has a number of froyo places; I love that too, but sometimes I want some good, something different, and Strawberry Fields fits the bill.  I love the freshness of the on-site homestyle gelato.  It's refreshing to see a a huge turbo-charged juicer behind the counter; that means there's some serious juicing going on there.  That can only lead to great sorbets and gelatos. The gelatos are great, but the fresh fruit flavors are spectacular - Mango is my favorite.I recently tried the Aztec Chocolate (I believe that was the name).  It was hot chocolate with the heat coming from chilies -- interesting and pure genius.  Maybe a better combo for chili-heads with a take on the combo of mint and chocolate.The last time I was there I had the Tagalong.  It was just like the famous cookie in gelato form.  Combine that with Fresh Cream and I was in heaven.I've had gelato at other establishments in the area - Ynot and Confetti.  Strawberry Field is above and beyond the best in the area.  It's not ice cream, it's not frozen yogurt, it's in a world all to its own.

There are always tons of excuses like the computer upstairs doesn't work, the credit card reader is offline, I can't remember who ordered what, the glasses aren't dirty they just have water spots (and lip prints). This most recent time I was there for Tuesday night $5 flights. The server told us 5 ppl only could order a flight of wine because only 5 flights fit on a tray. Ok, so then how many plates fit on a tray, can only 3 ppl order food bc only 3 plates fit on a tray!? Make two trips, right!?  We were told we could share 5 flights among the 8 ppl. If that's the case then we would just be ordering flights more frequently, saving the server no time at all, and causing annoying confusion among the party. From the time we were done eating, to the time we were handed our checks 50 minutes passed! I thought to myself, they must be really slammed downstairs bc there was only one other small table seated upstairs but nope, I walked downstairs and it looked pretty scarce. Dinner took 2.5 hours from the time we were seated until the time we were handed our checks. I don't know how long it took my friends to pay their checks and actually get their cards back bc I just threw down cash and hightailed it out of there. I ordered a special feature that night. It was grilled shrimp over plain quinoa with stewed diced (seemingly canned) tomato on top.  So 8 times now I've been to Lubo. First 3 times in 2012 were great. <review# 393,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/13/2013,10/26/2013,38,55,4,2,6>Can't knock the hustle of this place.My friends and I like to hang out in Norfolk and afterwards, more often than not, we like to return to the classic.... Doumars.The history behind this drive-in is enough reason to visit. Sticking to their roots, the simplicity of their food and dessert is evidently what they do, and all they'll ever have to do, to survive the times. Not to mention the staff is great whether you decide to dine-in or stay in your car. Obviously, one can argue that they've tried better food or ice cream elsewhere, but that's not what it's all about. You come here to respect the O.G. in the game and eat a cheap but satisfying meal, while admiring the fact that they've changed very little to their craft and haven't conformed to all the civilization and renovations surrounding them.Definitely recommend this location to those visiting the area, especially to see where the waffle cone all began.I guess you can call this Sonic Drive-In's great grandfather. Respect your elders!

<review# 395,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/5/2013,10/24/2013,29,248,2,8,2>(My mini story- skip this paragraph if you want the real review.) I was driving along Rt 264 towards virginia beach to watch the fireworks. 0.5 mi. before my exit was to arrive, the ETA per GPS went from 11 min to 34 min and i began to see shiny taillights of cars backing up. I mmediately veered my car to the right ( after cheking my side view mirror ofcourse) , and took the first exit i could find before i could get trapped back in that mess! i love fireworks, but not so much.  Anyhow, longstory short, i called up a few friends, yelped a hookah bar, prayed for the best and rolled into here.I gotta say, i was taken aback.Vibe: So, this place looks like a normal tapas bar on outside, nothing fancy. it has its own private lot and is immediately adjacent to Venue 112, which is also a kinda fun bar. (Side note- yelp has Venue 112 listed as the hookah bar- which is NOT. Central 111 is.) Anyhow, It  has two rooms- ones a dance floor/bar , and the room in the back was a smoking room- with the hookah and also served food and alcohol. It has a classy/trashy feel to it. It was kinda odd- the inside was pink/purple with beads all over- classy part. Trashy part- their had tv's around the minibar which kept playing this music video with people masturbating - on repeat! Im not sure what vibe they were trying to evoke, but it was definitely a conversation starter. More important stuff- Hoookah- They serve al fakheer(15$) and starbuzz(18$) ( 2 of my favorite brands). My problem was with the hookah itself- i dont think it was set up right- too many coals made it harsh and we had to keep adjusting it. Also, our hoses were not pulling properly, so she had to change them. Im an amateur, but my hookah at home comes out ten times better with less complications. The premium hookah ( stabuzz flavors) come with a mini appetizer platter- which is genius because we did end up ordering food because of it. But the food was GREAT. I have never had a better falafel, ever. Oh, we also got a cheese platter- it came with 3 type of cheese + apples, strawberries, crackers, YUM! Prices- pricey. We had just been to venue 112 earlier where drinks were 5-7$. here, drinks started at 9, which is expensive and therefore i didn't get any. Blue moon was 5$ ( at venue 112 it was 3$)  Extra hose was 2$ per person. ADD ICE to bowl was 2$ ( which is not on their menu and server did not tell me!). Service- was awesome. Our server nina was great. She came by often to check up on us and to chit chat. Next time you go, ask for her to be your server. Shes sweet:)My suggested plan as a smarter consumer- go to venue 112, drink it up first, then go to venue 112, smoke it up, then back to venue 112 and dance the night down. The end.
<review# 396,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/8/2013,10/23/2013,298,491,3,4,5>El Taco Loco has been on my radar for the last few weeks after seeing stellar reviews come across from Yelp friends. I have been looking for a really good Mexican place for a while. It seems that my old go to places are going down hill. So how excited was I today to be in the area and give it a test drive.Once I finally located it way off VB Blvd beside Harris Teeter and off Little Neck Rd. I almost had an accident. My car had a mind of it's own and insisted on redirecting my final destination to Braise, However, I overpowered the steering wheel and went a couple hundred feet around the corner and parked. I had no idea this taco joint was even here, let alone that such good buzz had been spreading around town.I arrived around 12:30 PM and the lot was not too busy. The parking area had some debris, but it was a really gusty day and can excuse it. I noticed an out door seating area that was closed with the cool windy conditions. I was ready to enter and starved.When entering the door I was immediately greeted by my waiter. A bar is right inside the door and I saw some real yummy looking margaritas ready to be served. Darn, this would not be the day to try one, maybe next time if the meal lived up to expectations. I saw seven TV's in and around the bar/dining area. The eating area was pretty much empty with only a few customers. Everything looked spotless... every table cleaned and cleared, as well the floor was completely free of trash. The waiter seated me and provided a menu. Hot chips and salsa followed by a junior waiter who was over the top nice and welcoming. Two kinds of salsa white and red. I tried both and usually do prefer the white, but red good too. Oh, the chips were so good and there seemed like a million of them in this big basket.It did not take me long when the waiter came back to order the $5.99 lunch special... #5 a Beef Burrito, Beef Taco and rice. I was not expecting a lot for this price so I ate away at the delicious chips. Within 10 minutes my very hot plate came out. Visually is looked scrumptious. Steam was roaring off the plate and before I knew it the dish was all mine to enjoy. Where to start, no detailed instructions, no road map with this bad boy. I tried a little of each at the beginning and found all just incredibly tasty. But I ended up eating the taco first. It had such an awesome crispy shell and was filled with beef, lettuce and tomato. It would end up being my favorite part of the meal. I am not a big fan of rice, but believe me when I say it was solid. The burrito was large, flavored nice, but not too spicy. The meal was quality in every way.The waiter checked on me once and provided a drink refill. I was not high maintenance today and wanted left alone with this huge plate of Mexican goodness. It took a while and I struggled a bit, but prevailed after about twenty minutes. I never had a chance with the chips, as good as they were just too many for one man to devour. However, the plate was clean and I anticipate a few notches off the belt may need to be loosened tomorrow. This is not a meal I would endorse for lunch every day. But whoa, would I ever love to not have to worry about blowing up and trying all the specials in one week... WARNING!!!! don't do this or suffer the consequences.I hit the restroom up prior to paying the bill and found it tidy. I took a little look around and saw a large second room for big parties, or over flow. The check was at the table as I requested and the amount was correct and under $7. Seriously, this much food, the service was awesome and atmosphere comfortable. What more I ask could any customer want.. Well, I did try to find a secret passage over to Bobby's Braise for desert, but to no avail. I will come back and want to bring family and friends to check this place out.  RECOMMEND HIGHLY if you are in the area swing by and you too will see what all the YELP is about.

Try having a conversation with your friends, if they ask where you went to eat, say EAT and laugh when they repeat themselves and say yeah eat; waiting for you to reply with the restaurant name. Cheers!

<review# 405,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/31/2013,10/14/2013,18,133,1,5,5>For an 'authentic' mexican restaurant in Norfolk, Jessy's is prettayy, prettay, pretty good. I'd stick with 3.5 stars, but I really appreciated the service so my impression was boosted up a bit.The good: This is a perfect 'by-the-beach' mexican restaurant in Ocean View. Coming from California I have had a lot of mexican food, but this place holds it's own. You'll quickly notice that not all all of the menu is 'authentic' (re: mexican submarine sandwiches?), but does that mean the food isn't really good? Not at all. Chips and salsa cost extra ($2--see 'the bad') but they are free refills! The salsa is 'home made' and was pretty good! They give you plenty so you probably wont even want refills unless you have a few people sharing, but I like the option! We also got a tostada, which was piled high with toppings--even if there was maybe a little too much sour cream. Everything we got tasted fresh and the chips were clearly freshly re-fried (in a good way). A big plus about this place is that the service was awesome from start to finish. Every employee (all women it seemed like?) was incredibly nice and helpful and our water glasses were never empty! The not so good: Like other reviewers said, everything here is itemized: chips, sides, etc. Sometimes they make that clear and sometimes they don't. I don't really like being tricked so I think they could be a little more forthcoming. The prices here are also clearly slightly too high. I know it's rough times and everything, but the fact is that they are in an outdated stripmall in a not so busy area of town, so why should it be anything but cheap? I think we ended up paying $25 after tip for 3 tacos, a tostada, beans/rice, and chips. If it were gourmet, fine, but this is more of a bare-bones (albeit a good one) situation so I think they could afford to cut down the prices a few bucks.Overall: This was exactly what we were looking for here in Norfolk and I think I'll go back next time I'm in that area of town. The reviews were mostly correct but the itemization of everything and the prices got a little out of hand. The service here definitely puts it over the edge of one of the better places in the area!
<review# 406,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/5/2013,10/13/2013,91,52,2,5,3>CALLING ALL BEER LOVERS!!! This place has beers out the wazoo. If you're looking to just try a bunch of beers, they offer half-pours as well as full-pours. If you're looking to bring beer home, they'll fill up a growler for you too! I love coming to this place at night and sitting at their tables outside. The waitstaff loves beer as much as their customers do, so they're able to give really solid recommendations if you don't even know where to start. Sometimes the amount of beer they have can be overwhelming, so don't be afraid to ask a question or two! If you're a cheese eater (not me), they have cheese boards here too. If you don't eat cheese, but are interested like me, they have a great beer-to-cheese pairing chart on their menu as well. I always find myself exploring something new when I come here and I don't mind that at all. Overall, come here to enjoy a drink or two, and maybe grab some cheese.

As there were three bartender and only 10 patrons, I typically expect a higher level of service.The noise level was perfect, the bar was separate from the general dining area.  I rarely drink, but they had a full bar and a fancy looking wine storage room.  They also had some unique beer on tap, including local Smartmouth.  Overall, I think Braise just needs to work out the kinks in service and perhaps a better bread course.  I look forward to coming back!
<review# 415,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/18/2013,10/4/2013,63,174,,10,5>For those of us who frequent the local Italian scene at Hilltop and along Laskin Road, La Dolce Vita is owned and operated by the daughter and son-in-law of the family that has run the outstanding La Bella Italia for many years.  Both spots are comfortable, unpretentious places, with kitchens that strive for authentic, fresh, primarily Italian offerings,  not haute cuisine.  La Dolce Vita has only been in operation for less than two months, and is currently presenting itself as a bakery and wine bar cafe.  The fare seems understandably to still be in a state of flux, however --- during our visit around lunchtime on a Saturday, in addition to the most yummy lobster tail I've had since our last trip to NYC, and two freshly baked cupcakes that were moist and not too sweet, we enjoyed a wonderful Mediterranean sandwich with red peppers, arugula, smooth and creamy goat cheese, fresh basil and olive oil, and served on freshly baked multigrain bread with the best crust I've had in a long time.  A small side of pasta primavera, served with a lightly seasoned olive oil, completed the much too large a feast; we took half of our sandwich home, for a snack later on. While there is wine displayed throughout the store, and presumably it's served later in the day or evening, the cafe's vibe, at least during the lunch hour, is really more of a comfortable European cafe/pâtisserie, not a wine bar in the sense that Americans have come to know the term.  In better weather, you might mistake your sitting at the tables on the outside veranda as a pleasant stop on the Via Vittorio Veneto.  And you might think your rich cannoli or creamy lobster tail had just come from the case at Ferrara's in Little Italy.  It's that kind of place --- authentic light foods and pastries, freshly prepared with subtle flavors by very talented and pleasant folks with a long history in the restaurant business.  A very welcome addition to our part of Va Beach --- we're glad you're here, and we'll be back!
