<review# 417,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/14/2013,10/2/2013,99,254,,5,4>From a music lover's perspective, this festival is fantastic. I loved the selected artists - so many good choices. I loved that it was set up across three different stages, and that the acts were staggered so you could meander back and forth with little to no break between music. What I found interesting was that each of the three stages had its own distinct feel, yet each of them were very inviting and comfortable in their own way. The smallest area had some shade, comfy couches, and hammocks, in addition to a gorgeous water view. The largest stage offered a big, open, grassy field with plenty of room to dance or lay in the sun - with another gorgeous water view to the right. The medium sized stage offered shade and lots of seating. I really appreciated and enjoyed the fact that we could rotate between the three stages to consistently hear live music - it almost felt like three tiny festivals. From an art lover's perspective, I wasn't so impressed. I think the festival could greatly benefit from more artists - both in quantity and in quality. I noticed that at least 1/3 of  the artist booths were more like mobile thrift stores selling second-hand clothes and other miscellaneous items. I can go to a thrift store on my own time. I was hoping to see local art, but at this point, I would've been happy with just actual art. The glass blowers and the make-your-own-art-from-scraps booth were the highlights of the art portion for me.As festival grows, I hope to see more food trucks in attendance. The festival could benefit from more food in general - though for today's somewhat meager attendance, the amount of food trucks worked out just right. Overall, though, I had a fantastic time and will definitely return to next year's festival.
<review# 418,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/14/2013,10/1/2013,183,190,,8,3>In all honesty, I love coming here.  This place has dependably good Chesapeake Bay seafood all around that is as fresh as fresh can be.  When you come in, you enter through their seafood market.  So, feel free to stop in and get them to filet some fish for you take home or get your little seafood extravaganza with a wide selection of shrimp, crablegs, scallops, and many options for fish.  They can also set you up for your own fishing trip with your buddies.  Now, on to the restaurant.  So, there are 2 separate areas I enjoy here.  First, the indoor bar--I come here for good drinks, great bartenders that always take care of me with a generous pour, and hot dog!--they have some awesome happy hour specials, not just on drinks, but on the food too.  Come here Sunday through Thursday from 4-7PM and you will get a great hook up with a tasty cheap dinner.  Keep in mind, Happy Hour is only valid at the bar and the bar tables, which includes this 20-top in front of the bar--this is definitely not reserved for just one party, just sit down and chat it up with some randoms and enjoy the bevs.  So, the best part of Dockside really is the outside.  I love to walk out on the patio and have a seat and enjoy all the boats coming by.  I will start out with a pomegranate mojito or sangria and just sip on it for a bit before I order, watching the sunset.  Some evenings, they also have some chill music to wind you down and get your hips moving a little.  For apps, they have lots of goodies.  Some of the best include clams casino, stuffed shrimp, fried shrimp and anything off the raw bar--oysters, clams, some of the best steamed shrimp.  For you blue crab lovers, they have you covered so you can come and have your own blue crab fest and the best part is you don't have to clean up afterwards.  For me, I am a softshell lover--the entire softshell season, I come here and just get repeated orders of softshells.  Not everybody knows how to do softshells, but Dockside softshells are among the best in the area.  They also offer like 10 or so different fish for catch of the day--fried, grilled, broiled, blackened or topped with crabmeat.    They also have sandwiches, crabcakes, seafood baskets, pastas, she-crab soup--you will love it.  The crowd is a little older than Chick's generally, but who cares...the food is much better.  Cheers!FYI: for whatever reason, their address is listed as being on Shore Dr.  This may be their technical addess, but they are really at the 2200 block of Vista Circle.
<review# 419,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/24/2013,9/30/2013,24,184,2,7,2>Another place where I have driven by it almost every day and just never stopped!I finally stopped by and OMG, I wish I had gone there sooner!First they have about 9 Beers on Draft, including PBR which is $1.25 all the time. Other drafts include Guiness, Blue Moon, Angry Orchard, Sam's Seasonal, Yuengling, a local brew I don't remember the name of, some kind of IPA, and Bud Light.Their burger menu is AWESOME. They have some really good combos for the burger, and you can choose your size patty. For the large size, on the basic burger, it is only $6.24. I don't see how they are making any money!They hand make all of the patties, and they even hand cut their fries. I am not really a fry person, just because most places use the exact same frozen fries from Sysco. I love that they hand cut and hand season all of their fries. The burger was amazingly well seasoned, presented on a great bun that did not fall apart, and served HOT. They have specials every day on food and drinks. Monday is 49 cent wings, Tuesday is bogo on appetizers, etc. Even specials on Fri Sat and Sun. They have 3 pay per game, not by the hour, pool tables, and quite a few tvs around the room. I did not ask if they get any of the sports packages, or PPVs.They do Karaoke on Fridays, and Saturdays they have bands. Everyday from 4pm to 7pm is Happy Hour, which is MORE specials. This place would be great for a group, they have two counter like rails near the pool tables that would seat 10-12. They are in perfect position to see the tvs, and use the pool tables.

<review# 421,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/17/2013,9/28/2013,83,478,1,2,2>This little gem is located in the Cypress Point Shopping Center and is across a small strip mall area from my new favorite antique haunt, Cypress Point Antique Mall.  So after looking in there, I wandered over to this unexpected find (it wasn't in Yelp so I had no idea it was here) to look around. I found a lot of very nice vintage items, the lady working behind the counter was exceedingly friendly and kind (in an older, "how can I help you sweetheart?", "let me know if you need me honey." Southern granny kind of way). I was specifically looking for a plateau mirror and found two in the glass jewelry display cases throughout the store but was told they aren't generally for sale.  The lady working did call the owner to ask if she would sell them and at first she said no but she did later say she had a few if I liked those that she might be willing to bring in for me to see that she would sell.  I left my name and number and got a call back yesterday that there are a few pieces for me to go look at and see if I want to purchase one.  The store isn't huge, but it does have several rooms full of vintage goodies all in good shape just waiting to be loved and purchased by someone.  There is plenty of parking in the shopping mall parking lot and there weren't a ton of people milling around or a lot of through traffic so it was a very pleasant experience and I always appreciate a call back. I'll make this one of my go-to Antique stores when I'm looking for something in particular and in this area.  It's worth a look if you like antiquing!
<review# 422,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/13/2013,9/27/2013,129,351,,9,3>More than it looks. - It doesn't look like much from the outside except a typical store in the middle of a strip mall that's kinda hidden away from the street. The inside isn't much better. It's not like it's ugly, dirty or anything like that just small and plain. The restaurant is long and narrow with only about 10 tables, each one comfortably seating 2 customers per table but a couple tables could be arranged to seat 4 (2 side-by-side and 1 on each end). Service: Only two people were working at this mom and the pop restaurant when we arrived so even with only a 1/3 of the place full and the call in "to go" orders had us waiting for quite a long time before anyone came by to take our order. When someone did it turned out to be a very nice female (I think one of the owners) who waited on us. Although we had a long wait it wasn't too bad because she was rather funny and made everyone feel like we were visiting a close friends home and talking with his mother as she was preparing dinner.Drink menu was limited to non-alcoholic but not a big deal for our family. Our daughter ordered the Thai Tea. She loved it but it was a bit to sweet for me. Meals: I order the Pad Si Ew, which was kinda like a Pad Thai with wide noodles, no bean sprouts but tastes better...at least to me! My  wife ordered the Pad Thai and it was dang good too, tops compared to any other Thai place we've eaten at in Hampton Roads. Still the Pad Si Ew was better : ) Our daughter had Thai Noodle Soup and it was equally awesome! Desert: Sweet Rice with Jackfruit, which is sticky rice with coconut milk, sugar, jackfruit topped with peanuts. Turns out I was the only one that liked it but I think it was because my wife and daughter don't care for rice as a desert.  Cleanliness: tables were clean but had a slight stickiness to them I think had more to do with the finish than any residual food or drink. The male bathroom was clean but also doubled as a cleaning closest with a mop bucket, mop, deep industrial sink with garden hose and jugs of cleaning fluids...but it was clean.   I also watched another employee show up that looked like family (turned out he wasn't) come in the restaurant to start work. He washed his hands immediately as he walked so throughly it seemed as if he was a scrubbing in for surgery. Overall: OK I know the wait, size, look of the place and the bathroom / cleaning closet should give this place a 3 Star rating BUT the food was awesome! It's hands down the best Thai for Chesapeake and arguably the best this side of the river. Also the staff was very nice. I can't help it 4 Stars...and I'll be back!

<review# 430,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/19/2013,9/19/2013,155,241,,4,6>The first time I ever got to sample Mannino's was at their Portsmouth location for a Yelp Elite event. I think a lemon wedge or two would have been a nice accompaniment.I got the Pollo Franchese and it was so good. Great lemony savory flavor. I opted for the mushrooms and artichokes though I would have liked a few more than 2 halves of an artichoke heart. Still, the flavor was spectacular and the portions were huge.My husband went for the Spaghetti Bolognese with meatballs. Now I love a good Bolognese sauce with it's deep flavors cooked for hours but I don't much care for meatballs. That is until I had Mannino's meatballs. (may or may not be a slight exaggeration)Of course we got desert. Ok .. we got 2. The classic cannoli stuffed with a vanilla chocolate chip ricotta mixture and a chocolate hazelnut gelato. It kind of ruins my husbands experience if he has to wait an extensive amount of time for his water/tea to be refilled but we didn't have that problem at all here.All in all this was a great food experience.My only sad note is that they don't allow dogs in their outdoor patio. I understand that some restaurants choose not to because of "health inspectors" but whenever I see an open patio I can't help but wish all of them allowed dogs.
<review# 431,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/27/2013,9/18/2013,73,159,,15,6>I'm actually pretty annoyed with the reviewers who tell you to go to DC instead. I was just there this past weekend, and it was one of the most boring zoos I've ever been to.The VA Zoo is one of the more personable and well-maintained zoos I've been to. I can almost always find a zookeeper or volunteer to tell me more about an animal, and we've become familiar with names, ages, genders, and the usual hangouts in their exhibits (the animals, not the zookeepers!). The barnyard area is currently closed for renovation, as is an area (no animals there normally anyways) near the African Village Restaurant. Construction of a new Animal Wellness Campus is underway. The zoo has had a successful year with its breeding programs. A new baby siamang, giraffe, squirrel monkey, cassowary, and three Aldabra tortoises have joined their parents at the zoo, as well as several new hyraxes and prairie dog pups. This is in addition to the new pair of tigers now at the zoo.On to addressing the orangutans. They made a beautiful new outdoor exhibit for them to climb and explore, but yes, they do spend much of their time indoors still. Find a zookeeper and ask about Schnitz's story. It's heartbreaking. Pepper, the female orangutan, won't stay outside for long without his company.This zoo has an excellent flow to it, and can be walked through in about 2 hours. The membership is worth the price if you have young'uns, and tokens for the zoo train are reasonably priced as well.There are vending machines for soda and water placed throughout the zoo, and several stands for popcorn, cotton candy, and ice cream on the weekends. The Beastro snack bar near the Reptiles/Small Mammals has ice cream cones, hot dogs, and other things to eat. Outdoor seating only over there. African Village Restaurant has indoor (A/C & heat) and outdoor seating, and offers french fries, pizza, cheeseburgers, Boca vegan burgers, salads, pretzels, and other goodies. Prices are comparable to any diner out in town.The fountains in the Compass Rose Plaza as you enter are generally on from Memorial Day through Labor Day, so make sure you pack some towels.Support this zoo so they can continue their expansion and conservation efforts!

<review# 434,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/28/2013,9/15/2013,40,107,1,12,5>This place has a really neat concept. You pick any 4 fruits/veg/herb you want (after 4, each additional fruit is $.60), and they blend it up for you. 16oz is 4.99, 20oz is 5.99. I prefer this place to Tropical Smoothie cafe, where they dump a ladle full of sugar into your drink without asking.Pros:No artificial ingredients, just 100% of whatever fruits you want! They also have health supplements I hope one day to learn more about, like Maca, Bee Pollen, etc, so that's great if you're into thatCons:All high powered commercial grade blenders (this place uses Blendtec brand, if you're a kitchen appliance nerd like me) infuse a bit of heat, which is why most smoothie places add ice, and sugar (to add flavor when the blended ice melts). These smoothies are 100% whole food smoothies with no added ice, so they might be a little warm when you get them.My favorite blend is Pineapple / Mango / Avocado / Spinach - the fruit adds a bit of sweetness, the avocado makes it all nice & creamy (without extra flavor), and the spinach has tons of Vitamin A.However, the menu can be REALLY OVERWHELMING if you're used to buying by smoothie name instead of ingredient.Tips:- If you want a creamy smoothie, add items like banana, avocado, cashews, almonds, coconut, almond milk- If you're new to green smoothies, start off with Spinach (mild, easy to mask flavor). Kale is great, but if you don't like veggies (why come here??), blend them with sweet citrus fruits, like pineapples / oranges. You won't be able to taste the kale at all.- Need a good sub for coffee? Get a smoothie with apple, ginger, jalapeno, & pineapple. Sure, there's no caffeine, but nothing'll wake you up quite like having your mouth burn up.I'll definitely be coming here until I bite the bullet & buy my own $600 high powered blender.

<review# 437,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/22/2013,9/12/2013,35,17,3,9,4>As rabid connoisseurs of Southeast Asian cuisine, we have been somewhat distraught over the recent closing of our favorite Vietnamese restaurant near home. When the craving struck, we were left with having to drive all the way to Ghent for what we always considered average at best Thai or Vietnamese options. Then hallelujah, praise the lord! Tonight we Yelped and found Sawasdee four miles from home. When we mapped the location, our expectations were somewhat tempered. I mean, a great Thai restaurant on Virginia Beach Boulevard's decrepit warehouse/retail stretch? But when we pulled up and beheld the well-kept, modern exterior and pots of herbs and chilies bursting with color out front, we began to smile.Inside, we were greeted by a friendly Thai waitress (I think she's the daughter of the owner and chef), a clean and sleek modern Asian décor, and gentle Thai music. The menu blew us away with a huge selection of traditional Thai and other Asian specialties: Five curry dishes (my partner LOVES him some curry, so he was thrilled), incredible seafood selections, four delicious-looking duck entrees, stir fry, and of course, the staple noodle dishes. We started out with the fresh roll and satay appetizers, which were both superb. At that point, we knew we had struck pay dirt and could not make up our minds about dinner. We wanted to try it all! I finally settled for a bowl of Tom Yum soup and the Yum Woon Sen salad, rationalizing that if they could make these two Thai standards with extra pizazz, I would be back to try everything else. My partner went for the "Thai hot" green curry (he's not happy until the paramedics are called.)The soup was earthy, spicy, and lemongrassy with not one but three large shrimp in it. The glass noodles in the salad were perfectly prepared, and the "special sauce" they dressed it with was a complex mix of rice wine vinegar, fish sauce, and some other ingredients I couldn't name but which worked incredibly well.Now, curry doesn't care for me, but I had to taste Andrew's. It was heavenly: smooth and creamy going down, and four-alarm heat on the back side. Just the way he likes it.Our meal was perfect in every way. The service was excellent and attentive. And the prices more than reasonable. Entrees range from $8 to $18. Try finding those prices in Ghent.Sawasdee has no ABC permits yet, but does offer a good, basic beer and wine selection, including Asian beers.Sawasdee has been open for less than a year, and it's obvious they are still trying to find a following. When we arrived at 6 PM, we were the only guests. But within the hour, another six or so tables came in, including two young Thai girls who sat next to us. That's always a good sign at an ethnic restaurant.Do yourself a favor if you enjoy Thai food. Run, do not walk, and check out Sawasdee for yourself. You won't be disappointed.

<review# 441,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,5/23/2013,9/8/2013,88,68,3,3,2>Located off of Nimmo Parkway in Virginia Beach and right across from Lucky Oyster Restaurant is a nice Greek restaurant, Yanni's Casual Greek.  I went here recently for dinner with my girl and her mom and I must say the restaurant has a nice layout and an inviting atmosphere with wood being the dominant theme inside. When you first walk in the bar is directly to the right of you and is a pretty large area. I would say you could seat about 15 or so and grab a drink while you watch any one of the two TVs.  Throughout the restaurant there are large paintings of various Greek locations done with pastels which brightens up the area. A nice touch for the casual restaurant. There are plenty of booths within with separate dining areas and a spacious outdoor dining area as well.We ordered the Tzatziki with Pita Bread and the Fried Zucchini with Tzatziki for our appetizers. The Fried Zucchini was the star of the two appetizers. Large strips of zucchini coated with a crunchy batter, can't go wrong with that! They provide 7 slices for $7 but well worth it if you're looking for a light app.The menu offers very familiar Greek dishes even though some are hard to pronounce, they do have traditional dishes like Pastitsio, Mousaka, Spanikopita and Gyros with various meats. Yanni's also offers entrees featuring Greek Pork Chops, Paidakia Lamb Chops, and Brizola Steak as well.I ended up getting the Bifteki Burger Pita with a side of soup instead of french fries.  I got the Avgolemono Soup which is a Lemon Chicken Soup.  The soup was delicious with a pleasant taste of lemon, a touch of cream, and had shredded chicken and orzo pasta in it as well. The "Burger" pita is more of a meatball pita with 3 large size meatballs coated with tzatziki, and tomato wrapped in gyro bread. Upon the first bite I immediately noticed how tender and flavorful the meatballs were and were not tough at all. Definitely a good size and for around $9 not a bad deal.Yanni's is a place you should check out if you're looking for a nice, casual dining experience and an introduction into the flavors of Greek cuisine. I'm sure I'll be making a trip back to try their other options as well as desserts and maybe become a fan of this place in the future."GET HIM TO THE GREEK!"

<review# 449,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/22/2013,8/31/2013,34,76,,5,4>One of the most romantic, intimate, fun and sexy places to eat in Hampton Roads.  Sitting outside is pleasant in the evening even in our summer heat because there is a constant breeze.  A menu that offers amazing options for every dietary restriction.  Fresh crab and seared tuna on crispy wontons with a wasabi drizzle, amazing!  Light and complex cioppino with a Red you can't buy locally, awesome!  These guys know good fish, seafood and fresh and rich flavors.  What you won't find is a menu of standard and boring proteins (chicken, big game fish, shrimp).  Instead they have slow-roasted pork belly (that they roasted all day), fresh seasonal seared fish, dishes with fresh cheeses (they make their own mozzarella), appetizers that are rich and perfect with your just-served wine.  An always-new selection of specials makes me want to eat there every night.  Desserts made in-house and always changing (they even make fresh gelato).  The chef came out to our table for a quick hello after we had finished our meal, we weren't hurried as we finished our drinks (even though they were past-closed), and everyone there is happy.  A quaint location, humble and talented ownership...wow.

I expected bar food.  Man, was I surprised!We sat ourselves and got in our drink orders soon after.  Tonight's choice of refreshment was a pitcher of Yeungling, not my favorite, but with only two other choices, a couple of light beers, Yeungling was the best of the three.  You're have to blame these newfangled joints for getting me into the craft stuff - I've left the mass production stuff alone, especially the lights.Brass Bell has a variety of daily specials, both food and drink.  I couldn't decide on a steak, the Friday special - 10 oz. prime rib, or the surf and turf.  The prime rib was out, so I went for the 10 oz. Delmonico - the today's special; it was $11.95!  I had a salad to start...it was typical and only OK.  The steak came out medium-well, as ordered, and was better than good....it was fantastic!  Had more salt than I'm use too, but I don't do salt any longer, so it was salted as I remembered.  Next time, I'll ask for 'easy salt'.  The baked potato was simply good with butter and sour cream on the side.  It had been a while since I had eaten a steak and baked potato - good eats!Karaoke started around 9.  It started a bit slowly but picked up quickly.  It was unfortunately dominated by men.  My group had 3 ladies in it and they were the only ones who represented. The KJ mixed in a few music videos and a group dance tune or two.  He sang a couple of songs as well.  Not a bad accompaniment to end our meal and the evening.I would go so far as saying, Brass Bell is the equivalent of a great little neighborhood British Pub - nice selection of alcohol, decent eats, and billiards.   For those of you who have never been, this is your notice to put it on your radar. It's a great little neighborhood joint.

<review# 468,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/9/2013,8/9/2013,62,212,2,5,4>Obviously I am a fan, I went on Sunday for the Yelp UYE then again on Monday for lunch. I don't even know where to begin actually because it was a smorgasbord of food, I mean serious FOOD. There were plates being passed left then right, sauces in little cups here and there and my GOD there was no room at our table of 9 to fit anything else but they just kept bringing us more deliciousness every time I cleared a spot. I will say it's super helpful to have someone with you who has came, saw, and ate what Judy's offers. The options seem never ending, which for some can appear overwhelming and for others, down right enjoyable. We had the hot pot going at the table and meats galore (beef, pork, lamb, chicken, fish, fish balls) and vegetables (mushrooms, sweet potatoes - my GOODNESS these were so yummy - and they aren't your normal sweet potatoes you think about, they aren't yams, they are white potatoes with a sweet flavor) and rice noodles, tofu, tofu skin, cabbage, oh my the list goes on and did I mention it is ALL YOU CAN EAT!! But you need to call ahead for the hot pot because of the time involved in the preparation of this fine eating experience.The other dishes circling the table included braised pork belly (so so so gooooood!!!), cold noodles, pork and chicken lettuce wraps (two thumbs up), onion pancakes (HOLY MOLY THESE ARE AWESOME!!!), chicken with chili peppers, and probably many more dishes I tried but can't remember. What I do remember was a great dining experience with new and old Yelp friends that won't be forgotten.For those of you who are skeptical of authentic chinese food, just talk to Judy - she'll walk you through it and is more than happy to provide recommendations.

<review# 470,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/30/2013,8/7/2013,77,61,4,5,2>Such a huge fan of this place. It's got such an unassuming look, outside and inside, that is refreshing considering the look of some of the more pretentious spots in Downtown Norfolk. These people simply know what they excel at and blow you away with it.First off, this is NOT a restaurant in the sense of all other "bars" in Virginia that have an extensive list of culinary offerings that appeal to the deep-seated foodie. They offer just the right mix of light fare and cheeses to accompany a good brew.Second, if a person can't find a good beer, mead, or cider here, I would suggest that they move along to another activity, like watching rocks roll downhill. Their selection is 1) ever-changing, 2) eclectic, and 3) extremely varied. Like saisons? No problem. Into a dark and earthy IPA? Here you go. Want a 18% barleywine that will surprise you? They heard of one.Not a fan of bitter beer taste, but want to ease in with something light? They got something for you.Third, if you get the chance, chit-chat with the family that owns the place. Most down-to-earth people you will run into. I should probably make an effort to remember their names (which I am horrible at), but it doesn't make a difference because they are welcoming to everybody.Fourth, bring your growler. Skipping out on their ridiculous growler prices is a travesty. Don't have a growler? Buy one from here on the cheap and start loading up on a weekly basis. Why is this critical? Because when a good beer gets rotated in, you better snatch it up while it lasts!My only complain about the place is that it's not near my house.

<review# 475,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/21/2013,8/2/2013,38,84,,6,3>Where should I start this review? There is so much to say,so I will start with its location. Tucked ever so discreetly in an upscale neighborhood is a bread and breakfast of an old farm mansion with converted carriage house converted into the B&B's cottage apartments. But back to the main house, there are steps and a wheel chair access to the restaurant. This could have been a root cellar, or once the original kitchen to the house turned restaurant. Hence, the name, The Cellar. We were running a little late, so unfortunately I didn't have the opportunity to check out this place, where the bar area, lounging area or anything was. We were immediately seated to our tables. If your looking for the next trendy hot spot to see or be seen, this place isn't for you. This place is about the food, and the food alone. Yes it is pleasingly aesthetic to the eye but it mostly about the food. The restaurant had a good age mixture, starting in their 20's on up to their 60's, and this place isn't kid friendly, so I didn't see kids in there. We started our meal by sharing a tuna tartare, very nice. They served it with what I assumed was lightly fried wanton wraps. And a creamy type of sauce. Not being a fan of tuna, I really did enjoy this very much. I'm the type of person who will try most anything once, but if I don't care for it, I won't eat it again. My husband ordered the Ahi Tuna and asked the chef to threaten it with heat, they nailed it! Usually restaurants over cook it for his taste, he never says anything but once we leave, he says that he will not be ordering that there again. This time he stated they did it well. I ordered the sea scallops with pork belly. Bacon and sea scallops, yum! They knocked to out of the park. This is a great place, one that my husband and I will be back to.
<review# 476,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/25/2013,8/1/2013,18,133,3,3,5>What an awesome [small] brewery in a very unsuspecting place in Norfolk.There's no way you would 'happen upon' this place since it's tucked away in a corner near the railroad tracks and some industrial buildings, which makes it that much more cool. I've been here a few times over the last year and have had generally good experiences every time:The good: The beer here is awesome quality (not that I'm a beer expert) and all the employees always have a smile on their faces. I appreciate the quaintness of this and think it's awesome that they offer free tours on saturdays. They also seem very community oriented, teaming up with local food trucks and attending many local festivals. The not-so-good: I understand that this brewery is fairly new still and business has exploded, but it does get a little tiring that it's almost impossible to find a seat if you come any time other than right after opening. They have a great little patio, but why no  chairs?? Seems like an easy fix and maybe there's a reason why they can't, but otherwise it just seems like a waste. I think this place would also benefit from a few more food options. I know they have some (pretzels, etc), but if you could get a small meal here to go along with you beer I think it wouldn't be so tough to bring non-beer lovers over to share the experience.Overall: I really respect this place and would give it 4.5/5 if I could. I hope they continue to thrive and [hopefully] have the opportunity to grow in size to overcome their tasting room crowding problem. I really recommend giving this place a look!

<review# 479,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/30/2013,7/29/2013,263,519,5,7,8>Omar's Carriage House is located on Bute street behind some of those fancy new condo's and if you're not looking for it you'll probably miss it. I had a delicious lunch here on Friday with co-workers. I've actually been avoiding the place because I've heard they're slow and don't want to go over my lunch hour by to much if I can avoid it. I'm happy to report that what I heard was wrong.Upon walking in the first thing you're going to notice is the unique decor. I can't quite put my finger on what to call it but I guess the closest thing I can come up with for now is "Eclectic Grandmother Design". All of the walls are brick but have been painted white. There's a stairway to the 2nd floor, a small L shaped bar with a kitchen behind it and then the main dining area in front of that. There's lots of pictures on the wall, lights and color. It's a nice place. For lunch I went with the French Dip Panini which also included Sweet Potato Fries. The roast beef was extra thin and it was accompanied by Havarti cheese on rosemary foccacia. The Au Jus is a Kentucky Bourbon flavor. I thought was a little to much rosemary in it for my taste. My co-worker had the Texas Burger which is a variation of the house Kobe Beef Burger. It includes bacon, cheddar cheese and a green chili ketchup. This is served with sliced roasted Yukon potatoes.Lunch was outstanding, the service was great and I will definitely be visiting again for lunch soon, and probably dinner too.

(Three 4-top tables and one 2-top table. Seriously. That's it.) We met just to enjoy a leisurely breakfast and catch up, but it's hard to have a nice, laid back conversation when there are throngs of people hungrily eyeing you and your table.Additionally, they periodically blast the music. I've read that small establishments sometimes do this to make conversation difficult and encourage a quicker patron turn-around. It worked. After less than 40 minutes, we relocated to a Panera Bread down the street just to be able to sit and enjoy a leisurely cup of coffee without feeling like a bunch of a-holes for wanting to actually sit and have a conversation. The place is tiny, so it's not necessarily their fault, but holy wow.
<review# 484,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/18/2013,7/24/2013,63,174,,7,3>I don't often start a new place I've never visited before with a 5-star review, but I'm really tempted with this new Indian spot (open less than two months, we're told), located at Red Mill Commons a few doors down from Rigoletto bakery.  I'll start with a very high 4, solely because our first visit was for a Sunday bunch, and we didn't have a chance to sample the dinner output from the kitchen.  But we'll be back soon --- of that there is no doubt.The vibe of the restaurant is small and definitely upscale --- muted pastels on the walls and in the upholstered chairs and faux-marble tables, understated/not dramatic modern geometric designs everywhere, unobtrusive indirect lighting, upscale silverware and glassware, linen napkins, fresh flowers on every table, and no salt and pepper shakers anywhere --- a very nicely done decor;  modern and inviting, and overall extremely pleasant.  Our host Bobby also turned out to be our server, and he clearly must be one of the principals of the restaurant --- extremely personable and gracious, and his in-depth knowledge of the menus (both the abbreviated lunch menu, and the much larger one for dinner) and limited but well thought out wine list certainly indicated he must have had a hand in their creations.  We found their Sunday brunch offering to be a three-course prix fixe,  which included choices of appetizers, entrees and desserts, plus a glass of wine, a beer or other non-alcoholic drink --- all priced at an amazing $16.00.  The brunch choices sample all the different types of dishes served at dinner except for their tandoori entrees, and we had wonderful luck with their lentil soup and chaat of the day, followed by a smooth and creamy Paneer Makhni and deliciously tender Lamb Rogan Josh, and finally  beautifully presented and light Gulab Jamun for us both.  Their naan offerings are apparently a work in progress --- a simple naan was served with our meal, and Bobby says they are planning to offer wider choices in the near future ---including, I hope, my favorite fruit-filled Kashmiri variety.  So after almost two hours of leisurely dining and chatting with Bobby, we were pleasantly full after a great meal, and entirely satisfied --- and had spent a grand total of $35.36, before tip.  Wonderful, elegant food, extremely pleasant surroundings, and bright, knowledgeable restaurant personnel --- all this, and priced like Ruby Tuesday.  You bet we'll be back soon --- and you had better visit in a hurry, too, before the place is really discovered, and their food and experience are priced a little closer to what they're really worth.

<review# 486,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/2/2013,7/22/2013,183,190,5,13,4>I think I fell in love last night.I hopped on through the midtown and found myself nestled in the charm of Old Towne Mannino's.  The history of this old building with the exposed brick, high ceilings, and  delicate lights are so warm and inviting.  I really adore the intimate bar tucked in the back with wine crate vestiges adorning the walls.We started out with a bottle of wine and the clams posillipo.  Whatever you do, definitely eat the bread that is soaking in all the juice!  Next, on to a very special addition for the evening...Mannino's totally blew me away with this dish: crostini's stacked with jumbo shrimp and lump crab meat in a truffle broth. When I took my first bite, I almost fell off my barstool...suddenly, you would've thought I was at some sort of revival as my head was bopping around, I was drumming my hand on the table, and I may have even been speaking in tongues.  The truffle wasn't overpowering...just enough to whisk you into Shrangri-la. I almost was that girl holding up the bowl to drink the broth...almost.  Never underestimate the power of the broth!Next, the entrees for the evening. Tonight's special: Rockfish Francese with baby artichokes.  They only used the freshest of fish, which is why the only fish they offer is featured with heir nightly additions.  This was absolutely phenomenal...Mannino's tops any Francese you can get around here.  I am smitten with vodka sauce so in standard Troy fashion, I ordered the penne a la vodka and topped it with sausage and artichokes. As this is a dish I order at every Italian restaurant that offers Vodka sauce, this was beyond my expectations.  I couldn't have been more satisfied with the whole Mannino's experience. I am sold; I am indebted; they have made me a customer for life. Now, if I can just get them to make me that shrimp & crab in truffle broth every time ;-)Update on new faves:1. OMG, the fried oysters--best I have ever had!! Seriously. Almost fell out of my chair again ;-)2. Brookerita martini--delish with an Italian feel, tres Agave, amaretto, triple sec, hint of lemon.  3. Tiramisu--sweet jesus, this was damn good!  Maybe my top 1 or 2 tiramisus.4. Anything with shrimp--his shrimp are the biggest!  Like colossal! And, he knows how to use them ;-)BTW: the she-crab is now the winner of the East Coast She-Crab Classic 3 years and counting...won for both critics choice and people's choice.  They use a marsala base rather than sherry...genius!  Try it and judge for yourself!!!

This place got extra packed extra fast so I would recommend a reservation before you just walk in. Thankfully we came early.The prices are moderate. Probably 18-30 a plate depending on what you get. But you won't be disappointed! Great food! Great service! Loved it!
<review# 489,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/10/2013,7/19/2013,69,206,6,6,4>It's not often a store names itself with the most apt word to describe it's product, but this place nailed it. Ethereal.  Not sure it's a sustainable business model in Hampton, VA, but that basically gives me a reason to go more often. They have amazing service, immediately upon walking in you are greeted and they give you a 1-2 minute spiel on their all organic cupcakes, gluton-free and vegan options offered daily, etc. I'm sure a lot of people really care about that stuff, but I was there for the taste, not the process. And amazingly, they managed to do both right. Listen, folks, they could have made these things from the remnants of burned tires and I would be back. They offer free wi-fi, so I opted to dine in and get some work done between meetings. They have a few tables and a cozy area with a few armchairs and a coffee table. Onto to good stuff. I ordered the salted caramel cupcake and a coffee. The coffee was really great, fresh brewed with quality beans. The cupcake was...ethereal. Seriously. The frosting was light and fluffy with a hint of salt in the sweetness. The cake was a chocolate and it was so moist it was ALMOST mushy -- but it wasn't. I ordered another to 'take home to my husband' - aka eat it at home later before he even sees it. It was the bacon one, yes BACON cupcake. It, too, was amazing. It wasn't a paltry nod to bacon with bits crumbled on top of the frosting, it tasted like brown sugar and bacon throughout the entire cupcake.  I am already planning my next trip to Hampton to hit this place up!

Otherwise, I had a great dining experience at Chow and look forward to many return visits.  JV

<review# 498,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/28/2013,7/10/2013,73,159,2,12,4>I have a love-hate relationship with this place.I love how fresh the produce is and how friendly everyone is. I love the Fruit 66 and other crazy bottled sodas and teas. I love the homemade jams and salsas. But I don't like not being able to interact with the growers/farmers unless they just happen to be there. I'm used to farmer's markets where they haul their produce in and set up their own stall. Five Points has more of a grocery store atmosphere in that it's essentially a large produce section with a few refrigerator/freezer/dry items and cashiers. It's convenient, but it's... cold somehow. I suppose that's why it's "Farm Market" instead of "Farmers' Market". Semantics.So, to the nuts and bolts. There's parking out front along Church St as well as behind the building, with entrances on both sides. I always park out front and enter through the bookstore, glancing to see if any titles pop out at me on my way into the market. There is  a specific area for the organic produce, then whatever seasonal "local" items are available. It's hit-or-miss with the origin labeling, but if you find Bev Sell, she can answer all your questions. Just look for her at the desk behind the register on the east wall or chatting up a friend in the cafe.There is a seafood vendor, cases of pastured beef, local eggs, dairy from Oberweiss, Twin Oaks' "More Than Tofu", some faux meat items from time to time, the Get Fresh Cafe, Sabrosa foods (think bell-pepper-based salsas), and a bakery whose name escapes me at the moment (Buttercream & Sprinkles perhaps). On Saturdays, a woman is there selling her homemade rolls that are absolutely fantastic.If you want to use your credit card, I believe it's a $10 minimum. Not difficult to meet if you grab some sodas.
<review# 499,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/4/2013,7/9/2013,40,107,,3,3>This place has everything. Bubble tea, yogurt, fixin's... well, ok, that's not everything, but it's still a darn good place to get a cool treat. I judge a bubble tea shop by how their taro flavor tastes... and this hits the spot. The  tapioca pearls are chewy without being gummy, have a hint of a sweet flavor without being flavorless (which is the worst IMO) and they give you just the right amount, as not to overpower the beverage. Also, they have a nice variety of frozen yogurt flavors and mix-ins. The fruit in the mix-in station is fresh, too - no soggy strawberries or decrepit soggy blueberries here! All in all, this is a great addition to MacArthur center - I just wish they'd open up a freestanding location so I wouldn't have to crawl through the teenager infested mall to get to it.

<review# 505,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/2/2013,7/3/2013,9,60,,6,2>Girlfriend and I had planned to try the new Bangladeshi restaurant around the corner from our house Monday night after work, but we were thwarted: they close at 6!  As alternative, she suggested Thai food.  I'd driven past Sawasdee last weekend and decided to bring us there.On a wet Monday night, the place... was empty.  We got there about 8:30 and were the only people there.  That did make for a nice, intimate date for us, but I hope the place does better business sometimes.  The interior's beautiful - they've put a lot of effort into the decor - our waitress was attentive and nice, and the food was excellent.  They've got a decent menu, not too long, but organized a little differently than other Thai restaurants I've been to.  There's the expected sections, but there's also a section devoted to duck.  And they had 5 or 6 curry options instead of just the usual 3 or 4.  But there's duck.  Duck!  I totally got the duck.After orders of a wonton soup (Katie's idea, I'd normally have gotten the tom yum or tom kha) and complementary salads (with a very nice ginger dressing), our entrees came.  Katie had ordered woon sen, which was a noodle dish.  It was described on the menu as having "mixed vegetables", which turned out to include carrots and baby corn (in addition to some other things, including zucchini).  She eschews both those vegetables, but after setting them aside she said she enjoyed the rest of the meal.  And she had enough for leftovers that were no longer in the fridge after Tuesday.  Personally, I thought the bit I tried wasn't all that flavorful, but then my Thai noodle dish of choice is drunken noodles.Anyway, who cares about noodles?  There's a whole duck section on the menu!  Not a big section, mind you, but enough that I had to choose between ginger duck and basil duck.  I went with the basil duck.  It was chunks of lightly breaded & fried quackbird stir-fried with vegetables, big chunks of Thai basil, and chili paste.  I'd probably ask for it spicier next time (if I can convince myself again not to get the green curry... I don't remember if there was duck curry), but it was delicious nonetheless!I loved it.  And I really hope they stick around.

<review# 508,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/24/2013,6/30/2013,88,68,3,5,3>This is the restaurant I chose to celebrate 2 years of being together with my girlfriend and Zoe's did not disappoint!Growing up and eating food on a daily basis you're bound to be exposed to iconic culinary treats that just naturally are pleasing to eat such as Creme Brûlée or Bacon wrapped Scallops. Zoe's in Virginia Beach doesn't offer dishes with such straight forward flavor combinations yet still gives diners adventurous reinterpretations of the classics.  Case in point, the Foie Gras Brûlée and Lob POPS appetizers.  I'll admit it, I'm as much as a foodie as can be for what Hampton Roads restaurants have to offer and these were 2 dishes of 4 that I tried in a 4 course tasting menu. I mean both of these dishes just dare you to try them if you're of an open mind just by reading the descriptions. The Foie Gras Brûlée was accompanied by delicious Morel mushrooms, Saba (a syrup made from freshly squeezed grape juice), and chives. This starter was great because you got the texture of a perfectly cooked Creme Brûlée complete with spoon crackable sugar shell overtop but with the taste of Foie Gras that wasn't overly heavy but still carried the richness in flavor. It went well with the fried wonton chips they served along side of it which were the perfect accompaniment to contrast the silkiness of the brûlée.The next course I had was actually the main course which surprised me as I was expecting another app. I decided on the Balsamic Roasted Scallops served with Pancetta, Mark's 24 Hour Tomatoes, Pecorino, Pesto Aioli, Focaccia, and Balsamic Reduction. The tasting portion gives the diner 2 scallops about U-10 size which are a decent size (enough to use a knife AND fork). The pancetta was spread out in crispy bits, and the 24 hour tomatoes reminded me of the flavor of sun-dried tomatoes. Overall, a nice dish.  The third dish was the Lob POPS. Pops in caps on the menu because the use of... POP ROCKS! For the first time in my life I tried a dish in which Pop Rocks were used in a savory application and it did not disappoint.  The tasting portion consists of 2 bacon wrapped pieces of lobster meat which are tempura fried and served with a Blackberry reduction and garnished with Cherry Pop Rocks. That childhood memory of the sound of pop rocks immediately rushed back to me as the waiter laid the plate in front of me. I'd say it took me about a minute or two to finish the plate.  The blackberry reduction was a nice addition to the dish while the pop rocks served more of an auditory sensory experience and delivered less on taste.Last but not least was dessert in which I chose the Trio of Cannoli (which is actually a duo if you choose the tasting menu). I got the ones filled with Mascarpone and Chocolate Curls. They were small but the filling was light and airy like a mousse which was very delicious and not at all heavy like some traditional cannolis I've had in the past. A great way to end the meal... almost!  At the very end as we were settling the bill the waiter brought out various homemade jellies, a vanilla marshmallow, and macadamia nut cookie bite for us to enjoy on the house. If you're looking for a nice fine dining restaurant where you can either dress up or come in business casual and enjoy some great food using great ingredients with a mix of imagination then this is a place you need to try. Zoe's does well in departing from the same 'ol same 'ol and does so not only in having great dishes but great service as well.You pay for what you get and it's only pricey if you don't find you got enough value in the overall experience; fine dining or otherwise ;)

<review# 514,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/31/2013,6/24/2013,119,199,1,7,5>Captain Groovy's is probably my favorite restaurant in the area...which makes it really tough to review.  You see, if I rave on and on about how incredible the Sunday Brunch menu is (Sausage and Bacon Fritata is to DIE for), then there is a huge risk that more and more people will start showing up, lessening the chances of me being able to walk right in and sit right down.But The Cap't deserves the review it earned, so here it is.  The short version:  Go here.  Now.  Drop what you are doing and get to Groovy's.  Just don't park in the hotel parking lot next door or they will tow your car.If you are a human being and like food, you will find something that will change your life on the menu.  I'm serious, the food is that good.  And a variety that will have you scanning for new items each visit.  I've been here countless times and have never ordered the same thing twice.The burger menu is interesting, including something called the Hangover Burger.  My advice would be to go out and get as drunk as you can tonight, then get someone to drive you to Groovy's tomorrow and try this out.  Let us know if it cures the hangover, I would suspect that the combination of egg and hamburger would do the trick.The vibe here is 100% locals joint.  You could dress up if you wanted to, but the usual is shorts, t-shirts, and flip flops.  When we feel the urge to dress up, the t-shirt becomes a polo shirt..Several of the reviews have mentioned the service at the place.  Yea, it can be a bit all over the place, I've had to wait a few times as well (after sitting down)...but...I find it a great break from the chain places that feel like they have to 'check in' on you ever 3 minutes to see if your digestive tract is still operational.  Get my order, bring my food, and leave me alone is, quite often, the recipe for great service...and under that definition, Cap't Groovy almost ALWAYS hits the mark!  If you are in a huge hurry and trying to squeeze in a quick business lunch, though, you should avoid this place for many many reasons.If you are looking for authentic local vibe with a menu that never ends, come to Groovy's.  Friday night they always have some cool Fish Fry special going on as well.
<review# 515,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/3/2013,6/23/2013,118,112,5,3,3>Being in VA for 3 years now, I think I'm finally getting the whole East Coast thing. One of them being seafood & OYSTERS!!Never would I have thought that I would eat a raw oyster and love it, let alone crave it.My man piece talked me into trying them, said that A.W Shucks had a great variety. Never knew there were so many different kinds and tastes of oysters. Our server told us pretty much everything that we needed to know about the oysters, where it came from and what kind of flavor it held. I loved trying the different kinds of oysters. They were very fresh and delicious. I eat mine with a saltine and cocktail sauce, NO slurping... baby steps.. We've been back many times and plan on keep coming back.We have also tried other things on their menu, and those did not disappoint.Can't say I'm a fan of the restaurants layout and lighting but I'll deal.
<review# 516,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/22/2013,6/22/2013,66,117,11,14,7>I'm not a kid anymore.  I'm not as flexible as I was once, my body moves a little slower than I remember and don't get me started on my cardio.  Years of smoking, drinking, fatty foods, big gulps, and other things that I shouldn't admit to have taken their toll on me.  I'm not saying that I'm completely out of shape;  I'm just not the nimble little ninja that I used to be.  But that didn't stop me from jumping around like a maniac in this place.I never had a trampoline while growing up.  But I would imagine that a single backyard trampoline would suck compared to the awesomeness of what Rebounderz has to offer.  There are a few rules you have to abide by, of course.  but just remember that they are in place to keep you from snapping your neck.  Be brutally honest with what your abilities are and you should be fine.  Don't go crazy parkour-style here unless you're looking for a leg injury.The best deal is on Thursdays where you can bounce for an hour for $8.  And trust me, an hour is a lot of time to spend on a trampoline.  After about 15 minutes of bouncing, throwing myself against the angled walls, and making failed attempts at landing a forward somersault I was pretty much wiped.  They do have a small snack bar for a quick pick me up if you need it (although drinking a blue slushie before jumping on a trampoline sounds like a horrible idea).  And if you want to avoid a crowd I recommend going later in the evening around 8.  It's a ridiculously fun time when there are only a few people there and you get full rein of the room.It's a great place for kids of course, but it's also a great place for adults too.

<review# 518,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/31/2013,6/20/2013,163,183,4,8,2>Dim Sum Sundays! I love Jade Villa! A bit sad that I don't frequent this place more often. First, it's a hole in a wall place, so please don't expect anything grand, because you won't get that here. Secondly, it gets ridiculously busy on Dim Sum Sundays! So if you can, send a member of your party ahead of time to secure your groups table. Lastly, contrary to popular beliefs, they do serve specialty Cantonese dishes aside from the typical Americanized Chinese food.Do arrive with an empty stomach. Do order Green Tea with your dim sum. Do ask for a pitcher of water for the table. Do park at the opposite end of the shopping center so you can get your "workout" before and after your glorious meal. Don't be rude. Don't expect any space, it gets packed. Don't fret if you don't know what to order, they can and will explain things to you if you ask. They also have menus to look at.  Don't believe any reviews, experience the food and the place for yourself!

<review# 520,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/27/2013,6/18/2013,122,469,1,7,4>On a search for glass noodles, I had my husband stop by for take out one afternoon in VB. When I called, the owner who answered was so nice and took the time to explain where they were located and what would be good dishes that would travel well since we were out in Suffolk. I ordered the Jap Chae (for all my glass noodle needs), Pork bulgogi, and steamed dumplings. I had expressed interest in the bibimbap but she didnt think it would stay crisp on the drive but what she did do is throw in extra sauces, garnishes, and rice that typically come with that so we'd still be able to sample everything. I thought that was so hospitable and shows they really value excellent customer service. Everything was phenomenal! My husband ate his entire takeout box of pork bulgogi in one freaking sitting. We took lettuce and wrapped our entrees with it for makeshift lettuce wraps and added the extra red chilli sauce and kimchi and garnishes she provided and devoured our food. Oh and the steamed dumplings were awesome, nothing like the mush you order at standard chinese takeout places. You could tell these were made with love.I don't think I've ever had proper Korean food before but this has really given me that push to come out and try another meal here at the restaurant and experience the real thing in person. Outstanding service and food, I look forward to returning to give it that 5th star.
<review# 521,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/9/2013,6/17/2013,21,28,,5,4>This place is never disappointing.  I can't even count the number of times I've been here and I am pleased 100% of the time.  The pita is soft, warm, and delicious, the veggies are fresh, and the meat is mouth watering.  Most of the time I stick with the lamb and beef gyro, but I sometimes order the chicken gyro for a change.  It has a nice grilled flavor and has never been dried out.  Also, the lentil soup was a very pleasant surprise.I don't claim to be a gyro expert, but this is without a doubt the best I've ever had.
<review# 522,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/6/2013,6/16/2013,27,56,6,2,2>I've probably driven by this place a million times and chuckled while reading the sign, Donkey Dawgs, seriously!? I've never met anyone who went inside so I had to try it when I finally got a decent lunch break on a Friday. When I walked into this place I felt like I was transported to a diner out in the dusty plains of Arizona. The decor of the establishment has taxidermy from the moment you enter and also has an extremely creepy life sized American Indian statue/doll sitting on the table...weird yes, but I love weird! When I stepped up to the lunch counter I was promptly greeted and so I asked for a to go menu. I ordered up the cheeseburger w/ bacon, fried egg and grilled onions (I don't remember the title of the sandwich). Although my experience and wait here was short, I did manage to catch up on some farm gossip that I could eavesdrop in on from a couple of farmers right next to me, juicy stuff! All in all, I like Donkey Dawgs. The burger was pretty awesome but I wish I would have ordered the hot dog that the establishment is named after (maybe next time). If you pass by, stop in, you won't forget the place.

<review# 524,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/11/2013,6/14/2013,121,170,7,14,7>I made my first of three or four pilgrimages of the year to Moseberth this past Saturday.  I don't know why I had this chicken on my mind, but I did for some reason.  I guess I wanted good chicken without the flavor overload.It was the usual wait - about 12 minutes.  That means you are getting something good, something fresh, and not something sitting under tanning lamps for hours.I ordered the Regular Dinner. It comes with a breast, a wing, a thigh, and a drumstick,  two small sides of Potato Salad and Cole Slaw, an order of fries, and a few hush puppies to round out the order.  The chicken at Moseberth is amazing, in my opinion.  It's crispy on the outside and moist on the inside.  This chicken has much less seasoning than most others.  It doesn't seem to be marinated, one, and the dredge has just the right amount of simple seasonings -mostly just salt and pepper.  In other words, I don't feel that I need to drink a gallon of water both during and after my finger-likingness.The fries are always good and hot. The hush puppies are deadly, but once in a while I resist replacing them with the rolls. This was one of those days. They were hot and just G-O-O-D!The only negative are those sides.  They come from what seems to be 128oz. milk cartons...Yes, premanufactured.  I know they will never be as good as the homemade stuff.  Reese's make decent potato salad, but I'm not fond of their slaw.  I'd prefer they both be made from scratch, honestly. As long as the chicken shines, I can forgive this.The hot sauce at Moseberth is amazing.  I'm still trying to figure out if it's premanufactured or 'doctored' up.  It's not really spicy, but has a vinegary kick second to none.  It's the kind of stuff you find on Carolina-style BBQ, off-red with a strong vinegary nose, but has little heat and zero pepper flakes.  It's good to the last drop.I watched box after box of chicken, BBQ combos, livers, and gizzards make their way out the front door.  I love the chicken here, but I found myself wanting something different as well.  Maybe next time, I'll find the nerve to try something new here.This is one of Triple D's local finds where I agree with yo' boy, Guy.  I haven't had the same good luck with most of his local finds, but this one is a keeper.

<review# 526,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/1/2013,6/12/2013,31,234,1,9,4>The consistent theme of all the reviews seems to be that service here is outstanding. I am very pleased to report the same. Richard was our waiter and he went above and beyond. Personable, helpful, spot on with drinks and food. A waiter I would actually request should we return. Besides, he complimented my ridiculous shoes. No quicker way to my good graces.And yes, the interior was lovely.  Soft lighting, wood detail and the painted tin ceiling made it feel earthy. The fake oasis of plastic trees should be thrown out with a quickness. The huge Italian themed posters were not my taste, but worked well enough.Now onto the meal. I enjoyed the house martini. We were given a single piece of fresh bread each with a garlic butter. The appetizer was a duck spring roll with a peanut dipping sauce. I had a caesar salad with my seven ounce filet topped with gorgonzola butter and a side of garlic mashed potatoes. The boy had the special with rock fish, roasted sweet potatoes, and sauteed vegetables. Dessert was a apple cinnamon cheesecake. This came out to about a hundred dollars, which seemed reasonable to me.The specialty drink was very strong. So props to the bartender,  I just nursed that all night. The bread was baked fresh and came out warm, but wasn't particularly noteworthy. The butter on the other hand did not fear the garlic so I was a huge fan of. The spring roll was good. Fried crisp, filled with duck, and the sauce was a great compliment. But I wouldn't order it a second time. The caesar was lightly coated with dressing so all the lettuce was crisp. There were large shavings of parmesan all over which I love, but it lacked a touch in flavor overall. The filet was cooked a beautiful medium rare, maybe just the slightest bit over. I thoroughly enjoyed the goranzola butter, but maybe should have saved that for a different cut. A good filet should stand on its own as a star. The steak was buttery and one of the best I've had. Yet, I felt without the butter lacked in seasoning. The garlic mash was a sad cry from the garlic butter earlier in the night. I had none of that flavor. A creamy, velvety side as it was this was clearly a dish that needed seasoning. Jeff ended up adding salt and pepper, which I think you shouldn't ever need to do if something is prepared correctly. The rock fish was poached, which Jeff loved; light and satiny. Here we disagreed slightly as I prefer a little more texture. The roasted sweet potatoes and the sauteed vegetables were done very well. Whatever fault we may have found during the meal, Jeff easily forgave them all when we tried the cheesecake. I know my review on the food is very nitpicky. I actually enjoyed the meal as a whole quite a bit, and between the service and the ambiance they earned all four stars. I just feel like you can be more open about shortcomings with fine dining. They are striving for perfection. So the criticism is meant to help them get there. I would go back again.

<review# 528,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/27/2013,6/10/2013,104,345,5,22,9>We waited a couple of weeks before coming to Braise just to give the staff some time to work out the kinks that every new place has when first opened. For those not in the know, Braise is Bobby Huber's new restaurant located in the space that was once Forbidden City.  Somewhat confusingly, Forbidden City is reopening shortly in the same strip mall so don't let the signage fool you.  Just focus on the Braise sign and you will be fine.Anyway, we met a group of friends and ended up as a party of eight.  They easily accommodated us as there is a large dining room in the back of the space.  In fact, the dining room is enormous, which is quite deceiving when you first walk into the separate bar area.An initial disappointment was actually with the bar.  There is no cocktail menu and the list of wines available by the glass is meager.  Any restaurant with this much reputation behind it needs a cocktail program not only for the customers who like to start meals with a cocktail (That would be me!) but it also helps the bottom line.  Having customized cocktails that you can charge higher prices for helps to supplement the razor thin margins on food.  If nobody on staff has cocktail talent then hire somebody who does.The same goes for wine.  I understand that they really want to sell wine by the bottle but limiting the by the glass selection isn't the way to do it.  Not everybody is going to drink an entire bottle of wine with dinner.  I would have to carry my wife to the car if she drank a bottle by herself.The menu is studded with dishes that Bobby Huber has been well known for at his previous restaurants.  Many are absolute flashes of genius but others can be hit or miss as we discovered.  This night turned out to be one of the few times I chose better that my wife did.For starters, I did his famous oyster stew and it deserves every accolade it gets.  Plenty of fat, plump oysters, none of which were overcooked.  It is decadent with bacon, cream, corn and a good dollop of mashed potatoes mounded on the middle.  A nice crostini on the side would have been perfect but that is my own preference.  My wife chose the softshell and "lobstah" app.  While the softshells were passable, the lobster portion left her wanting.  There were only a few pieces of lobster and none bigger than the nail on your pinky finger.  Flavor was wanting as well.For main courses, she choose the rockfish over orzo mac and cheese with crab butter.  The fish was excellent but her mac and cheese was actually cold to the touch.  The execution fell just a bit short but the concept of the dish is sound.  The kitchen might still have a kink or two to overcome afterall.  We discovered that with the dessert as well.  Her rhubarb crumble was cold and the topping wasn't crumbly at all.  Keep tweaking back there, kitchen folks.But the star of the night was Bobby's lamb shank with blue cheese polenta.  This dish is a grand slam home run in the bottom of the ninth to win game seven of the world series.  Holy arteriosclerosis was this thing a dish to behold.  The lamb was fall off the bone tender and lacquered with an incredible sauce that I cannot even begin to describe.  The blue cheese polenta was the perfect foil.  Sharp on the palate and smooth on the tongue at the same time. I barely managed to keep using my fork and knife as I fought the urge to pick that shank up and gnaw away on it.  I came very close to throwing etiquette out the window.  It was the best lamb shank I have ever had in my life.The shank earned a star all by itself. The rest of our experience was a three star kind of night.  There is plenty of potential here.  They just need a little more fine tuning.

<review# 532,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/5/2013,6/6/2013,74,230,3,9,5>I stopped by Cafe M this morning to give breakfast a try.  And, overall I can safely say that I will be back.  When I walked in, I was greeted by Missy, the owner, and I placed my order.  I got the sausage and gravy bisuit with egg and a banana streusel muffin.  The muffin was a nice start to the meal, moist and delicious.  It's made fresh every day and you could tell it was made recently.  Very good.  The biscuit with gravy and sausage was good but not great for me.  The biscuit itself was really good, again made in house and had great flavor.  The sausage, which is also made there, lacked whatever seasonings you need to make it sausage.  It was good but not quite "sausagey" enough.  The gravy needed more salt, in my opinion, and I told her that when she asked for my opinion.  The sandwich itself was only OK for me personally.  The best thing I ate was the pumpkin donut holes.  She had some ready as I was finishing up and I had the chance to try them warm and right out of the oven.  Dear heavens those were good.  I would go back for those alone.  Again, they are made in house and from what I can gather they go quickly.  If you want to try them, get there early.  So, to sum up my overall impressions, I am a fan.  It wasn't a perfect meal but there was enough there that was good to make me want to go back.  The pastries were definitely the stars of the morning and I will be back for those at a minimum.  Missy said they have meatball subs (which my wife loves) on Thursday lunch and tacos on Tuesday so we will probably hit it for lunch soon too!  This is a new business that is locally owned and trying to build itself up.  Give it a try and see what you think!

<review# 534,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/8/2013,6/4/2013,54,55,,6,3>The taco is the meter stick I use to judge the quality of a taqueria.  The first time I came to El Rey, the tacos didn't have enough meat and the tortillas were thin and dry as a result.  I was disappointed and resorted to ordering other items, some of which are better than others.  (Pupusas and burritos here are very good.)I gave the tacos another shot recently and was blown away.  The carnitas taco I had was easily the best Mexican food item I've ever eaten in Hampton Roads.  Served in the traditional style with a homemade corn tortilla hot off the press and succulent, crispy chunks of pork, diced onion and cilantro, I can say with confidence that this taco stands up to any version I've had on the west coast where I'm from.Check out the picture.
<review# 535,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/30/2013,6/3/2013,23,129,,5,3>I went here for dinner on a Tuesday night with a friend. I had always wanted to try this restaurant, because it is conveniently located on Colley Avenue near the Naro theater. The restaurant has outdoor seating and a stand that holds their menu and daily specials. We walked in and was greeted with a pleasant hostess who ended up being our waitress. The place gives off a chic, modern yet retro, romantic vibe. The phone at the hostess station is a cool old school red one that you can picture Marilyn Monroe women using while smoking a cigarette. There is a bar in the back as well as an adjoining room with lounge sofas. My friend and I opted to share the fried oyster appetizer ($11) and the pan roasted pork chop entree ($22). The fried oysters were delectably prepared on a bed of shredded lettuce and drizzled with a citrus remoulade. Our waitress suggested we prepare the pork chop medium; perfect choice. The pork chop was succulent, moist and bursting with flavor. I was surprised at how well they cooked it. Alongside it was a skillet of macaroni and cheese, which ended up being a larger portion than I had expected it to be. The portion could have sated a small child. The additional pairing of roasted tinged brussel sprouts made it a great meal. They offer 50% off select wine bottles on Tuesdays, and they will recork it for you to bring back home for free. I think they also have a happy hour from 3-6pm too.I was afraid that I would be underwhelmed but this place, but my experience here was exceptional. I would definitely recommend this place for a dinner date or for a semi upscale dining experience. The food was deliciously prepared, and our waitress was one of the nicest ones I've experienced in a long time. I would recommend this place if you ever plan on catching a movie in the Ghent/downtown area. Make sure to bring a partner in crime with you though; you may feel a bit out of place eating here by yourself for dinner.
<review# 536,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/27/2013,6/2/2013,62,212,2,6,3>I rarely give 5 stars unless the place knocks my socks off...and let me tell you - I LOST mine at this place! It's a small little restaurant located near a somewhat questionable area of Norfolk (Park Place...eeek)...but maybe that area is getting an awakening...thanks to the Dirty Buffalo!The smell when you walk in is nothing but chicken wings, and that's ok! It's not a greasy smell like other wing places, it's a nice saucy chicken smell that ignites your nose and makes your stomach grumble and scream FEED ME MORE!!I ordered the Dirty Chick which consists of two meaty chicken tenders tossed in your choice of sauce (I opted for the sweet bbq at the recommendation of the girl taking our order) on top of home fries smothered in mac-n-cheese. Anything that is SMOTHERED in anything must be good, right?? WRONG - it's delicious! The mac-n-cheese is outstanding. I could have ate an entire pan of this stuff, well not an entire pan but I sure would try! The home fries were cooked perfectly - crispy with a light golden color. The chicken was tossed in the sweet bbq with the perfect amount of sauce and didn't make my chicken soggy at all. I will be back for this again!! My boyfriend ordred the hot wings and they were HOT. I usually order mild wings, but he made me try these and my lips were on FIRE. He also had an order of the poor man's wings - fries tossed in your choice of sauce. His were tossed in spicy bbq. The spicy bbq was on point!I will be back, oh yes, I will be back!!
<review# 537,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,3/27/2013,5/30/2013,159,120,,9,1>Today was my first visit to Stove, The Restaurant.  First impression:  The quaint neighborhood location was def off the beaten path.  But, I must admit that the location does set it apart from other eateries...especially those in Norfolk/VB.  It's a rather small location, offering ample street-side parking, even if a short walk is required.I sampled one of the cheese platters, and was impressed by the local honey featured.  I also had the green salad, which features a super-tangy mustard oil dressing, that's a win in my book.  Finally, I had the shrimp and grits, Étouffée, and scallops.  Now were the dishes the best(most fattening) ever??  No.  But, the key to these dishes, is the use of ripe veggies/tomatoes, to provide great depth and taste, without the heavy butter, ect. we southerners are accustomed to...Bottom line, very filling, good, and light.  A winning combination for a "Neo Southern" joint.  I do suggest researching this eatery...and giving it a try...Solid 3.5 stars (may be worth 4 stars)...and I honestly would recommend a visit...

<review# 541,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/2/2013,5/26/2013,17,153,1,4,2>Cool place.  My daughter goes after school on occasion and had informed me about the House Cup deal: $2 (includes tax) gets you a mug of coffee, plus a refill.  Pretty good deal for a budget-conscious consumer like myself (read: "cheap bastard").  Tasty, non-fancy, good stuff regular coffee.  There are several tables inside and out. We settled in at a small table in the old sleeping porch area.  Beautiful day with the windows open.  Because the building used to be a house, it is divided up into rooms,  Not fully enclosed, mind you, separate spaces, but still relatively open.  It makes it easy to separate yourself a bit if you like, and cozy into your little area.  They have some games out on the porch as well if you are so inclined.  I will definitely return.  I'm having a hard time understanding how anyone could walk into Starbucks with this place right across the street.  So much more character, and local.
<review# 542,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/4/2013,5/25/2013,13,19,,3,2>One of the first things you'll notice about El Taco Loco is that it is packed...all the time. This place is always hopping whenever we go. Lunch or dinner, full. I think that says something about a place.El Taco Loco has a large menu with everything from appetizers to "house" specials. The service is good, everyone is friendly and sometimes give you a little ribbing in good fun. I also like being called "amigo", yeah I know, it's gimmicky and cheesy, but it adds to the atmosphere and feel of the place. There is plenty of seating and one of my only complaints would be climate control. During the winter it gets very hot in there; if you're wearing a sweater you'll be burning up in no time.The food is good and comes out at a decent pace. Of course you get your chips, salso and white sauce. I love the white sauce, I can eat that stuff all day long. This is probably true for most Tex-Mex places I go to though. You can get table guacamole, made to order in a huge wooden bowl that looks like a pipe. So if you see that put at a table expect to see someone pick it up and act like they're smoking it. It'll get a chuckle the first few times.The shrimp tacos are good and my go-to is the slow braised Carnitas. You get huge chunks of pork that have been cooking for long time. It also comes with a grilled Spring onion (that sounds fancier than green onion -G) and jalepeno. Portion out the bites for a good chew.The bar is fully loaded so you can order whatever you want barstool or at the table. Big margaritas and a few of the typical "Mexican" beers.If you like Mexican-American food, check it out. It's good.

My husband had teriyaki chicken and he said while it was good, it wasn't as hot (temperature wise) that he's used to but he generally eats his food steaming hot. Which is why I'm not letting it factor into my review. He likes his mouth to be on fire and that's not normal. lolThe experience just gets better as we go. The wait staff was extremely attentive but not hovering. We were there for 2 hours and as we enjoy our meal more and more folks come in. Never once were we pressured to give up our table nor did they rush us out. The emptiness? The restaurant only had our recently vacated table open plus one more. Don't let the fact that it's in a strip mall scare you away. You'll definitely be missing out on something if you do.Oh, try the dream roll for dessert. You won't be sorry!

<review# 547,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/29/2013,5/20/2013,18,133,,4,2>I'd been wanting to try the lunch buffet at Nawab for a while after the rave reviews and finally got a chance to go! Overall, I had a great time but think some of the reviews might be a little exaggerated.I came on a sunday around 1pm and after getting to the place (which doesn't have the most inviting location) there were only a couple other tables taken. No one really greeted us when we got in so we wandered to a table until someone finally saw us and seated us. The buffet itself isn't as big as I was expecting, but the food overall tasted great! They have a salad section with rice pudding and several dishes with curry and chicken. I'm not an expert on Indian food so I can't be more specific than that (my cultural ignorance). They did have naan, which would probably be enough to make me happy, but unfortunately they kept running out for some reason. One disappointment is that they didn't have samosas, which I thought was expected of Indian buffets (guess not!).The inside of the restaurant was updated and nice (unlike the outside) and once we were seated, our water glasses were almost always full. One note about the lunch buffet- It says it goes until 2 (at least on Sundays) but they started running out of dishes at 1:30 and packed up at 1:45, so don't push your luck if you're trying to catch the tail end of it!Bottom line: Not the biggest indian buffet, but the food tasted good and the atmosphere was nice too. For the price ($9-10) I thought it was a great deal and plan on coming back! They should be more truthful to their own set buffet times, but maybe that's only a problem when it's not as crowded.
