<review# 550,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/15/2013,5/17/2013,63,174,5,5,3>The older I get, the more I try to stay out of places like Rigoletto Bakery.  For every piece of tiramisu, it's another hour at the gym.  For every eclair or cannoli, it's forty-five more minutes.  For every piece of fresh, homemade biscotti, add twenty more minutes on the treadmill.   You get the general idea --- this place is just a fabulous bakery, and I have absolutely no control.I think it's been almost four years ago that Gilda Di Dominico, a very active and pleasant lady who's originally from Naples, opened Rigoletto in VB's Red Mill Commons shopping center.  She was almost immediately featured on Triple D, and hasn't had time to take a breath since then.  Rigoletto's main emphasis is on baked goods, and I have yet to find a local spot that does a better job with the rich, custard or mascarpone-filled pastries that so excite me when we travel to New York City's Little Italy or Brooklyn.  Additionally, there's a huge supply of wonderful cookies, cakes, glazed fresh fruit pies and fresh breads offered; and the menu has recently been expanded to include a selection of homemade soups, salads, and fresh paninis, assembled with their own handmade Foccacia bread.  I've not sampled their food items, but the plates coming from the kitchen when I'm there for bakery items all look very inviting.Rigoletto's prices are a little above other fresh bakeries in the area, but I think, on a dollar-per-pound basis, and certainly on the basis of quality and just downright yummyness, Rigoletto is superior to the other two in this area that I still enjoy visiting.  And there is nowhere --- I'll say it again, nowhere --- within Tidewater that makes a fresher, more creamy, more delicious cannoli or eclair.

<review# 554,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/6/2013,5/13/2013,83,478,3,6,2>OK - I'm not going to lie.  I was in a bad mood when I arrived because it's off a few of the small streets in downtown Norfolk, which I typically avoid like the plague, but I was following my gal from Aveda here, Katie.  So when I saw she was still cutting someone's wet hair when I showed up on time I knew I'd be in for a wait... so I was grumpy.... Anthony and Co. is located in a small shopping strip/mall area but they do seem to have plenty of parking (a big plus for me as I HATE street parking) and is nestled in between plenty of little specialty shops and restaurants in downtown Norfolk, so if you are already in the area for a haircut you could plan to shop and eat and spend some time after or before... The space itself isn't really large but it was big enough.  There were about 6-7 stations for the stylists with 3 shampoo sinks and 3 of those little chairs where the little ladies with curlers sit in - no idea what they're called.  The inside reminds me of an art deco loft or something with wood beams and bricks.  It's not really to my contemporary tastes but it was by no means unattractive or run down.  The entryway is very nice and clean with the products displayed very nicely and a large welcoming front desk.  They also seem to be very supportive of local artists as there was artwork for sale hanging up all throughout the shop and Katie invited me to another artist's debut next week.Even though we started a little late  Katie was quickly forgiven.  I did wait for about 25 minutes but I realize people sometimes run over or early - it is what it is.  We did our usual consult about what I wanted done, she offered me a drink (water, tea, soda), and since I had checked in via Yelp I got a free leave-in oil treatment offer with my check-in so that was nice. Katie has been cutting my hair for about 3 years now, since she started at the Aveda salon in Virginia Beach so it was a no brainer to follow her here.  I trust her, I like her, she's always done an excellent job, and she knows my style.  Also, as I mentioned in my other review of her at the previous location - the time flies while sitting in her chair because she's very very friendly and chatty and it makes the time fly.  I used to dread going to get a haircut but, because I know she's not going to cut off 4 inches more than I want, I look forward to going and getting my hair done and having girl talk for a while.I got a partial highlight in blonde but we lightened it up a little more for summer, and she explained that Anthony and Co is a little more expensive because they use the new hair dye that doesn't have ammonia in it which dries your hair out less - and I am all for that!  So I got my color, leave-in oil, and cut in the span of about 2 hours where we got all caught up from my last appointment (about 4 months ago) and chatted about everything from Real Housewives to auto immune disorders to bad traffic in the area.  I love coming to Katie because, while she is EXCELLENT at what she does, she is very easy to talk to and remembers the little details about what's going on which is impressive when it's 4 months between seeing each other and she has tons of other people she sees.  Anthony and Co. provided me upon leaving with a nice little first-timer gift bag that had some color-treated hair samples of little shampoo and conditioner bottles that are probably enough for about a week of use and a coupon for $10 off my next purchase.  Which was a cute way to treat a first timer.My partial color and cut ran me about $100.  Which is about standard for that sort of thing with a good stylist and can actually cost much more.  You cannot leave a tip on your credit card or debit which stinks, I never have cash, but since it's so centrally located I walked the two blocks to the ATM and got some money to leave a nice tip.  So bring cash if you're a tipper!All in all - I had a good experience and my hair looks, as always, fabulous!  I'll be back.

I think the cooks must be perfectionists, I don't put as much work into Christmas dinner as these guys do into every sandwich.  Everything is fresh and delicious, from the fries to the salads -- oh god, the salads.  They have great salads, I've tried 4 of them and every time I think I say 'this is my new favorite'.  When you get a salad with chicken, they give you a whole grilled chicken breast, same thing with the salmon and the steak. They do not skimp on anything. My favorite sandwiches are the Mexi-Cali chicken and the Figgy Piggy - these sandwiches could not be any more different or awesome. The Mexi Cali is an entire chicken breast with bacon, roasted tomatoes and pepperjack on chewy ciabatta -- yep its as good as it sounds. The Figgy Piggy is roast pork with a sweet fig glaze and gouda cheese. The staff is friendly and the prices are reasonable for the amount and quality of food you get. Seriously check this place out. I'll be in the corner booth eating everything on the menu.

<review# 571,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/15/2012,4/26/2013,107,136,4,7,4>Wow...So, I haven't ordered Chinese Fast Food in a long time and it is few and far between I find one that "wows" me.  I was immediately greeted with a friendly "hello" by two people.  I saw actual pictures on the wall of dishes unique to their business as well as the standard pics one would see at other Chinese Fast Food establishments.  Everything looked clean and faces were pleasant. I ordered it and am sooo happy I did.  When it was ready, she allowed me to try a bite.  It was absolutely DELICIOUS!!!  The shrimp were mediums w/ vein and super fresh..not frozen. I grew up around the shrimp business and believe I may have some credentials regarding fresh shrimp. hehe I feared the Salt and Pepper Shrimp were going to be too spicy or too salty for others I was sharing with but, they LOVED it.  One of them doesn't even like spicy food.  I'll definitely be ordering this dish again and dining in so it's crisp and fresh! I even enjoyed the fortune cookie.  Definitely not from the same distributor most of the restaurants get their fortune cookies from. I've already spotted several other dishes I'd like to try such as Jalapeno Chicken, Lobster Fried Rice, Lobster Lo Mein... Sounds so good!  So, we'll see!  I'm also interested to see what kind of pancake they use for their Moo Shu... From the genuine, humble, and kind people that worked there/owned the spot to the food.  Never thought I'd have such a positive experience ordering Chinese Take Out..but, wonderful things CAN happen.
<review# 572,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/26/2013,4/25/2013,26,148,,4,6>Having spent the majority of my life in SoCal, I gave up on ever finding a place with good Mexican food.  I've tried Plaza Azteca and all the other local places, and while good they're not great.  Ladies and gents, this place is money.  Swear to god I thought I was back in San Diego.  Someone commented that the shop was in the ghetto...please.  Yes there's a laundromat next door, and it's in a working class neighborhood.  It's not like you're driving into Compton for Roscoes Chicken and Waffles, or into Chula Vista for real Mexican food.  It's a nice open strip mall with a parking lot.  It's safe, and they're friendly.  There were at least two elderly caucasian couples (obvious return guests), as well as other young folks chatting over meals while a construction crew covered in plaster and paint enjoyed theirs.  The food?  Amazing, just like my grandma would have made (if she wasn't an elderly Filipino lady trying to get me to real Filipino "pood")!  I got the steak tacos which were right on point.  My wife got the sopes which she loved.  For variety I got the chimichanga as well, which was ok...not great, but I'd order it again.  Rice and beans were also good, so I'm not sure what to say about that.  I'm also not sure about the hot sauce comment - maybe he was talking about the salsa with the chips, because that was just salsa for the masses, and I don't usually expect it to be overly spiced...the OTHER red sauce was definitely on the hot side, as was the green (in yellow/red mustard/ketchup bottles).  It's the good hot, too...not "burn your mouth so you can't enjoy it" hot, but "why am I suddenly sweating" hot.  $2 Coronitas for happy hour, too!  Could things have been better?  Sure...chips could have been crispier (I think they fry their own); everything else is just preferences based on prior experience rather than them being wrong.  If you're ordering to-go, sidle up to the counter and they'll take your order; if you're eating in, have a seat wherever you can and they'll come to you.  Pay at the cashier.  The attached tienda had some great pastries, and all the votive candles you could need.  So why go here?  Two things:  the food (above), and atmosphere.  International soccer games playing on the multiple HUGE flat screens, music overhead, and decor that makes you feel like you're not in Norfolk anymore.   This is a place where the result is greater than the sum of its parts.  Give it a shot, you're doing yourself a disservice by using the other area restaurants to set your bar for good Mexican food.
<review# 573,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/29/2013,4/24/2013,255,146,,11,5>I came here with some friends to celebrate a retirement. I didn't know what to expect but was looking forward to it since a Yelp Elite event was scheduled to be here (I figured "It gotta be good right?"). Well, it was more than good, it was great! They are currently only open for dinner. It's a quiet little Italian restaurant established in a building that is over 100 years old. Softly played music and tables with candles in glasses help set the ambience. It was a tad bit too dark in there, but they provide individual reading lights for those who need it to be  a bit brighter to read the menu. This location is definitely for adults, you can bring the kids, but this place isn't geared towards completely accomadating them.The servers were on point. When presenting the specials for the evening, John and Marina appeared to really know the menu items, sometimes when servers do this it sounds like they are regurgitating something they learned for a test. The staff was very attentive. I suck down my drinks like a camel, but the server's assistant kept my drink full the entire time, even after I finished my meal. The meal was preluded by some freshly baked Italian bread. We had a group of 16 and shortly after ordering we received our soups and salads that came with some of the meals. The salads were huge and can definitely be shared. My wife and I had the Tortilini Mannino and Polo con Pepperoni , both dishes were super-delicious. Though I was stuffed I made it a point to get a dessert because I was enjoying my dining experience so much, I felt compelled to try a scoop of their gelato. What separates this Italian restaurant from others is their attention to all of the small details. I was completely sold when we asked for to go boxes, they boxed the left overs and wrap it with plastic wrap to help avoid spills during the drive home. I'm sure many can relate to the dreaded moments when it's time for the members of your large party to check out, those waits to close out can be irritating, but they handled us quickly without issue. I will definitely come back to this location and highly recommend Mannino's to anyone who likes Italian cuisine.

<review# 576,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,10/28/2012,4/21/2013,88,68,2,6,5>Strong Margaritas in oversized glasses, unlimited chips and salsa served with that mysterious "white" sauce, sizzling platters of fajitas, and cheap eats through any large number of combination platters from #1 to #30 or more.  These are most of the things people in the Hampton Roads area would expect from a good Mexican restaurant in the area.  If these were the only qualifications then you may just pass on Alanna's Tacqueria altogether. However, you'd be missing out on a nice "hole in the wall" restaurant with good flavor and good value. Oh and they deliver too within the area!Alanna's Tacqueria is located in the same shopping center as The Egg Bistro and Tokyoto off of Kempsville Road. Nestled in the corner of the shopping center the eatery is a small place with about 10-12 tables/booths, a big screen tv, and a notable oversized fork and spoon on the wall reminiscent of what you'd find in most Filipino houses across the nation. I admit when I saw it I cracked a little smile.  There is also a "bar" area where you can sit and watch the cooks making your order.  I went with my girl and some good friends of ours one night to try it out. The meal started with the standard fair of chips and salsa (which looked pretty fresh being that it was more of a blend of diced tomatoes, onions, and chopped cilantro with no sauce binding it together) and also verde and rojo dipping sauces. The verde (green) sauce was nice and mild in flavor but the rojo (red) sauce was rather spicy and almost had a burnt flavor to it. From there we each had a large order of the "Carne Asada Fries" which is a staple item anytime I go out west to Cali at a Mexican restaurant. The fact they had them here was a pleasant surprise.  The fries themselves tasted like seasoned fries you could get at a Walmart (nothing wrong with that as they blended in well with the rest of the dish) served with seasoned steak, guacamole, sour cream and mexican cheese it had a lot of good flavor and for its size was a good deal. I only wish the fries were a little crispier, but then again with the amount of topping loaded on top it's understandable.We took another look at the menu and I noticed that although they don't serve margaritas they do have the standard fare of Mexican and American beers. They also don't have a single item on the menu above $10 which is great!  I ended up getting their Super Burrito which is a large burrito filled with rice and beans and sauce along with your choice of chicken, steak, or pork. I got the steak per the waiter's recommendation and to say the least was very pleased with the ratio of steak to everything else.  It may not be the size of your typical "California Style" burrito but it was packed with I would guess to be close to a pound of chopped steak which was very flavorful and ITIS worthy!  One of my friends got the California Burrito with chicken which had the same things my burrito had but instead of rice the burrito was filled with french fries.My girlfriend and our friend got the Fish Taco Plate which consisted of 3 corn tortilla tacos with fried mahi and shredded cabbage and sauce served with rice and beans.  The only drawback to the tacos was the sauce was pretty nuclear hot which took away from the good flavor of the fish which had a thin crispy batter and was served in big chunks in the tortilla. For dessert we got the fried ice cream which was $3.95 and some churros which were $.99 each! Mind you the owner told us they're pretty much like the ones you would get at an amusement park, but I thought they were much better since they were crunchy on the outside and soft and cream like in the middle. All that was missing was some chocolate to dip it in. Alanna's Tacqueria also has daily specials like $1 taco Tuesdays and kids eat free on Thursdays. It's a nice hangout spot to get some good mexican food that won't break the bank and will leave you full and satisfied. "It is what it is" and I'm OK with that.

<review# 579,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/9/2013,4/18/2013,68,22,1,10,6>The first time I tried french macarons was at Chantal Guillon in San Francisco.  Ever since then, I've been on a search for local bakeries that offered some.  I'm no macaron connoisseur, but I know the difference between a poorly made (stale, wrong consistency) macaron & a fresh, high quality one.I first experienced Terebinth's macarons at a friend's wedding.  It was their wedding favors, and I was so thrilled to see macarons on our table that I ate them right away :P  They were perfect!  The texture was soft, the crust was thin/egg-like, and the filling was just right.  As soon as I had the chance to ask where they ordered the macarons from, I google mapped it right away.  I was happy to find out that Terebinth is near where I work!I've been here a few times now, and I've never been disappointed with their macarons.  My favorite flavors are nutella, earl grey & salted caramel.  They offer different flavors each day and they do run out sometimes (I've had my few shares of going too late), so I would recommend calling ahead.Based on their macarons, I would give this place a 5 star but I'm giving it a 4 for now because I have yet to try their lunch & other pastries.

And you feel how proud he and the staff are of how cool this place is.Give this place a shot one day after work.  Like most guys, I wear a tie and slacks to work.  And as much as I love to belly up to the closest happy hour after work with my friends to grab a drink, there are lots of times I feel way too overdressed.  Havana Nights is the best place to go after work when you don't want  to risk getting wing sauce on your pants.Really, really classy joint!

<review# 584,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/10/2012,4/13/2013,21,28,3,6,3>Borjo is delightful.  Everything that I have tried so far has been a wonderful surprise.Dark roast coffee: good.  I drink my coffee black and don't have high expectations wherever I go.  It didn't taste metallic or watery and I didn't get a mouthful of coffee grounds, so it was a win for me.Chai latte: I now want one every day.Pumpkin muffin:  I had zero hopes for this as it was afternoon and it was sitting in a display case, but it turned out to be pretty good.  It was moist with a nice light pumpkin flavor and some icing on top.Powhatan sandwich: Three cheese, avocado, bacon, and tomato on a grilled multigrain bread. This was not on the menu (special - not sure for how long as it's been up there for over a week I think).  It was fairly light and really tasty.Brie plate: This is listed on the "small plates," but is a generous amount of food.  It came with a large wedge of brie cheese, raspberry preserves, and nice slices of grilled bread.  It was very enjoyable.Breakfast panini (add bacon): Perfect ratios of egg, cheese, and bacon.  It had really nice flavor and wasn't even a little bit greasy.  I have to have napkins for everything and I totally forgot to get one with this sandwich because I didn't need it!The service is excellent and friendly, the music is always good, and the patrons behave themselves.  I don't recommend it (or any coffee house, ever) for serious studying, but if you want to look over some work or meet with a friend, this is a good place for it.
<review# 585,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/30/2013,4/12/2013,21,240,4,5,4>After the talk thread the other week and the reviews, I wanted to check this place out.  It has been about 10 years since I've into a comic shop, as I walked thru the door I was greeted with a friendly smile and a hello, that was nice since I was obviously new to the store, as their regulars came in they greeted them by name, nice touch.  The store is very clean and well organized.  In the '90s I used to collect Image comics because of the quality art work, high quality paper and unique story lines, I found several of my old favs in the used bins.  I was happy to see a couple still going strong like Spawn and Witchblade.  All the new issues were well displayed and easy to see.  They had lots of cool collectables, card sets, a large gaming area and they even had drinks and snacks.  A very nice cool place!
<review# 586,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/10/2013,4/11/2013,27,56,,7,1>This place had only been open 6 days when we decided to try it out but I think they have a lot of potential. When my wife and I walked in we were greeted to some loud reggae music. There wasn't anyone to seat us so we just grabbed a booth along the wall. Shortly thereafter, the waitress brought us our menus. I really liked the diverse barbecue styled items on the menu. I have been to a handful of barbecue spots around Virginia Beach and none of them really grabbed me. Smoke From Above has a pretty decent menu and Whitner's isn't bad either but there isn't anything very exciting on the menu; luckily Smoked Out prevails! Their menu ranges from beef brisket cheesesteaks to bbq chicken wafflestacks, I dig it. I ended up going with the pulled pork platter w/ hush puppies and a side of mushrooms. The pulled pork was pretty awesome. It didn't come with much sauce which I think is great, you get a chance to enjoy the meat without sauce saturation. The hush puppies were pretty damn good but I wasn't that big a fan of the mushrooms since they were cooked in beer....just my preference.All in all, I will be coming back to Smoked Out. The food was pretty awesome and they seem to be able to book some good live music. I'm amped to try the brisket next time!Side note: The wait staff is horrible, worst I've ever seen. This place could definitely use an episode on Kitchen Nightmares!
<review# 587,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/26/2013,4/10/2013,46,196,,5,4>I am in this shopping center at least once a week and have eyed this place on many occasions.  From the outside it looks like a dirty little greasy spoon, today I went in.  It wouldn't be fair to say it was similar to Dorothy opening the door to Oz but I felt more confident is getting a decent lunch once I crossed the threshold.  It's bright and clean inside with a row of red covered booths going down a long wall.  I grabbed a shiny stool at the counter.  Jenro's grown son was behind the counter, he told me that him and his dad opened this place in the 70's instead of building a tree house.  They sold hot dogs and bean soup.  They still serve those items but have greatly expanded the menu.Today was the first day for my waitress and it was her first day being a waitress!  She had a couple of mis-steps but hey, we all had a first day.  She had a great personality.I chose one of their four home made soups, chicken noodle, and a grilled cheese sandwich.  The soup was good, not too salty like many are, but the chicken was tough, perhaps over cooked. Jenro's makes their own bread but by the time I got there, 2:00, it was sold out so I got store bought wheat with cheddar cheese.  I like a cheesy sandwich, gooey and hot.  There were only two slices of cheese on it, not enough, imho.  But the garnishes on the plate and the home made potato chips made up for it.  Look at the pic of the rose shaped tomato garnish, very nice touch.If you're hungry and in the Haygood plaza near Farm Fresh stop in and give them a try.
<review# 588,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/22/2013,4/9/2013,122,469,2,8,1>Whenever I'm in the greenbrier area, this is my go-to for lunch. There are places LIKE it (Taste Unlimited?) but this is the only place that I feel is really dedicated to healthy, fresh, and local. It's hard to decide what to get, I went with the goat cheese & roasted red pepper panini with sweet potato fries. So good! They offer fountain drinks or water but I feel this could be an area for expansion to offer fresh juices/teas/wheat grass, etc. We didn't have to wait too long. I will say that they are super stingy with passing out condiments, it's kind of weird. My friend and I both asked for ketchup for our fries and she brought over a tablespoon of ketchup. Granted the fries are awesome on their own, but that's annoying. Then we saw a couple people go up to the counter and ask for more salad dressing and they kind of gave the side eye. It's such a stingy thing to do, hopefully they either just start giving more product or loosening the hell up. For that I take a star away. Don't mess with my ketchup or dressing.I also think they offer dinner entrees (that is NOT listed on their menu) on certain nights as well as desserts, like macaroons, that again, is not listed on their menu. A bit strange but either way, I'd like to return and try a dinner and more of their salads.

<review# 590,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,2/27/2013,4/7/2013,121,170,2,12,5>The building that occupied 2700 Hampton Blvd. was many things - a check cashing place, a tax preparer, and who knows what else.  I have to say that it was both a surprise and a bit exciting to see something special coming to that space. The build-out began; the empty shell practically doubled the space, but there was still no notice that it would be a new restaurant there better yet a smokehouse.  The Small's sign went up long before the restaurant was close to being finished.  It was a long, hard-to-take build.  I'm still not sure how long it had taken from start to finish. I pass that building twice a day and took my own mental time lapse photograph everyday. I drove by last Friday evening and noticed an 'Open' sign and the front windows completely covered in fog.  Finally, I thought to myself.We were there early today; maybe 11 am sharp.  The restaurant was still pretty empty and we were immediately greeted by the hostess.  Our waitress soon joined us and took our drink orders.  While she was away, we checked out the menu.  I had a hankering for some kind of mixed platter.  I was hoping it had pulled pork, brisket, and ribs; those are, in my opinion, the top three smoked meats that tell you if a barbecue restaurant is legit.Two of us went for the Farmhouse Platter - pulled pork, sliced brisket, and pulled chicken and one had the smoked sausage. I guess two out of three top meats ain't bad.  The sides on the table included onion ring, cole slaw, cheese grits, and cucumber salad. The cucumber salad and cheese grits were super delicious and the stars of the side items. The onion rings were hand dipped, but the rings themselves were a bit too large and difficult to eat.The pulled pork, in my opinion, wasn't pulled at all; it was more chopped than pulled.  It had good pork flavor and the Carolina BBQ sauce really accentuated its flavor.  I had my heart set on pork of the pulled variety though.I was looking more forward to the beef brisket.  I think we all have aspirations of having Texas-style championship brisket on a local menu.  We've all seen Salt Lick, Mueller's, Franklin's, etc. turn us all into Pavlov's dogs.  We've seen Oklahoma Joe's burnt ends on Travel Channel and wished we could jump in the car and take a trip West for a taste. I think my expectation may have been too high; Small's brisket didn't have the flavor profile I was hoping for.  The brisket was tender, but the lack of a smoke ring detracted from its flavor profile. You can doctor anything with sauce...they have a Texas and a Kansas City sauce in addition to the Carolina, but saucing already smoked meat really defeats the purpose of ordering said meat.  I do like sauce in general, though.The pulled chicken was my least favorite of the three.  It was just chicken, in my opinion, and nothing more.What I found at Small's was a wonderfully beautiful space destined to go primetime.  The service was wonderful. The location is great, right down the street from ODU, Lambert's Point, and Larchmont to one side and Ghent on the other. A restaurant that serves smoked meats and seafood, especially raw oysters, in this area has a nearly unbeatable concept.  To top it all off, Small's has a happy hour.It's my hope that Small's Smokehouse & Oyster Bar continues to grow and bring beautifully smoked meat and fresh seafood to us all.
<review# 591,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/1/2013,4/6/2013,14,98,8,15,5>Clean and intimate-like atmosphere. The age group gears towards the mature audiences; you have to be 25 years old to enter the lounge. The drinks were fantastic; reasonable pricing at the bar. The type of music were mostly Hip-Hop, R&B, Reggae. Even though I felt out of place (because I was trying something new "hint: i do country music and latin sounds, so this was wayyyyyyy out of my comfort zone") but it had nothing to do with the location/atmosphere. They have a medium sized dance floor. They have white couches to lounge around, open floor plan, restrooms were cleaned, the DJ was fun. The customers/patrons were civil and nice. Great crowd.Now, there were a couple of things I did not like. The cover charge is extremely expensive $20/person. That was an eye opener. :) Another con was that the DJ was playing great music but constantly kept fading the music to hear himself talk on the mic. I can see the DJ needing to intervene but there were people dancing and every time I thought I had a move going, I lost my rhythm because the music would fade out to allow the DJ to talk. He's a very talkative DJ. *DISLIKE* Let the people enjoy the song.Other than that, I gave it a 4, even though I wouldnt come back for multiple reasons: cover charge, annoying DJ, location (took me 40 mins to get there). Hey, if Hip/Hop, R&B, Reggae is your "thang", then do you. This is a great spot to check out. It's just not up my alley. But I can now say that I know how to dance to some caribbean/jamaican dance moves, hahaha. I think a few of the patron felt pity for me (i think I was the only hispanic on the scene) hahaha so they jumped in to help me get the "music". Great people. :)
<review# 592,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/26/2013,4/5/2013,31,234,1,6,6>Out running errands is just a day to day reality. When the hubs and I stopped in at La Bella for dinner, we inadvertently found ourselves on a romantic date.The interior was humble, but the simple design and limited seating made the room feel intimate. Both the lighting and the music were soft. Dark woods, oak barrels, vine laden landscapes, small tables you can reach across and hold hands. It was enchanting.Service was friendly, fast, and unobtrusive. It was like we had the place to ourselves and food just appeared, our drinks refilled.  They had a great selection of wines and we started out with some warm, fresh bread. We opted to order recommended specials. Coming from Jersey, I'm always pretty critical of Italian food, and for the first time since moving to Hampton Roads, I found a place worth visiting again.
<review# 593,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/26/2013,4/4/2013,163,183,4,6,4>The only reason I went out of my way before heading to NN for this little hole in the wall is because of the fantastic looking teriyaki photos that Matt M. Have been posting and popping up in my feed. Thanks for that Matt. The pictures just made me crave teriyaki more and more. This little restaurant, if you can even call it that, reminds me of an abandoned Capt'n Ds, previously owned by the Chinese mob. That probably doesn't make much sense, but when you see this little "dive" you'll know what I'm talking about. There's parking all around the place but absolutely NO lines are visible, so park however you want, just be courteous. I went for lunch, and I was the only one there. Inside is very small. A few tables lined up in a row, cafeteria style, but nothing more. The front counter was barricaded with plastic glass and a small hole for exchanging payment of food. Quite a reminiscent view of the Philippines  typical corner store. The old Asian man, I could only presume to be Japanese, took my order promptly and started heating the grill. A few minutes later, it was all ready, bagged and stuffed with a fork, some napkins and a soy sauce. The food, oh, the food. Superb! It was far better than the Sakura Elite of McArthur Mall. But also sweeter than Sakkio Japan of Lynnhaven. I would say it's in between for me. I only tried their chicken teriyaki, so I will have to make a return and try other things on their menu. -1 Star for the location, layout and physical aesthetics of the restaurant.

<review# 596,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/18/2013,4/1/2013,220,185,2,16,4>A brand spankin' new international mart located on Lynnhaven & Rosemont.  It's a big store but not huge.  However, there is a tremendous amount of variety crammed up in that joint.  They make very good use of the space they have.  I found Thai tea leaves (to make Thai tea), loads of different instant noodles of various ethnicities, various fresh & frozen noodles (Korean, Chinese, eye.), and the usual suspects you'd find in regular good 'ol American grocery stores.  The produce section was pretty fresh with some exceptions. The seafood dept looked pretty good...with the exception of some of the seafood in wicker baskets BUT further down the fish packed in ice looked very fresh.  Nice gelatinous clear eyes in most of the fish I saw.  Also on hand were fishmongers ready to clean your fish...just be aware of the bucket that says "propinas por favor/ tips please".  Another Korean-owned international supermart that has anything and everything anyone could desired...especially when cooking anything Asian or Latino.  Hopefully this won't go the same way Fresh World did...downhill and then gone.  I hope they continue to improve so this can be my new go-to international/Asian mart!

<review# 604,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/3/2012,3/24/2013,74,230,3,6,3>I've probably driven past this place a hundred times and had never given it a thought.  Then, one day my wife says she wants chicken fried steak and, for whatever reason, this joint pops into my head.  Random.  So, off we went.  When you walk into the place, the first thing you notice is that it looks like you have stepped back in time 30 years. The decor is dated.  Like dated.  Do you watch Restaurant Impossible?  Well, that guy would gut this place and try to modernize it.  But, as my wife said, "I kinda like it" and I kinda did too.  Our server, whose name I don't remember, was very nice and attentive.  She did a very good job.  My wife had her chicken fried steak, though it was only available as a breakfast dish.  It came with white gravy, home fries, toast, and eggs.  She liked it all and so did I (I usually eat half her meal as well as mine.  The result of course is my not so girlish figure).  I ordered a reuben and it was only OK.  The corned beef was a little fatty and didn't have much flavor.  But, to be fair, I have been ruined for any other reuben after trying Route 58s so I should have gone a different direction.  It wasn't bad just not great.  The fries were hot and fresh, so they were good.  As others have said, there is a fairly strong hint of cigarette smoke in the place and that normally would be a big turn off for me.  But, it wasn't awful.  However, if you are sensitive to it at all, this isn't your place.  Luckily for me, my parents exposed me to cigarette smoke my whole childhood so I am used to it!!  I can definitely see us coming back again for breakfast or lunch.

I thought this restaurant was too cute with all the German decor everywhere. I've never had a bad customer experience here the staff is always great. So check them out, this place is excellent!

<review# 614,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,10/9/2012,3/14/2013,18,133,4,5,3>I first had Cane's in Ohio and I was instantly hooked. Amazing chicken fingers, weird but great [and greasy] texas toast, and fresh steaming french fries. Since I'm from California (a Cane's deprived state), I had to rely on my trips to Vegas to get it. When I found out there was a Cane's in my new home town, I was STOKED! This location, though, is a little wobbly compared to other locations.The staff is generally nice, but some have been less than friendly. Which leads me to my next issue: about half the time I eat here the soda machine is out of their amazing, soft ice! It sounds ridiculous, but the ice at Cane's is probably the best I've had. It's basically like crushed ice, but even lighter! But, after having to ask for ice from their *~special*~ ice machine behind the counter, they always seemed a little perturbed. Also, the sweet ice tea is the best! I usually mix it with unsweetened to cut down on the sugar.The chicken itself is always good, but better some times than others. Last time I went it was slightly cold, which was disappointing. The fries, though, have always been steaming and great, which is saying something for curly fries. The toast has also always been amazing, so if you're a Cane's newbie then don't blow it off! Your life may be changed forever. I can't stop before talking about the special Cane's dipping sauce. They give you a small container of it, but it should be enough to enjoy its greatness in combination with all parts of your food (chicken, fries, bread). It's really just like thousand island dressing, but it's still amazing!So why 3 stars? Basically the inconsistency here is a problem in my opinion. They're so close to being great but can't quite reach it. Also, as always, it's just a little expensive for what you get. 3 chicken fingers, cole slaw, toast, fries and a drink will run you about $9. Pricey for fast food!Bottom line: Do I still love Canes? Yes. Will I keep coming back here when I need my fill of junk food? Yes. The price and inconsistency make me a little less than ecstatic about this location, and are probably why (aside from not wanting diabetes and hypertension) I don't come more than once every couple of months. If you like chicken fingers, toast, and fries then give this a shot! I think you'll be glad you did.
<review# 615,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/6/2013,3/13/2013,63,174,,6,6>Kincaid's is one of those chain restaurants that will restore your faith in chain restaurants.First of all, it's a chain, but a really small one.  Nine locations, in places like Oakland and Redondo Beach, CA, St Paul, MN, Phoenix, and our very own MacArthur Mall location.  Larger than Burton's (in Va Beach), but way smaller than Ruby Tuesday (where isn't there a Ruby Tuesday?).   And as with these other chains, we again found that, if you'll watch what you order and stick with what they try to accentuate and do well, you'll have a pretty good visit.We were at MacArthur Mall on a trip to the bookstore around lunchtime, and since we've been to 219 a bunch of times, and everything else except the sandwich shops and pizza places in downtown are closed for Saturday lunch, we stopped into Kincaid's for our first visit.  A nice initial vibe from the place for the both of us:  the restaurant is spacious, with high ceilings, lots of indirect lighting, dark woods, burgundies and earth-tones on the walls, nicely done decorations and plants, high-end tables and booths, a huge bar area (where, thankfully, all the TVs reside), and an open kitchen with a huge grille.  We were quickly met, warmly greeted and shown to a lovely booth right under the large oil portrait of The General himself, complete with corn-cob pipe --- a good start!  We order our coffees, and begin the walk through their lunch menu --- and immediately notice some old standbys, but also a number of offerings that could be good.  How about Meatloaf Sliders, with olive mayonnaise and sweet hot mustard?  Maybe a Crab Melt, with aged Parmesan and cheddar cheeses?  Or Crispy Fish Tacos, with chipotle-lime sour cream and pico de gallo, on soft corn tortillas?  And, since we're both big grilled chicken fans, the Grilled Chicken Club, with a lemon-Dejon marinated grilled chicken breast, smoked bacon, tomato and sliced brie, served on a brioche bun, sounds very tempting.  Additionally, of course there's a large and very tempting offering of half-pound burgers, prepared in all kinds of different ways.  Our very friendly and competent server Dallas arrives again; I ask about the Crab Melt, and am told that it's really their crab and artichoke dip, spread on a roll with sliced tomato and the cheeses.  And then I remember the old restaurant adage that says "...have what they accentuate"  --- and promptly order the 'Shroom Burger (half-pound, medium rare, sauteed mushrooms, caramelized onions, Swiss cheese and tomato, on a brioche bun).  My wife goes with the Grilled Chicken Club,  opts for the sweet potato fries, and we have another cup of coffee.  And both choices turn out to be really delicious --- char grilled to perfection, wonderful flavors from the meats and accompaniments, and huge.  I have rarely had a burger that was done as well, especially in its medium-rare preparation.  My wife's chicken was as good as I'm able to do on my grille --- light marinade, still juicy and not overcooked, and crispy on the outside.  Just delicious, all-around.  And prices were where you might expect --- somewhat higher than Ruby Tuesday, but lower than Burton's.  Our sandwiches, fries and coffee came to $35.10, before tip.So, for those of us who sometimes can be a bit snobbish about chains --- myself included --- give Kincaid's a try.  Just remember that they're not trying to be a fresh seafood place, or a high-end steak place, or a fresh-red-sauce Italian place.  You'll have a great experience if you stick to having what they're trying to accentuate.  And, at Kincaid's, the big open grille that you'll see when you come in should be a dead give-away.
<review# 616,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/3/2013,3/12/2013,183,190,3,10,6>Unbelievably, insanely good!  I feel so lucky to have found this place that all the Yelpers have been raving about and I am busting at the seams to tell everyone about it.  We had a little UYE lunch here today and I am still in a trance even tonight.  Judy took such good care of us and was full of excellent recommendations--we shared about 10 entrees and I loved every single one of them.  This is truly authentic chinese--she actually recruited a chef to come over from Sichuan Province in China--so this is the real deal...We were lucky enough to get seated at one of the tables with the lazy susan in the middle, to make all the sharing that much easier and more fun.  There are a couple of things that you absolutely must order every time.  As you may have figured out by some of the reviews, you definitely have to get the XiaoLongBao.  Judy saw me rip one of these trying to get it out so she was so sweet in showing me how to do these right--so the trick is you gently take the dumpling into spoon to get it out of the steamer and then eat it whole--do NOT just try and grab it out of the steam basket with your chopsticks--you will fail and it will be a total Debbie Downer moment.  As the dumpling bursts in your mouth, the soup and the pork will flood your mouth and fireworks will be going off.  The other must have is the onion pancake and this comes with a little dipping sauce---hmmm, hmmm!Do yourself a huge favor and don't order anything the typical white person would order from a Chinese restaurant--skip the sesame or general's chicken--look around and realize you are not at Bamboo Hut. I am sure that these are great here too, but you are selling yourself short if you get one of those---you did come here for authentic Szechuan cooking, right??? If you aren't sure what to order, just talk to Judy.  She will get a feel for what you might like and will help steer you towards a magnificent order.   So, since we had about 10 things at the table, I can't go into details on all of them, but I will cue you in to my favorites.  I told Judy I wanted duck and she suggested Tea Smoked Duck, especially if I want the crispy skin--sold!  Next, we tried several lamb dishes--I think the stir fried lamb with house chili pepper was the best, but I'm a little torn because the stir fried lamb with mixed vegetables was also off the charts and it came out steaming and sizzling!  Thanks to another one of Judy's recommendations, I would also suggest you try the Yu Shiang Pork--just do it and your mouth will be happy.  Most of the dishes come with white rice, so you may want to add some pork fried for the table too.I was really impressed with Judy and her new restaurant.  I want to bring everybody here because she really does have something special.  And, Judy herself just makes the experience so much more personal, as she tries to talk with each and everyone that comes in and gets to know who they are and what they like.  Just see, when you go back in even after a couple of months, Judy will remember what you drink and what your favorite dishes are.  Thank you Judy!  You have made a permanent customer out of me!UPDATE: I HAVE DISCOVERED THE HOT POT!!! You will not find this secret item on the menu! You have to give Judy a little heads up before you come in that you will be coming in for the hot pot...it is 18 bucks all you can eat and it is well worth it...think of it as Chinese Fondue.  They will bring a lovely hot pot with spicy broth on one side and not spicy on the other side.  Then, you have a full selection of meats and veggies, etc.  I am talkin fish, fish balls (definitely get both of these), shrimp, pork, beef, lamb, mushrooms, noodles, cabbage, sweet potatoes...basically neverending amounts of yumminess.  Having this hot pot at the table really brought the whole table together for an interactive dining event. Judy will bring you some sauces and cilantro to mix together to dip your meats.  Go get your hot pot on!!!
<review# 617,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/24/2013,3/9/2013,83,478,2,4,2>This one tends to be less crowded than the one on holland so sometimes I Iike to switch it up and come here even though the other is closer to my house. The waitstaff was efficient and effective, not overly friendly, but I can understand that given the crowds. I think this place will end up being our new go-to for pizza on the Peninsula.

Once again, they cooked it just right. Not too smushy.I've also had the masaman curry and the drunken noodles here and both were just as good. I would caution anyone with a nut allergy to be careful and check for sure.This will be a definitely stop whenever I crave Thai food.

<review# 630,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/25/2012,2/24/2013,38,86,,9,5>This is an classic barber shop with a modern twist. It is still the spot to go chillax and rap to the fellas, but what is out of the norm at other black barber shop are 1) you sign in...first come first served without an appointment, and 2) they accept credit & debit (w/ major CC logo) cards! I've been to a lot of barber shops, but to be able to charge your cut with having to run to the bank is a plus. Here's another plus...Every barber there can cut! This is the first barbershop that I've been to where I needed to avoid a chair. You know not everybody that has a chair knows how to do a simple edge up. To top it off, they have complementary refreshments. This is another reason I keep coming back. The only issue I have is with the price. Adult cuts are $18 for regular, $23 with facial cuts, and $28 if they use a razor.  This is the highest I've been to in Virginia Beach.  However, the overall convenience and comfort negates me going elsewhere.  If you are in a desperate need of a cut, check Image out. Tell them Lawrence sent you!

On the way back, we stopped in to check out the goods at 215p.  Although they'd already *officially* closed at 2, they kept the doors and grill open for our unofficial after-party.  Totally worth it.  I got the shorty (egg and cheese) and my love ordered the stevie (fried chicken, pickles, mustard, and honey).  So darn tasty.  We got our treats to go, and they didn't make it out of the parking lot.  Totally yummmy...A little off the beaten path in Park Place, but well worth the trip.  You'll have to plan carefully as they're open from Wed to Sat from 10a - 2p. Check it out - you won't regret it.

<review# 641,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/2/2013,2/13/2013,72,106,2,3,4>Im so full I can't move, in a good way. Which means I ate too much cause it was too GOOD! We were going to go to another place but seating was limited so since this was around the corner and on my list of places to check out we went. We walked in and luckily got the last two top table, as they were pack for the 1 pm lunch rush. Our server greeted us within minutes. He was overall very nice and personable. The decor is artsy and fun, the bathrooms were fairly clean and had as much flair as the whole place. We opted for an appetizer which is rare for us. The Artichoke Dip with Pita wedges was awesome. tIt contained actual huge pieces of artichoke, not the tiny little chopped up chunks you usually see in this kind of dip. They make the pita wedges themselves seasoned with a parmesan seasoning, very good. I see so often a dip of this nature will be so tasty but served with boring run of the mill tortilla chips or something. It was a nice touch having the pita wedges, they added flavor and held up against the heavy dip due to its giant artichoke chunks!After much debate I ordered the Spotswood Melt, and thats what it does, it melts in your mouth. The burger was not over cooked, the cheese and onions are all melted into the crispy grilled sourdough bread. You cant just say there is bacon on this burger because its not your average bacon, it is thick cut, cooked perfect and delicious! This burger  was perfect and full of guilt! I originally ordered fries which i would have to say were the only thing I did not like, they were nothing special, just frozen fries. So I asked for an extra order of coleslaw after the fact, Im glad I did. I find good coleslaw to be hard to find. Most is watery and flavorless or has been sitting in the cooler way too long. This had long chunky cuts of all  colors of cabbage, with an awesome sauce. It was not just sweetened mayo, it had an asian flavor too it and i immediately  recognized a sesame oil flavor. I flagged down the waiter to ask and he told us it  was called Dragon sauce. Whatever its called doesn't matter though, it was good. I was so pleased with my meal however the portions are large so I took half home with me. My boyfriend ordered the Bacon cheeseburger which to me looked pretty awesome. The Bacon makes it, its such good quality bacon. He seemed to really enjoy it so it must have been good. With it he ordered onion rings, which I would refer to as onion tires! they were giants and the batter was light and not too over powering. similar to a beer batter I would say. They serve the onion rings with another lovely sauce they make that you could dip anything you were eating into and it made it good. It was delicious! I would like to go back here many more times, next time is to try their Funky Chicken which they are known for.
<review# 642,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/18/2012,2/12/2013,88,68,,9,7>Ask anyone local or tourist in the Virginia Beach area where the heart of the action for restaurants and entertainment is at the Oceanfront and they may tell you between 16th and 31st Street. If you're looking for a great dining experience composed of seasonal tapas style treats you may wanna head further past 31st Street... No further... Just a little bit furth... yeah hang a right at 40th and pull into the little parking lot and head into Pacifica!This was my first time here at this restaurant but not the first time I have enjoyed tapas from the collection of restaurants it is under. Pacifica is part of a chain of tapas style restaurants including "Six" (in Hampton), "Empire" (in Norfolk), and "Crackers" (also in Norfolk) under the name "Little Bar Bistro." I have been to "Six" previously.I went with my girlfriend and two other great friends last night to try their offerings.  I started with the Southern Mule which was a cocktail made of Southern Comfort, Lime juice, and Ginger Beer, while my GF had the Pink Paradise. I  will say that both of these drinks are quite the contrast in that mine was enjoyable with a good balance of flavors and could be had throughout the meal. Her's was one of heavy alcohol flavor with tropical and coconut flavors that probably having 2 to 3 would put you in a good mood the rest of the night.The meal itself was great. Looking back on our selections they turned out to be a good variety of land and sea, taste and textures.  We started with the Fried Calamari with Pickled Peppers and Smoked Remoulade. We've had Calamari from more than 2 handfuls of places in the Hampton Roads area and beyond and this one had great flavor and crunch and was sans the traditional "marinara" sauce. I then ordered the Sweet Potato and Pork Belly Pie with Crispy Edward's Ham and Rosemary Oil. For $9 it could have very well been an entree dish for it's size.  I think they did a great job with the flavors as the sweet potato was smooth and pork belly could be found throughout the pie, the ham added a nice crunch and saltiness to the dish to balance out the sweetness in the dish.  I then had the Sea Scallops with Butternut Squash Puree and Gala Apples. Such a well composed dish as you can see from my picture. My only critique of it was that I wish the puree were a little bit thicker and not so much watery like baby food puree but the flavors all worked very well. The scallops (3 of them) were all well seared and seasoned. The natural buttery flavor from them went well with the squash puree and the matchstick Gala apple garnish provided nice crunch and acidity to cut through the richness of the scallops.The last savory item I had was the Oyster "Chowder" with Bacon & Cornmeal Scone.  I put "Chowder" in quotes because it's not the typical consistency of a chowder which is very thick.  This dish eats more like a soup and a damn good one at that.  With great flavor and a generous helping of whole oysters in the soup it was delicious and satisfying. The Bacon & Cornmeal scone was a nice alternative to the packaged oyster crackers you may be used to getting.The four of us ended the night with S'mores which was great in the sense that after a night of eating composed plates you can still indulge in an interactive, messy ordeal that never loses it's luster. One order makes enough for 6 S'mores and the presentation was well done (Just like at "Six").Pacifica has a great cocktail and martini menu as well and some great beers to wind down with or get rowdy with in a small but inviting atmosphere. There is bench style seating toward the back of the restaurant as well as a center lounge area with modern style couches and tables. The lighting is a bit dim during night time but nothing to complain about. The only thing we did have a comment with is that they don't split checks (as noted on the menu in a rather humorous, smart ass manner). So if you're looking to split the bill be sure to break out your phone calculator :)Definitely looking forward to making a return trip to this place as well as the others in the area as it's a good place for all to enjoy, have a good meal, good laughs and is away from the hustle and bustle of the Oceanfront strip.
<review# 643,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/30/2012,2/11/2013,96,146,4,3,4>I came here about two months ago; my sister in law was in town and wanted to treat us to a nice upscale dinner. I looked this place up online and saw the great reviews. It's tucked away off the oceanfront, nice property, Valet parking service Ect, we were a group of 4. I walked in the night before and got a table reserved for us that was near the kitchen area. as you can imagine is was very loud and busy near that spot but it was not a deal breaker, the establishment inside is very warm and cozy, elegant. Most of the staff was nice, the waitress were a bit off putting however, almost like you could feel them observing you, like if you took to long for a portion of your meal and they have it waiting ect. Sommelier, Marc Sauter, makes the experience however, he is a pleasure to interact with and was my favorite part of the experience all together. For some reason I could blindly listen to this mac describe wines and methods of wine making or facts and never get bored, I'm still evaluating if this is a good thing or not :) The food is excellent, the blue Crab Mac and Cheese, although usually a dish that would be considered generic was memorable and mouth watering. The steaks are also fantastic and were paired perfectly with our wine. The selection of cheeses also works wonderfully if you are enjoying a wine flight. Other dishes like the Chinatown shrimp tempura are...well... Not that great. Its pretty much shrimp tempura with pop-rocks on it, unless they changed it, it was not a hit. Anything you order (except the poprocks shrimp that someone came up with after smoking the chiba.)  will most likely be wonderful, of the dishes we got, between fish, steaks or deserts, all were fantastic. That being said... this all comes at a price, chances are you are willing to accept that if you are even considering a restaurant of this caliber.  This in my opinion is the best restaurant in this area, for fine dining period. Fantastic location to impress a Date, romantic Dinner or special occasion.

<review# 654,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,1/18/2013,1/31/2013,121,170,2,9,5>I had been driving by Chow for weeks waiting for it to open. It was appetizing -- the most appetizing thing I'd ever seen in that building on that part of Colley Ave.  The fact that it's close to work and smack in the middle of neighborhood where I have a huge number of friends was another plus.  Well, last night was the night to pay Chow a visit.The space looked as inviting inside as it did from the outside.  The decor is simply and not overly done.  There are lots of tables, some communal. There are wall-to-wall chalkboards that display the menus; the drink options are given out as a traditional menu, however.On the way in, I ran into a couple from work.  We talked for a while and they eventually settle into a table with another coworker of mine.  All together I met 5 people there that I knew.  It was an omen, I guess, of things to come....good things to come that is.I started with a Smartmouth Alter Ego - it's a Hefeweizen and was so good, I had to have another.  John G. turned me on to Smartmouth; one of his good buddies is the owner of this local brewery.The fried chicken livers with the Garlic Balsamic Reduction was fantastic.  The livers were beautifully done and there was a little salad at the bottom of the bowl to boot.I had the Salisbury Steak and Gravy.  It was the 2.0 version - huge portion, the steak was a little pink inside. The mashed potatoes were a bit chunky, but I didn't mind that.   The mac and cheese was a bit soupy and not the best, in my opinion. The table was rounded out with the Pork Belly. It was on the stringy side, but was full of flavor.  The BBQ Pork Sandwich was OK as well.  It was not the traditional stuff done in a smoker, low and slow for hours -- it seemed to be cooked pork, shredded and doctored up with BBQ sauce.  It was not bad, though.  The final dish was fried green tomatoes with the ham salad.  I didn't try it, so I cannot speak on it's taste.  The presentation was good, however.Overall, the food was good.  The beer selection was better than good.  The decor was appealing and not overly pretentious. The waitstaff was very attentive and knowledge of the menu.  All those things together make a good neighborhood hangout; I supposed that was the objective of the owner(s).I know I'll go back - for drinks, for dinner, for both.  First impressions are important and I enjoyed my first impression of Chow Restaurant and Bar.

Not the fanciest or the prettiest, but definitely the tastiest. And the icing was delicious as well. The cupcakes are a standard size & fairly priced at $8 - $13 for a 1/2 dozen depending on the flavor. You can even request organic ingredients for an additional $3. They have vegan dog treats too!

I ended up going with the Montmartre, which was incredibly flavorful but didn't necessarily blow me away. The owner told us he's planning on scaling back the menu to only about 10 burgers after opening month, to include the Montmartre, to decrease prep time (and probably cost as well). The best fries are the NYE spice and the house fries; the NYE definitley have a kick and the house are classic garlic, rosemary, & parm. They have an eclectic selection of beer on draft (see picture) and interesting wine picks. Service was laid back and friendly and the owner seems very hands on. They have a kids menu and we also saw a bunch of kids in there, which will make us feel better about returning with the kid. Overall, very impressed at what they've done with the place, the food is commendable, and we look forward to returning and seeing what kind of tweaks happen to the menu.

They offer low fees per transaction, but at least you will be able to do credit card transactions.
<review# 661,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/25/2012,1/23/2013,54,55,2,9,3>Delicious Filipino food at a great value with very friendly staff.Went based on my homie Matthew M.'s review and was glad I did.  I walked in and sort of stood there awkwardly looking around the bustling restaurant for a few moments until one of the girl staff members grinned at me and knowingly asked "Is this your first time here?"   I admitted it was and she gave me the run down of how it works at FeLynn (sit wherever you want, hit the buffet line, pay, eat).PANCIT:  Solid, standard.  No complaints.  I like pancit but haven't yet had a version that really rocked my world more than any other.CHICKEN CURRY:  Although FeLynn's recipe isn't spicy the way I like it, it's worthwhile to note that I prefer my curries to be hotter than the 7th circle of Hell, and I did find their dish to be tasty with succulent pieces of chicken, even if it's a little on the mellow side in regard to heat.BBQ PORK SKEWERS:  These were a highlight for me.  The pork is tender and well-seasoned without losing its fundamental porky flavor.  They're grilled perfectly with just the right amount of caramelized bits on the outside.  The majority of patrons whose dishes I glanced at had chosen these bad boys.LUMPIA:  I wasn't raised eating this kind of egg roll but I love them and feel that FeLynn executes this simple, classic dish very well.  Fried perfectly, nice ratio of meat to veggies.TURON (fried plantain):  I'd never had this before today and absolutely loved it.  It's a subtle dessert; Not overly sweet and I felt that the textural contrast between the fried spring roll wrapping and the plantain was fantastic.  Plus, it's like a buck-fifty.HALO-HALO:  Also a first for me today, but definitely not my last.  This thing is delicious and perhaps has more going on than any other drink on the planet.  Ice cream, crispy rice, red beans, maraschino cherry, tapioca, shaved ice, sweet corn and probably at least five other items I can't recall now or couldn't identify in the first place but which were shocking in how well they went together.My only criticism -- A few of the dishes were lukewarm.  This isn't unusual with buffets and given how delicious the food was, it didn't seriously bother me.Definitely looking forward to coming back here.

I always hesitate about what to order, but once I taste it I am quite pleased. The bread and butter for $3 is no ordinary bread and butter. It's a baguette toasted so that the outside is crunchy and toasty and the inside is warm and slightly chewy accompanied with an herbed/spiced butter of some sort (depending on the whim of the cook, I suspect). I will unashamedly admit that the butter was so good that I proceeded to eat the rest of it with a spoon. I could honestly order multiple plates of the bread and butter. I had the clam chowder which was broth based, not cream or tomato based and it was wonderful. So flavorful and satisfying. The one thing that truly bothers me is that the restaurant states on the menu that they do not split checks, with some quip about "what's a few bucks between friends."I always forget that they don't split checks and I rarely carry cash. So I have had to ask for an exception, which they have so far always granted (about three times). But it would be nice if they would consider customer service in this regard and axe that policy.

request when making a reservation) is so spot on with his timing that I think his nickname should be the Metronome, or perhaps the Mind Reader.  When we think we are ready for another drink or we think we would like to split another order of oysters, he magically appears and asks the very question we were thinking just moments before.  I don't know how he does it.  Is there a microphone under your tongue.  It puts filet mignon to shame.  Your carnivorous life will be unfulfilled if you do not sample this dish at least once before you give up the ghost.For nostalgia sake, I opted for the Tomahawk Veal Chop which makes an occasional appearance on the menu during the winter months.  Simply served with gratin potatoes and braised greens, it could not have been more soul satisfying.  My manager and pastry chef prior to our visit to craft a surprise dessert that paid homage to her native land.  When the time came,  Wes presented us with a uniquely crafted Chranachan styled trifle with Drambuie ice cream garnished with whiskey-soaked cranberries.It was perfect.

<review# 679,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/29/2012,1/4/2013,18,133,,4,2>Public house is definitely one of the more unique places on Colley, which is why I keep getting lured back in. I'll be honest, it's not the best place in the world (which is why I spent several minutes teetering between the 3 and 4 star buttons in contemplation), but it's good enough to recommend for a try. The main theme here is kind of a North-west european hip, speakeasy, gastropub. Confusing? Maybe, but I think that's a good representation! They have several rooms (including a smelly smokers room in the back) and a bar at the front. It's usually fairly loud here, so not the best for a date, but a great place for relaxing after a long day of work/school. The menu is very clever (err, 'sassy'?), but the food is different than anything in the area. Everything I've had is pretty good to great. The better thing's I've tasted were the mac and cheese (with chicken tenders!!), shepherd's pie, and Fish and Chips. Something interesting is that most items come with a side of green apple slices (fries cost extra). This is definitely an awesome thing for the oversized public, but I like my french fries better and would rather not pay extra. That's just me though.The service is usually great too! On several trips, my school had functions here and they were very liberal with the rules as far as what they were giving us discounts on. They're always attentive and willing to split even the most complicated checks (everybody with their own meals and some people sharing some things and other people sharing others...sorry, waiters!!). The prices are definitely more than what I'm comfortable with to be a regular here (always around $13/14 for dinner and $5 for a beer), but it's not too insane. I would come much more often if everything was $2 cheaper (it makes a difference!!).Bottom line: If you're looking for something different than the usual places in Norfolk or on Colley and don't mind a little loud-talking with your company, this is worth a try! The meals aren't the cheapest, but you'll generally get what you pay for and get a chance to try something you haven't tried before. Don't expect the best food you've ever had, just something different, and you'll be satisfied. Also they have many local and non-local beers on tap if you're into that!

<review# 682,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/7/2012,1/1/2013,63,174,,10,5>On a friend's recommendation, my wife and I visited Yukai on a Friday night before a movie. The restaurant is located on Laskin Rd in Virginia Beach's Hilltop area, and has seen various lives as two or three different themed buffets over the last 20+ years. We hadn't been in the building since it was the Old Country Buffet --- and boy, has it changed; and much for the better.The restaurant is still laid out as a buffet, but the food offerings now have a healthier Asian orientation instead of the usual roast beef, fried chicken and instant mashed potatoes, or the deep-fried foods at the Americanized chinese buffets. The sushi is not the most exotic I've ever had, but the selection is varied --- probably 10-15 different types of rolls --- kept chilled, and reasonably fresh. Well-prepared seafood dishes included three different sashimi offerings, fresh steamed flounder, shrimp prepared a half-dozen different ways (the coconut shrimp were especially good - of course it was; it was the one made with sugar, coconut milk and shredded coconut), steamed alaskan crab legs, very tender steamed mussels and clams, a couple of real crab dishes (no steamed blue crabs, however), and probably a half-dozen baked (not fried) fish dishes in different preparations. If you get past the seafood, there is a Hibachi grill station where a server lightly grills your meat, vegetable, noodle and spice selections for you, without soaking your food in oil in the process. In addition to the really good stuff, there's a nice selection of other vegetables and fresh fruit, plus a smaller selection of the more traditional Chinese items (including one dim sum offering, which was not done very well) for the take-out Chinese fans. And, if you're still hungry after all that, you can top off the meal with the usual little cakes, vanilla pudding and machine-made-right-before-your-eyes frozen yogurt for dessert. A dessert twist here is the addition of a chocolate fountain and fresh strawberries and other items to dip, which seemed to be especially popular with the kids. The only Asian food items that were noticably absent were all things Thai --- I surely could have eaten some steamed spring rolls, if they had been offered.The restaurant's servers and buffet table employees operate as a well-oiled machine, and keep your table, the buffet tables, the floors and everything else in the restaurat very clean and pleasant. No left-over plates on your table, constantly topped-off beverages, new silverware (or chopsticks) after every new plate if you want it, no dropped food or napkins left on the floors, and very little mess on the serving tables and around the food items (and there were a lot of kids there). And all of this order is being maintained while being very polite and attentive to customers. No light conversations and banter with the customers, like you might get from your server at a more expensive restaurant --- they're too busy for that at Yukai. But very professinal, pleasant and quick service from everyone we met at the restaurant.Our buffet frame of reference is a little limited these days, and the $13.95 price seemed very reasonable to us, given the variety and overall pretty good quality of the food offerings. If you're looking for a buffet experience with healthier, Asian food offerings in a very pleasant restaurant environment, give Yukai a try.

After seeing the way Hampton Roads-ians dress when I went to Wicked last week and then people watching at Vintage Kitchen, I really would like to start "What Not to Wear: Norfolk." All in all, I had a great time and will definitely return!

<review# 688,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/5/2012,12/25/2012,231,461,,7,1>I can't believe I have not written a review on this place yet. The bread.... THE BREAD! OMG. On that note, if you are a fan of Cuban sandwiches, try the Cubano. It is fantastic. Another great menu item is the roasted tomato bruschetta. The roasting of the tomato brings out the natural sweetness and gives it a nice, almost sauce like flavor. They serve it up on that delicious bread I happened to mention earlier. They make the best damn Margarita I have had. They also make some killer drinks with lychee. If you have not had lychee you are missing out. They make a puree that is used in the lychee drinks and it is absolutely amazing. They also have some beers here that I have never heard of that are great. They have a black ale that is killer. It looks like a porter, has a full bodied taste like a porter or stout but feels like any other golden ale when it goes down. I found it incredible to get that full bodied taste in a beer but not have it feel like I was eating my beer because it was so heavy.They have an in-house musician, Justin that plays piano. <review# 699,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,11/14/2012,12/14/2012,22,104,,7,2>I am now HAPPY to report that Thai is back on the menu!!! I admit it, I have been missing Thai food since my ol' favorite place was forced out due to renovations.   Located on Hampton Blvd near NIT, this is not necessarily a hot bed of culinary prowess.  This could change.  I saw the new sign go up a couple weeks ago for Thai Best Cuisine while I was going to enjoy one of my new favorite spots for Sushi, and now I know I have a new go-to spot to placate my pad-thai hunger, to quench my curry cravings, and satisfy my urge for Sum Tum that is yum yum!!!I admit, I immediately lowered my expectation because although clean, bright, and smelling great, it was basic wood table tops, straight back chairs,  and glass storefront with a view to the parking lot.  We had our choice of seating because with only 10-days under their belt, the word hasn't gotten out yet.  Once we sat down, we decided to go with our standard dishes so that we could truly test how they stacked up.  So, with an order of SumTum (spicy papaya salad), Chicken Pad Thai, SPICY Chicken Pad Thai, and Chicken Green Curry ordered, we waited.  During our respectably brief wait for food, the owner Pat, talked to us pleasantly and with a genuine sense of fun, it was refreshing.  Once our food arrived, it was a wonderful thing.  The SumTum was spot on.  Spicy, and fresh with the crisp crunch of freshly stringed Papya.  Spiced just right and a great start. The Pad Thai (both varieties) were soft, sweet, and flavor packed just like they should be.  The Green Curry was delicious. Again, freshness, and texture are important.  The coconut milk giving it that thicker-than-broth, creamy texture along with the perfect amount of spices over sticky rice.. oh, good grief, I get goose bumps.  I digress, sorry.  I really do recommend you hit this place because as long as this quality stays, you owe yourself the visit.  Good luck and happy eating!!!ADDENDUM!!! My one and only barely reasonable gripe was addressed beautifully.  The dining room is now pleasantly screened from staring folks on the sidewalk by tasteful decor, and I get that "private dining" feel that I love when I go to a place with such remarkable food.. and yes, the food was OH SO GOOD.  I will say it again, take the time, make the drive, you will be glad you did.  Hope to see you there!!!
