<review# 707,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,7/11/2012,12/6/2012,88,68,1,11,4>Never judge a book by it's cover. Or in this case a restaurant by it's exterior. Usually when you travel around a city looking for a good place to go to without any assistance from any one of numerous social media outlets or food reviews the first impression you get of a place is how it looks on the outside. Maybe it's the design of the building, it's size whether massive or "hole in the wall,"  or even the cool neon lit marquee with interesting color scheme that draws you in. Luckily, we do have the luxury of good friends, social media outlets, and food reviews to guide us in the right direction sometimes. Otherwise you might miss a place that offers a satisfying, flavorful, and enjoyable experience serving delicious Korean food like Asahi.I went here last night with my gf and two of my good friends to experience Asahi ("family" in Korean) for the first time. The outside of the restaurant has the name of the restaurant in "Oriental" style lettering and is located next to a small hole in the wall pizzeria.  The one window for the restaurant was covered with blinds so you couldn't see inside. Just a name and a door to walk through.Upon entering, the restaurant looks a little small with a small dining area to the right with about 6-7 booths and then another area to the left for large parties and karaoke which they also advertise.  There is also a small 5 seat area for the sushi bar.  The first thing we noticed when we got there was that the whiteboard had a special on Bulgogi Tacos and Lettuce Wraps with BBQ Pork Belly. While both caught my eye I definitely wanted some Pork Belly.We sat down and ordered and were greeted by the first of what would be two of our most friendly waitresses.  They welcomed us for our first time being there and took our drink orders to which we requested the Watermelon Soju we had seen so many raving reviews about.  She also served us a complementary "appetizer" of Korean Crackers which she described it may look like popcorn but is like the childhood favorite cereal Smacks.  Eagerly we dove in and picked a few pieces. It was ok to me, tasted chewy and stale with a slight hint of sweetness. Maybe that's the way they're supposed to taste. Then again I'm no Korean Cracker conniseur. I'll have to consult my friends across the water who live there about that one lol. As we anxiously awaited our drink, we took a look at the menu and it is true to form with Korean dishes true to the language and with descriptions.  We were also served "banchan" which are condiments meant to supplement the main dishes we were to order they were about 8 small dishes ranging from pickled radish, fried anchovies, kim chee, sesame bean sprouts, and kim chee infused cucumber to name a few. Then the Watermelon Soju came out and it was a presentation to say the least.  Soju is a national alcohol of Korea like Vodka is associated with Russians. Asahi's drink was mixed with the Watermelon and served in a hollowed half of watermelon complete with mini ladle and  2 inch tall skinny shot glasses around for the table.  The first thing everyone at the table thought was, "Why shot glasses?" Well it serves it's purpose as we found out you definitely need them to pace yourself as it's not a strong drink but tasty and a "creeper." by the end of the night. I think I might have had about 10 shot glasses worth by the end of the night.I decided to get an order of their Dol Sot Bi Bim Bap which is similar to Bi Bim Bap (White rice and Shredded Beef with Shredded Carrots, Cabbage, Greens, and Cucumber all topped with a Sunny Side Up egg and garnished with shredded seaweed). The big difference is the Dol Sot version is served in a super hot stone bowl which keeps the ingredients hot throughout the meal (and yes it keeps it burn your throat hot for about a good 10 minutes!)  It's served with a side of spicy sauce.  When the bowl arrived in front of me I was excited. I had only had this dish a few times before at Tasty Korean BBQ and wanted to see if the bowl did what the description stated (enhances the flavor of the ingredients). While it did just that I felt it was missing a bit of salt and thought it could have had a lot more beef to make it substantial. My gf got the Bulgogi which comes with onions and green onions (since my gf doesn't like onions they served it on the side). It was a healthy portion and luckily I was able to get some of that into my Bi Bim Bap.  Our friends got the Dol Sot Bi Bim Bap and the Galbi which are BBQ'd Short Ribs. Also a healthy portion and served with a side of rice.  See the photos for proof :) If there's one thing that people associate Korean BBQ with it's the beef and Asahi's is well cooked with a good balance of sweet, char, and soy which makes it addicting to eat.  While it may be off the beaten path for some it's definitely worth the visit. Don't be alarmed by the surroundings or you'll miss out on a good food experience!

<review# 720,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/15/2012,11/23/2012,83,62,2,7,4>I just got back from an incredible dining experience at this local eatery - some of the best Szechuan cuisine in the Hampton Roads area. I met up with my friend, Lorie, and she was excited because she heard Judy's served the "soup dumplings" that she traveled all the way to NYC for. I was merely excited to try out a new spot (Judy stated that she's only been open for six weeks). Walking in the place, I noticed it was a little bare - they haven't received their ABC license yet so the bar in the corner was empty. There were a couple of parties already dining but it wasn't busy. I was seated immediately by Judy and was served by Frieda. Both ladies were friendly and accommodating and were eager to make suggestions and explain the menu.Like Jade Villa, which is nearby, Judy's offers an American and a Chinese menu. But unlike Jade, its menu is different since Judy's offers Szechuan cuisine, as opposed to Jade's Cantonese. So if you're looking for dim sum here then you're out of luck. That may be a drawback for some, but Judy's offers some very delectable dishes that will make you forget about dim sum... at least while you're dining here.For anyone not in the know, General Tso's chicken ISN'T a Chinese dish. It's one of the many misnomers that Judy wants to tackle by serving what she knows and loves - true Szechuan food. Everything on the menu looked great and it took a lot for Lorie and I to not order the entire menu. But we settled on the beef noodle soup, onion pancakes, watercress in garlic sauce, and the aforementioned soup dumplings (i.e., xiao long bao).Every dish was amazing as they were full of flavor and delight. Both Judy and Frieda were quick to show us how to eat the dishes and provided small sample bowls of sauces that helped enhance the flavor of each. I can't thank them enough for their knowledge and their hospitality - it made an already pleasant dining experience even better. It's safe to say that I instantly love Judy's. Dining here would easily have you believe you're eating somewhere in China... or at least a spot off of Lexington Ave in NYC. If you're in the area and are craving some authentic Szechuan you don't need to take the Chinese bus like Lorie did... just head over to Pembroke!

To sum it up, it's the kind of place that makes look forward to getting pregnant and being able to  eat whatever you want, whenever you want it, without judgment. I will visit this place anytime I'm in the neighborhood.

<review# 737,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/5/2012,11/6/2012,122,469,,8,1>You know your husband loves you when he'll drive 30 minutes both ways in the rain for Indian food. I had a craving for it yesterday and heard about Monsoon recently so decided to give it a try. The owners are the same ones who own Saffron at the VB town center and Monsoon is located at the Peninsula town center. I know it's hard to review a place solely based on take out so I won't be taking service or ambiance into account but the food was pretty much amazing. We had the chili garlic naan with the mint raita, the assorted pakoras, the chicken vindaloo, and the blue crab curry, all served over jasmine rice. The entire meal from start to finish was mouth watering. The mint raita was nuts, so fresh and light, it provided a refreshing dip for the chili garlic naan. My husband's chicken vindaloo was very flavorful and full of indian heat. My blue crab curry had SO MUCH blue crab meat in it, we were both pleasantly surprised. Most places that have real crab meat skimp on it, but this dish was bursting with tons of shredded blue crab meat in every bite. My husband said it looked nice and very trendy inside, I really want to have the full experience next time. So because we didn't eat there I can't give it the full 5 stars but I do intend on updating once we return. Definitely add Monsoon to your list of new restaurants to try out. The peninsula is lucky to have a place like this and not another stupid chain.

<review# 739,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/29/2012,11/4/2012,84,331,,4,3>My coworker pretty much had a foodgasm eating one of their macarons today. I bought half a dozen for $7.50 in all the flavors available that day: dulce de leche, strawberry, coconut, and Nutella/expresso. The were generously sized and beautifully made. I only had the strawberry one and it was soft and delicious. I've had macarons in Paris and from some fancy store in New Orleans that was on Oprah...these were just as good. My coworkers eagerly help me eat the rest and all loved them. They came packaged in a box with ribbon and printed tissue paper inside - great for gifts. The place is very clean and modern looking (think white leather reclines) and service is super friendly.If you're coming just to buy macarons, recommend calling ahead...my previous 2 trips came out empty-handed and they don't really seem to have a set schedule for making them.

I am usually in the water and surfing before 5AM.  After I've had my fill and the barnies start showing up, I get out of the water but I don't want to be on the roads with all of that traffic.  I start feeling something deep...instinctive...a craving...a yearning within my soul.  I close my eyes and I can see her standing there.  Softly, Teddy Pendergrass starts filling in the scene..."Close the doorLet me give you what you've been waiting forBaby, I got so much love to giveAnd I want to give it all to you"...I open my mind's eye to a smell so rich and fragrant it encapsulates my entire being and I already know...I know that in front of me is something so good I can't go nowhere else ..."Close the doorLet me rub your back where you say it's soreCome on get closer and closer, so close to meLet's get lost in each other, come here baby"...BAM! <review# 741,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/19/2012,11/2/2012,74,230,3,6,5>I'll be honest, I am a simple man.  I don't know alot about alot of things.  But if there is one thing that I do know it's good Mexican food.  It's my favorite "genre" of food and when we moved to the Hampton Roads area almost two years ago to the date of this review, one of my first missions was to find a place that I could go for authentic Mexican food.  Two places fit the bill, this one and El Rey, but Jessy's is my favorite.  As many have said here, the guacamole is fresh and so tasty.  The tacos are just as you would want from a great taco, two corn tortillas, onions, cilantro and meat.   My favorite thing I have tried so far is the torta that has hot dogs, ham, eggs, and other things that I don't recall.  It's a strange concoction but seems to come together perfectly.  Though I haven't tried the horchata, a colleague of mine said it's as good as any he's ever had and the reviews here vouch for that.  Add on your bottle of Coke and you have yourself a great lunch or dinner spot.  In addition, they have a dessert case with items that look fantastic.  I haven't had any but might add that to my list of 'to try'.  They also do breakfast, which regrettably I haven't tried.  When you are done, go next door and pick up some pan dulce.  Typing this review is making me re-think my lunch plans tomorrow.  Perhaps Jessy's will be in order.  If you want great Mexican food , you cannot go wrong here.
<review# 742,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/6/2012,11/1/2012,263,519,4,10,10>Sacralicious Strikes Again!!!So we had ourselves a little UYE tonight at Woody McGee's Barstro... I can positively say that EVERYONE left here with a smile on their face and belly full of their bacon concoction of choice. Bacon you say? That's right! BACON! Because this was Woody McGee's 'Bacon Week 3.0'. What's Bacon Week? I'll tell you! It's a special menu full of apps, entree's, drinks and deserts made with everyone's favorite food. Bacon! Sacralicious indeed!!! So grab a piece of bacon, settle back and get ready for a long one.First off, we had a party of 7 tonight. John G and his wife Ashley, Julia A, Yajaida P and her husband, our local Yelp big wig Xerxes and myself. Each of us took a turn with the apps on the menu and we covered the spread.In no particular order:Bobo's Bacon Bundles - Homemade blueberry pork sausage stuffed bacon wrapped in jalapeno poppers with a Dr. Pepper reduction.Devil on Horseback - Dates stuffed with bacon goat cheese and wrapped in bacon with a mango-mint habanero chutney.Picked Cucumbers wrapped in Bacon & Beer Batter - Spears of pickles on a stick battered in PBR, then fried and served with BBQ sauce. We mixed, matched and compared, all were delicious. I also noticed down at the end of the table Yajaida P had a Bacon-Apple Martini on the table. I didn't try it but the ladies seemed to be enjoying it.Next up were the Entree's. I had the Cherry Coke Braised Pork Belly. This included 3 succulent slices of the pork, roasted potatoes and bacon sauteed spinach. D-Frickenlicous! I saw at least 2 other plates of this at the table as well. The pork was very very moist and easy to cut, I wouldn't call it falling off the bone, but it was pretty darn close if you know what I mean. The same goes for the bacon sauteed spinach. My God, who thought of this? They're excellent together!I noticed John G went with Bacon Wrapped Filet of Beef which also came with a corn from the cob bacon relish (which I sampled and was awesome) and some asparagus stalks with a crispy piece of bacon holding them together. That's for his review. Also on the table was the Bacon wrapped Shrimp over Crawfish dish and rounding it out Xerxes gave the 50/50 Burger a try Sacramento Style. I'm sure those reviews will be here shortly.Last but certainly not least were the deserts. I'm not much of a desert person normally but tonight was special. I split a desert with John and Ashley, and we selected the Whiskey, Marshmellow, Caramel & Chocolate Bacon Bark. I think the better way to describe this would be to call it the mutant bacon chocolate smore's bar from hell. Wow! Just Wow! You gotta try it. It was so good! Other desert items on the table were Maple Bacon Cheesecake and the Bacon Cinnamon Rolls (which I also sampled). All I'm going to say is think of a cinnamon roll with bacon wrapped up in the spiral... Yeah, I know... I see you salivating... What a night. I can't believe we all walked out under out on our own power. I thought for sure that there would be an ambulance before the night was over. In all seriousness. We had an incredible meal here, AGAIN, and the service, food, atmosphere was first class from start to finish. If you want to catch one of Woody McGee's Bacon Weeks or any other specials they run make sure you check out their Facebook page or you can sign up there for one of the Woody's cards which get's you something good once you get all your spots marked on it. I'm looking forward to my next visit already. Peace Out!
<review# 743,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/6/2012,10/31/2012,121,170,2,6,5>It was my first visit to Salvatore's; my co-worker, a trusted foodie, gave me the 411 and suggested I pay them a visit.  With a group of 4 in tow, I took her advice.Salvatore's was quite crowd, but it was Friday night.  Our group of 5 waited for about 20 minutes for a table...not bad.  We were finally seated after sitting in the front and drooling over the pizza, calzone, and other goodies in the front case.Garlic Knots came to the table first -- gratis!. This gave us a chance to peruse the menu.  Salvatore's has everything you can imagine -- pasta, pizza, calzone, stromboli, hot and cold sandwiches, salads, and so on.  We all went for something different and sampled each others dishes.I had the traditional spaghetti and meatball.  The meat balls were large and full of flavor.  The marinara sauce was amazing with chunks of tomato.  This was one of the better spaghetti and meatballs that I've had in a while. We also had the lasagna -- amazing -- layer after layer of pasta, ricotta, cheese, and meat sauce.  The eggplant parmigiana was just as good.At the end of the meal, I asked for an order of zeppoles.  The waiter promised enough for the table.  Imagine a sort of Italian churros -- deep fried, dusted with powdered sugar with both chocolate and strawberry syrups.  Fantastic!!I visited a second time.  Again, great food, great service, and a great experience.  The owner walks around and checks on each and every table  He always sends around 'amuse bouche' for the table to enjoy.  On my second visit, we had the garlic knots and some amazing bruschette.  The syrupy balsamic was the 'coup de gras'.If you want Italian, regardless of where you are, I recommend Salvatore's to you.  The food is great, the service is attentive, and the owner's prominence makes everything run like a finely tuned machine.

<review# 746,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/21/2012,10/28/2012,77,61,1,4,>Although I think the museum is a pretty cool draw in itself, I think the real star is the incredible Noland trail around the museum. It's a great workout, comprised of over 4 miles of ups and downs that can challenge about anyone. Compared to other trails, it's thoughtful that the folks who manage this trail clearly mark about every exposed root along the way. There is also a walking trail around the outside that is flatter, for walking, running, or biking, but I haven't traversed that from end to end.That all being said, whether you are active and want to enjoy the trail or path or are an inside/nautical person who wants to see the exhibits indoors, there is something here for everyone.

<review# 749,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/23/2012,10/25/2012,63,174,,7,4>After having Eurasia on our "We Gotta Get To This Place" list for over a year, we finally made it for an early dinner last Saturday, after an afternoon movie.  And it's been our loss during all that time that we put off going --- the place is an absolute gem.Located at one end of a nondescript strip mall on Laskin Road (the same mall as the new location for Heritage Natural Foods), Eurasia may be described as an American bistro, small plate wine bar, fusion cafe, or whatever term for a small, intimate cafe serving limited offerings of well-prepared dishes and wines that you're comfortable with.  The restaurant advertises the use of fresh, local ingredients as much as possible, and, after settling into one of their outside patio tables facing the parking lot, we certainly found that to be true with the dishes we tried.  Wonderful pan-seared scallops with a sweet balsamic reduction drizzle for my wife, served on a bed of soft creamed couscous with grilled leeks, and watercress for decoration; and novel "herbal" crab cakes for me, made with claw meat only and seasoned with basil, onion and tarragon, giving the dish a slightly bitter herbal taste.  The  cakes were served with steamed jasmine rice and crisp grilled chinese cabbage and julienne d carrots and celery, topped with an Asian drizzle reminiscent of a tart hoisin sauce.  We couldn't resist also adding their mac & cheese to our order --- here served with shaved truffles  --- and were impressed with the dish's creaminess, use of spiral-shaped elbow macaroni, and wonderfully blended multi-cheese flavors (I detected fontina, munster, mild cheddar and cream cheese, among others).  We both thought all our food was very well prepared, wonderfully different, and just fun to discover and enjoy.  Wine selections at Eurasia seemed a little limited, but they do have an arrangement with the wine shop next door wherein you're able to buy any favorite  you might have at the shop and the restaurant will then charge a corkage fee and serve it with your meal.  We stayed with the house choices, and my wife found a Reisling that was just a little sweet, and I a very good Pinot Noir.  Strangely, Virginia labels were almost totally absent.  And helping make the selection, delivery and enjoyment of all this yummy food happen was the friendly and very efficient assistance of our server Mark, who displayed  just the right combination of attention, knowledge about the food and drink offerings, and idle conversation and chatter.  So, now that we've finally made it here, we're kicking ourselves for having missed enjoying this place over the last year+.  A really great little spot to relax, enjoy a glass or two of wine, and experience some very pleasant surprises with wonderfully different food  preparations.
<review# 750,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/19/2012,10/24/2012,29,54,,8,2>This place is awesome. There are probably two actual healthy places to eat in the area that are quick. The whole place is up to date with huge screens displaying the juices/smoothies/lunch options. You even pay and sign on an ipad. They make FRESH juices and smoothies straight from the fruits/vegetables without any extra fillers. I had the beet juice with apple and something else. It was delicious. I also had a salad, which was great. They only use local/organic ingredients for the salads and wraps as well. This is a perfect place for a snack/lunch/brunch. I could probably eat there every day, but I would be broke. The only con is that it is expensive, but in order to get that fresh of produce, I guess that's how it goes. I will return many more times.
<review# 751,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/4/2012,10/23/2012,183,190,,14,4>The quintessential dining experience and nothing less.  This new hot spot is located next to One Fish, Two Fish right on the water--come by boat or car.  When you walk in, there is beautiful bar on the left  with comfy-cozy bar stools and a few cush bar tables.  The bar opens at 4 daily while the main restaurant is available starting at 5PM.  The main dining area is gorgeous and open.  I love the modern chic light fixtures and the attention to detail on this renovation of the previous La Marinella.  They have a lovely array of wine to start the evening off right.  The chef prides himself in trying to use local ingredients, including produce and freshly caught seafood for this Modern American menu.I was lucky enough try a whole spread of food--I went with about twenty people and, since they all know the foodie that I am, they were all kind enough to share with me.  I find it hard to name a favorite appetizer--I loved the flatbread with bubbly goat cheese, yellow & red tomatoes, and shrimp.  The tuna is nice and simple, diced into a generous bowl with a hint of arugula.  The clams and scallops are also highly recommended but I didn't get to try these yet--now on my to do list.Now on to the entrees.  Since eating here last night, I have not been able to stop thinking about the pork belly, which compliments the pork loin--this is definitely my favorite entree thus far, but I am a huge pork belly fan so perhaps I have some bias-LOL.  I had seen the menu ahead of time online, and knew instantly that I had to try the gnocchi (as I have appropriately nicknamed "Knock you socks off" gnocchi).  This gnocchi is homemade and baked with goat cheese, divine oyster mushrooms, olive oil, spinach, and yellow & red tomatoes to give it a real burst.  The crabcakes are lumptolumptuous and paired with coleslaw.  The shrimp are kickin with polenta (way better than shrimp & grits).  Our waiter said the salmon was his favorite--it looked gorgeous but I didn't get to try it myself.  Everyone that ordered the skirt steak or the Hereford beef tenderloin was well satiated. There is definitely something for everyone in your party.This place is perfect for groups, date night, or girls night out.  Just what Virginia Beach needed.
<review# 752,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/5/2012,10/22/2012,134,156,4,4,4>Oh yeah, this place is right up my alley, Organic Food Loving Hippies... I've been to Taste twice now and its been insanely packed each time; like to the point of being able to get sexual w/the person beside you. I'm not a fan of crowds either, but this place is awesome. The food is so fresh and honest. Yeah, honest, lol... just made that up. But you know how you eat something bad for you, and even though its good, you feel like shit (sort of like a one night stand), eating here gives you life, lol. You don't want to go home and take your lazy ass to bed, or sit in the chair for another 20 mins because you overate, you want to continue about your day. This is what food should be, it should give you energy, not take away from it. So I've only had two things thus far, the crab cake, which was amazing! No detectable filler, great portion size, and reasonably priced. The only negative is how it had no remoulade sauce. While the crab cake itself was really moist, the overall sandwich was faintly dry because it was essentially, lettuce, crab, and bread. Very delicious though.I also had the Princess Anne, which is a vegetarian sandwich. Veggie prudes will love this one... I thought it was excellent, although, the roasted bell pepper can make your bread a bit soggy if you don't eat it right away. Wasn't too happy w/that. The next time I'll definitely omit those. All in all, I love this place... Definitely plan on being a regular. They also have a cute little Wine of The Month Gathering, and a ton of expensive merchandise that you're still going to want to buy, despite the price.
<review# 753,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/19/2012,10/21/2012,12,61,,3,2>First Landing State Park has some of the BEST trails to hike/bike and run!  Since discovering this park in 2008 I've never been disappointed with my experience.  There are 3/4 different area's to explore including a new nature center when entering on the Shore Drive side.  People are always courteous and smile as you pass by.  The main trail has a few obstacle/workout stops that are perfect for a break from your jog/run or whatever your doing.  There's a beach (with parking) and tons of trails to explore!  Wild life includes turtles, birds and i've seen a few garden snakes but those are less frequent.  The park staff are always roaming the trails and some boy's scout groups have made bridges to cross some of the more frequently rain drenched areas.  All trails are mapped and distanced in the hand out and many maps located throughout the park.  The main trail has mile markers along it's course as well.  The shade is perfect and the atmosphere is just what the outdoor enthusiast is looking for.  Bottom line is that this State Park has just about everything your looking for for an outdoor experience.  Did i mention the Native American heritage trail including sites to view/enjoy/learn? yup they have that too..  See you on the trails!!!

<review# 756,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,8/5/2012,10/18/2012,14,98,2,2,1>The marketing director, Danielle, is a sweetheart. She accommodated my work group for an After Work Party and she made it happen. There's a guy and gal who seems to know all of the dance moves so this is great if you are wanting to learn how to line dance; but when you try to incorporate line dancing into something like "We Found Love" by Rihanna, you are taking it too far...very cheesy lol :)There is another regular, older lady with long blonde hair; she use to teach line dancing, she goes around dancing with a partner; I think she looks great, but she tends to not like it when it gets crowded on the dance floor; she purposely (as she was dancing 2 steps with her partner) bumped into people to give herself room; the look on her face, it was one of an annoyed dancer who couldnt get her dance-on because the place gets packed; my suggestion to her is...chill out, relax and enjoy what you can, you dont have to dominate the entire dance floor to have a good time. *winks*Overall, the place is fun to hang out; great for ladies night out, after work parties and social gatherings. Parking lot gets full and the party doesnt really get started till closer to 10. :)

<review# 758,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,9/16/2012,10/16/2012,464,705,4,7,2>What a rare little gem buried within the Virginia Beach Town Center. If you're driving past, you'll probably miss it. It would be a pity though because you've just passed the HR chocolate mecca.If Willy Wonka only made chocolate and had a candy store, then it would probably look like this place. Walk in and just breath the chocolate (and the calories!). The two ladies in charge travel all over looking for the best chocolates and bring it to your doorstep. Every month they have chocolate tastings so sign up quick! They have beautifully arranged display cases of all sorts of chocolates. Some are made in the store, others are imported. What's even better is that they have a sample of all the chocolates they had.I didn't know what I wanted. Actually, I walked in not wanting to buy anything since I have no self control around chocolate but they had a big box of samples that the owner pulled out and it was heaven. Bacon and chocolate, pepper and chocolate, hemp seeds and chocolate. You name it. I think what I learned tonight is that I'm a one eyed one horned spicy chocolate eater. One chocolate in particular was spicy and had pop rocks in it. Too bad they ran out because I would have bought it all!In addition to their premade chocolate delights, they also have a wide range of chocolate fondues, chocolate flavored drinks and fruits dipped in chocolate. Bring your friends for a fun late night snack. I'll be back!
<review# 759,isUSA=TRUE,3.0,9/4/2012,10/15/2012,99,254,,5,1>As the rating suggests, this place is A-OK. Our dining experience was uneven. A Box of Bocas will run a couple bucks...and is substantially cheaper than real steak. I felt punished for being vegetarian because they saved money on my dish but charged me more.- We ordered the tempura asparagus. Totally misleading. Overall, my visit was a little uneven. I'm going to go back and give it another chance, but as of right now, it just feels OK.

<review# 775,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/21/2012,9/29/2012,88,68,3,7,5>If you're looking for a place that serves food with great plate presentations in scarce amounts then El Desorden may not be the place for you. However, the counter to that style of food is enough to make you wanna lay back in your chair, enjoy a cold brew, and fall into a mini food coma before you feel the urgent need to find the comforts of your couch at home ASAP. Yes, El Desorden satisfies a need to be well fed with comfort foods and dishes from Columbia at a more than reasonable price.Located off of Newtown road in a shopping center right beside the local GranMart it's immediate location is right next to a pizzeria.  This now marks the second favorable review in a row I've done where a restaurant was located next to a pizzeria. Coincidence? Maybe not. It's a small location of about 12 to 14 tables and decked out in colorful tropical themed murals representative of the homeland. They also have a small bar area which also doubles as their pickup area for to-go orders.Having eaten here less than a handful of times (OK twice now!) I can say that I've had the same dish twice, a beef empanada to start and then the El Bandeja Paisa (#43 on the menu) Rice, Beans, Grilled Top Sirloin Steak, Homemade Sausage, Corn Cake, Sunny Side Up Egg, Avocado, Sweet Plantain and Thick Crispy Bacon. While El Desorden does offer several other specialty dishes I feel this one gives you the most bang for your buck for quantity and flavor.  The beef empanada is a great start because it's a nice size and has a nice crunch from the dough along with a flavorful filling.Everything on this dish works in harmony. The rice and beans are not an afterthought combination you may think of when you order it at a Mexican restaurant. Here there's something different and flavorful that brings it altogether with their well seasoned steak and sausage. The avocado is nice because it has a buttery texture that only adds to the richness of the entire dish and paired with the sunny side up egg which I cracked over my rice providing a "sauce" it makes for a true eating experience.  The plantain has a nice subtle sweetness which gives you a nice break from the salty, umami sensation you get from everything else. Last but not least the "Thick Crispy Bacon" is not your typical cut. In fact, you won't find it in any supermarket because it's essentially one thick cut of bacon (about an inch to an 1 1/2 inches thick!) and cut in such a way that you can enjoy it in bite size pieces.  ALL of this is served with a nice sauce on the side which is spicy yet citrusy. The service may be a tad slow than what I would like despite there being a few tables occupied during the lunch hour. Then again maybe the waitress was just giving my friend and I our space to enjoy the meal.  The only odd thing I can say about my second experience was that the sunny side up egg was cooked in such a way that the yolk was hard boiled. I'm still trying to figure that one out.Nonetheless, El Desorden has made the right impression on me about it's offering of Columbian dishes to the general public of Hampton Roads. Flavorful, made from scratch, down home cooking done well and in a place where shorts, t-shirt, and flip flops could well be considered a welcome dress code.  Just know there's a lot more to this country's cuisine than it's 100% coffee!
<review# 776,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,9/20/2012,9/28/2012,22,104,3,6,5>Man, talk about a surprise.  I had seen reviews raving about this place and didn't feel like cooking, so we decided to hit this local burger spot because of commentary and reviews.  It is SMALL, but great things come in small packages!  As you enter to order, there is a short counter with 4 stools, and a small 2-top... that's it.. SRO after that, and that is at a premium.  Chalkboard paint has made the place one continual menu board.  The kitchen area is definitely what got all the attention, as you can see the whole place along with your meals being prepared.  There is bottle beer in a glass front fridge,  as well as a small selection of tap beers (which I will address momentarily).   There is ample DOG FRIENDLY seating outside, so if you choose a day with nice weather, it is a clean, safe place to sit and enjoy some great food with your best friend at your side.  He also has plans to extend the outer awning, and install some TV's so that it can be a great place to tailgate, in a manner of speaking, and catch your favorite game.  I look forward to seeing that dream come to fruition.As small as this place is, you realize that Ron (the owner) loves him some HUGE game-day, All American (albeit internationally flavored) Burgers, Dogs, and a small assemblage of tasty sounding sides.  I settled on the Spicy Burger finally.  All the while, Ron is reminding me that his menu seems more suggestion than limitation.  You pick the burger and then customize it with anything you want that he has on hand.  I have had my share of kicked up burgers... topped, spiced, slathered, battered, but I have never had one with this much flavor punch.  Jalapenos, Gouda cheese, a spicy mayo, and fresh veggies was all I wanted.  I am telling you, that instead of the flavor being all toppings on just well prepared beef, this bad boy was packed with flavor in every morsel.  Also, this is no home style, 1/8th lbs shriveled burger, hidden in the bun.  These are what seem to be between 1/3rd to 1/2 lbs, and they carry that flavor beyond the edges of the bun to tease you even as you unwrap it.  I also ordered the fries and Onion Rings.  The fries were thick cut, just the way I like them.  Crispy, but not overdone and hollow.  The onions rings scared me.  He broke out a bag from the freezer.  Yes, they were frozen and prepackaged, and I was honestly afraid for a few minutes.  Although not that fresh crisp battered taste I love in a ring, I will say that he made a great choice from the supplier, they were surprisingly tasty.While there, I was talking and discussing beers and was shown that 2 of the 3 taps were O'Connors, a local brewer in downtown Norfolk.  He even allowed me a small sampling of the stout, and the IPA and I have to admit, I plan on spending a Sunday 1st half there for lunch in the very near future so I can give those more of my attention.  I am telling you, give it a shot, it will be worth the while to head here and grab some really great food.  Maybe I will see you there, because there is a lot of menu left to test!!

Hands down they have some of the best sushi in the area that you can find on a buffet. Good selection- mackerel, clam, white tuna, salmon and assorted rolls. Although I have no idea whats up with the orange roe on a pringle chip. They also have a great hot food area including a hibachi grill. I wind up putting away 4 plates of everything when I go here. Fatty paradise for Asian food.

<review# 787,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/7/2012,9/16/2012,30,51,,4,3>A girlfriend of mine didn't recommend this place at all and was very against going to Tida Thai in Newport News...but my husband and I decided to go anyways. I'm glad we did. From outside the place seems mediocre, but the inside ambiance was really nice. I always give extra kudos for places that has real candles and real flowers as a part of the decor. When you first walk in, you enter a small foyer which is pretty claustrophobic before you actually enter the restaurant. We had a new waitress waiting on us...she was a little clumsy, but I didn't really mind it. The place is pricey for Thai food. There are booths alongside the walls of the restaurant which gives a decent amount of privacy because the seats are high. My husband and I got the satay chicken (which comes with four skewers), the pad Thai with chicken (which is what I usually try first at Thai restaurants), and the pad saew with pork, and Thai fried rice or something with chicken. I've had my share of Thai food and have certain expectations...sooo, with that being said, I thought the satay chicken peanut sauce could be better. It ran a little bit on the watery or runny side. They definitely had a little too much coconut milk extract or something in there which made my throat hurt a little it. (I like to drownnn my chicken in the sauce because I LOVE peanut sauces.) The pad Thai was pretty good in my opinion. I was very satisfied with it. I really wished I had the shrimp pad Thai, but that would've jumped the price to like $15.00 or something ridiculous for pad Thai. The pad saew was alright. And the Thai fried rice was a small portion which I thought I could probably finish by myself. With all the dishes, the meat portions were pretty generous...it was like HUGE slices of meat. I personally don't like the huge slices...but what can I do? They also put a little orchid flower on our plates which I thought was cute and they have carrots garnished as a part of the presentation. As I said earlier, our waitress was a little clumsy and unknowledgeable of the dishes, but she was honest and I didn't really mind. There was also a miscommunication with me and another waiter I spoke to when I wanted to order sweet sticky rice WITHOUT the mango to go too. I ended up getting the mango and getting charged for an extra side of sticky rice. All in all, my husband and I spent $60.00 for our meal that night.
<review# 788,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/19/2012,9/15/2012,104,345,9,14,7>This restaurant just opened up in the space that used to house Conklin's Irish Rover before it died a quick and justifiable death last year.I was a little cautious about trying a new place on their opening weekend since it sometimes takes a while before a new restaurant hits its stride.  There was no need for caution here.  The restaurant was packed and the staff and kitchen were operating smoothly.  Very impressive.  They blow that God-awful Tapas joint by Regal Cinemas Strawbridge out of the water.I don't know who the chef is here but whoever he or she is, they are rocking out some righteous food.  Everything we tried was lick the plate delicious.  Mushroom and smoked gouda soup, she crab soup (with huge chunks of lump crabmeat), lobster rolls, crab fried rice, pulled pork egg rolls.  Even the fried doughnuts with raspberry, caramel and chocolate dipping sauces to end the meal were perfect.  The owners had better tie this chef down with a long-term contract.  This food is going to get noticed soon I'll bet.They have a very creative list of martinis but I always like to stick to the classics.  The bonus was that we were there during happy hour so I was paying just over $5 for my dirty martinis.  The usual price is $7 which I will gladly pay anytime.  But I do have to be a bit critical as they do not currently have Bombay Sapphire Gin (my fave!).  I had to settle for Tanqueray but I did notice a bottle of Hendricks on the shelf behind the bar after I placed the order with the waitress.  I hope they correct this discrepancy soon.  No martini bar should be in business that doesn't carry BSG.  It almost feels like a law is being broken.  If I see a bottle of BSG the next time I go I will raise this review up to five stars.Speaking of wait staff.  Holy eye candy, Batman!.  Every waitress is young and, um, shall we say...healthy in appearance?  Yeah, you get my drift.  And the fact that they were all wearing LBD's makes your martini drinking experience all the better.  But it isn't all about the looks.  These ladies were seriously efficient and kept the orders flowing out to the busy dining room.  The owners did a good job hiring their staff.Needless to say we will be returning.  The food, drinks and atmosphere are superb and the prices are incredibly reasonable for what you get.  This place is a gem.
<review# 789,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,8/12/2012,9/14/2012,11,54,,6,1>We were trying to go to "The Grace's Cantonese", but when we got there, we found that all the signs had changed. Judy, the extremely friendly new proprietor, told us she had bought out the restaurant after The Grace's closed, and opened Judy's about two weeks ago. Judy's had a huge menu full of authentic dishes you might run into in Beijing, as well as a few obligatory American-style favorites; she is hoping to introduce more authentic Chinese cuisine to the region, and wants to phase General Tso out entirely. She was more than happy to make recommendations if you are looking to learn some new dishes.We had two plates of dumplings, an order of stir-fried watercress, and an order of chicken with chilies, and of course rice, and it was a huge amount of food for three people. None of us could think of a single negative thing to say about any of the dishes; the watercress was flavorful and garlicky, and the chicken was crisp and spicy.We went at 2pm, so the restaurant was emptying out. We found service to be prompt and our food came within 15 minutes, but it might have been slower if the place was busier. Judy dropped by several times to check on us and to chat.In terms of appearance, the restaurant was more function than form; a few pieces of generic-looking art on the walls and two-dozen or so small tables set around the room. Still, everything was well-kept and clean, and it was a comfortable space to hang out for lunch. Judy's had plenty of floor space for large groups, although some tables would have to be shuffled a bit. They don't yet have their ABC license ready, though.I'm sad to see The Grace's go, but Judy's was really a very pleasant surprise. We'll definitely be back again. It's really hard to find authentic Chinese food in Hampton Roads, and I think this place really adds something to our local foodie scene.

<review# 796,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/6/2012,9/7/2012,18,133,,3,3>Pelon's is a California-mexican style restaurant that looks like a chain but has the feel of an independently owned shop (which I think it pretty much is). I say 'California style' being a native Californian, where mexican restaurants are a dime a dozen. There are two things that keep me coming back (even in the world of a Colley Chipotle): The customer service and the food quality.Every time I've eaten here, the waitresses/cashiers have been extremely friendly and are always working hard both around the restaurant as well as behind the register. I was concerned about this restaurant's well-being after the Chipotle conglomerate entered the neighborhood (which I like too by the way), but they said they had no change in sales! It made me think of 'You've Got Mail' when the book superstore opened and the 'shop around the corner' was in denial about their dwindling business...but I sincerely hope they live long and prosper. The food here has always tasted both fresh and been of perfect quantity. I usually get a burrito, but I've also tried the soups, quesadillas, chips/salsa, and tacos and they were all good as well! I never leave hungry (but I also never leave with leftovers...for those who like leftovers this might not be a great thing). They have PLENTY of vegan/vegetarian options for you non-carnivores in the crowd. For those that like alcohol, they have it here -- Which you might need to drown your sorrows if you don't eat meat.One complain I have that loses a star for me is the value of the food here. While, again, everything is of great quality, I always leave feeling like paid $2-3 more than I would have liked for what I received. Maybe I'm spoiled by my cheap California mexican restaurants, but if they even just included chips with larger entrees I would be much more satisfied with the prices. Although, I would be remiss if I did not mentioned that on Tuesdays they have a free BIG brownie with entrees+drink :). They also have many deals during the week, so check the website!Bottom line: If you like mexican food that isn't from a chain but is of great quality and in a comfortable atmosphere, this is the place to go! Prices are slightly more than you'd expect, but what's a couple extra bucks for good service??

The best part? Little bits of crackling pork skin were mixed into every bite! The textures and tastes of crunchy, spicy, and tangy were dead-on, and it was fantastic mixed into my white rice. Lumpia is made to order and in our excitement to eat them, totally forgot that "made to order" also meant "straight out of the fryer". Rookie mistake. Once our mouths (and the lumpia) cooled down, the Man declared them to be the BEST EVER! They looked like regular lumpia, smelled like  regular lumpia, but these must've been magical lumpia because an order of 6 magically disappeared in about 2 minutes. Everything can be ordered as part of a combo plate, or in 3 different sized containers. The amount of food for the price was really good.  Saw tons of take out customers and grabbed an impressively robust menu to take home with us to decipher what some of the other dishes were called.It's not too often we run across food we haven't tried before, and we're glad we stopped. Mmmmmm Sisig...

We were easily able to find five seats together at the bar on a Saturday night around 7 so I would probably even forgo table reservations and opt for the bar. Although I will say this, the tables overlook the inlet and provide for such a great view (even better than Lynnhaven Fish House) it makes me want to come back for a long lunch with the hubs. They ALSO have a huge outdoor patio right on the water too so there really isn't a bad seat in the house. Have I mentioned yet that I'm impressed?And now the food. I started out with the caprese salad, which was served proper with large basil leaves and stacked with buffalo mozzarella. So good. Their wine/glass list is very selective and they had my unoaked chardonnay for $8/glass, what more could you want? I went back and forth on my entree but ultimately decided on the brie stuffed tenderloin. I know I know, steak at a seafood place but BRIE STUFFED FILET!? Are you kidding me? And it did not dissapoint, cooked perfectly Medium as requested, with a side of new carrots and mash (see picture). DELICIOUS. I was considering the flourless chocolate torte for dessert but opted to drink my dessert instead with their espresso martini (see picture). Everything about this meal was heaven and they had everything that I love (espresso martinis, unoaked chardonnays, filets, CHEESE). I'm coming back, for sure, and drinking A LOT of wine and ordering the fresh catch and sitting outside. Very. Impressed.
<review# 809,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/22/2012,8/25/2012,74,230,4,7,4>We recently saw this place while dining down the way at Brother's but it was after closing time, so we didn't have a chance to stop in and check it out.  However, I was looking for a gift for my wife and who doesn't love chocolate?  So, I made the trip over to Schakolad.  What I saw when I walked in was beyond my expectations.  They had two full cases of various chocolates that they make in house.  It was overwhelming at first to figure out what I might want to get for the gift.  I was actually given a number of customization options to create my own gift and really personalize it.  That was the real draw.  I know I could have gone to any supermarket and picked up some turtles or Ghirardelli squares and probably been in good shape because those are good.  However, coming here gave me the chance to pick a number of options that I know my wife liked rather than sticking with one or two types of candies.  I ended up going with some turtles, sea salt caramels with milk chocolate, almond and pecan clusters, and others that I cannot recall at the moment.  You just tell them what you want and they load it into the box until its full of yummy candies!  And, they are very good.  We really liked everything we tried.  And, while I was in the store, I was given several samples as I asked about a certain item.  It was a nice touch to be able to try it before buying.  I knew it would be a hit when I got home and it was!The candy is fairly pricey so as Eric C. said, it's not something I would do regularly.  But, the personalization and service in store makes it a great option if you need to impress someone with a nice gift of chocolate.  For the cost conscious, they have daily 'dollar deals' that give you the chance to try their chocolate on the cheap.  On the day I went in, they had chocolate covered pretzels for a buck.  Nice!  I think strawberries are on the dollar deal list so definitely contact them to find out the specifics.  Just be warned, if you go in for just a little bit you will be hard pressed to not walk out with more than you planned.  You just get sucked into a chocolate trap......and that's a good thing!
<review# 810,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/4/2012,8/24/2012,121,170,2,8,3>I was excited when I learned that there was an artisan bakery in the area.  I use the Midtown Tunnel daily and thought the proximity of this bakery to my workplace would shine a little extra light on my mornings.  For the most part, it did, but I think Artisans Bakery & Cafe can be so much more.The bakery itself is in an old, almost Victorian, house that has been completely refurbished.  Yes, it's Olde Towne Portsmouth, but is reminiscence of some of the houses you might find in Olde Town Alexandria, with many of them becoming cafes and shops, as well .I have been to Artisans about 5 times and each experience has been different.  I really want to see some consistency, however.On the first few occasions, I had the scones -- large, but more biscuit-like and less buttery like the usual scone.  They are less sweet than most, I like that part, and a good accompaniment to a nice cup of morning joe.On another occasion, I had the chocolate-dipped eclairs.  They were heaven, but a bit petite.  The Chou was nicely done and the creme filling was fantastic.  I would go for those again in a heartbeat.Truth be known, I go to Artisans for the bread.  I lived abroad where bread is king. And there I fell in love with bread. Everyday, Artisans has a selection of breads on the menu.  You can find the baguettes there daily, however.  All of the breads that I've tried have been fantastic.  I usually buy the baguettes in pairs, just to have them on hand at all times.  I had the sourdough once -- also great -- nice crust and a fantastic chew. Strangely enough, the sourdoughs were all different sizes; it was as if they were just pull from the mother-dough and kneaded without portioning first.  This is one of inconsistencies that I worry about. My advice, go for the big one!Artisans, I guess, recently changed their hours of operation.  I was there earlier in the week and the billboard out front said that they were open from 11 - 3; I didn't actually pay attention to that until I left.  I was, informed, of that because I arrived a bit early. I wasn't happy about that because I usually go at 7.30 before hitting the Midtown.  I think the hours are earlier on Friday and Saturday.In addition to the hours changing, the bread always seem to be coming from the kitchen later than expected.  I was there when they opened on several occasions and there were only baguettes to be had.  So, go later in the day if you want some of the delectable breads.I really love Artisans and want them to succeed; I hope they are not suffering from a lack of business and that's the reason for the  hours of operation adjustment.  I hope that this review will bring a little more business their way.  Even with their inconsistencies, I think they deserve a 4 star rating for their service and, of course, the product.  Meanwhile, I hope they continue to work out the kinks because they have become my 'go to' place for artisan bread in HR and I would hate to see them close shop.
<review# 811,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,7/22/2012,8/23/2012,263,519,2,10,8>One 'Food Coma" wasn't enough. I had to do it again... On my second visit to the County Grill five of the people from my first visit were in attendance. This was a birthday dinner of sorts and everyone ordered something different from the previous visit, so I have a lot more pictures to show you at the end of the review. On this visit we were seated in the bar at a round top table under the giant elk head on the wall. We started off with 2 appetizers as well as an endless supply of mini corn bread biscuits. The apps were Wings and Potato Boats. Both of these apps are unique and have a County Grill twist on them. The wings are smoked, grilled and then doused in the house buffalo wing sauce. The taste is truly unique and they are one of kind and excellent. The same goes for the Potato Boats. These are potato skins on roids. They start out with the same basis, bacon, green onion, cheddar cheese but then the CG adds smoked BBQ beans & smoked beef brisket to the mix. You could make a meal out of these alone. So good.... Now for the entree's. If you read my reviews you know I'm a burger guy, so I went for the County Grill Burger. Good lord CG delivers. This includes a pit grilled burger basted with the house BBQ sauce & topped with smoked bacon, cheddar cheese and fresh mushrooms. The crinkle cut fries come on the side in a mini fry basket and house slaw. This burger is gigantic and delicious. Very cool and darned filling to say the least.Other entree's at the table included the Cape Cobb Salad which includes BBQ skewered shrimp. A large Ribeye steak platter w/ baked potato. Smokehouse Quesadillas (which are an app but big enough to be a meal) and a BBQ Combo which includes pulled pork, beef brisket and smoked chicken breast.Everyone loved their food and the portions are huge. Most of us took food home. If you want some darn find southern home cooking you need to try this place out. Skip lunch that day and bring an appetite. You won't regret it.

<review# 815,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,3/4/2012,8/19/2012,103,96,1,22,3>In the Hampton Roads area there are plenty of piercing and tattoo parlors, but none compare to Virginia Beach Ink.  The problem that I have run into in most of the piercing and tattoo parlors in this area is the attitude of the staff.  I've seen so many tattoo artists, piercers and front desk staff act like they are holier than thou because they work in a tattoo parlor.  Well let me say that Virginia Beach Ink's staff is NOTHING like that.  Everyone that I have talked to that works there is awesome!  They are all very friendly and knowledgeable.  They will talk to you if you have questions about your tattoo or piercing and they seem to treat you like an actual client rather than cattle they are trying to quickly brand so they can move onto the next one.  Their prices are reasonable and their work is quality work.  Since they have opened and I got pierced by Shimp I will never get pierced at another place!!  They ROCK!!!
<review# 816,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,4/21/2012,8/18/2012,63,174,,5,2>Bubba's is one of two or three Virginia Beach Shore Drive restaurants that are consistently on the Local's Favorites list for fresh local seafood, and they're probably the best spot in town for fresh crab and crab dishes. It's a small, unpretentious place right on the water on the inland side of Lynnhaven Inlet, with a boat ramp on one side and the Virginia Pilot's Association boathouse on the other. Hard to find a more pleasant and nautical location for a restaurant! Given it's location, the seafood is always right off the boat --- literally. Bubba's doesn't try to get fancy with preparation --- thank goodness --- just well prepared fresh seafood, broiled, fried or blackened (sometimes) and no fancy sauces or toppings. Their sides are equally basic, but very good. I especially love their coleslaw; the cabbage is only shredded and made into slaw when the order is received in the kitchen.The only downside to Bubba's is that the kitchen is small, and you can wait a while for your food if you're there on a Friday or Saturday. Mid-week early evenings seems to be the best for service, although the waitstaff is always pleasant, no matter how long the wait for food. I never tire of the scenery out the restaurant window --- or on the patio when it's warm enough --- so a wait here for food is among the most pleasant of any restaurant in town. All in all, one of my two most favorite places for fresh seafood and crab in Va Beach. A lot like most Va Beach seafood restaurants used to be in the 50's and '60's --- except that you can no longer get away with throwing crab and shrimp shells on the floor.

<review# 835,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,12/13/2011,7/29/2012,220,185,,2,2>Expensive yes.  Great quality and taste...heck yeah!  This is our lunch date spot and you can tell by the clientele that it ain't Panera.  The bread is fresh and the sandwiches are usually stuffed...and completely fresh.  Our favorite is the Princess Anne (which is vegetarian) but we'll add chicken or smoke turkey.  It's redunk.  The roasted red pepper aioli is so good.  I'm normally not hot on mayo or mayo-type sauces...and definitely not a lot of it if it's on my food.  However, they are super generous with the aioli and you'll hear no complaints from this girl.Most of the sandwiches are winners.  I've had the crab sandwich and pannini and both kind of left me wanting more.  I'm a MD native so crab cakes are in my blood.  The Son ordered the cheese pannini and we were a bit disappointed after waiting forever and the sandwich was barely hot...the cheese wasn't even melted.The gelato selection is from Melt and not too shabby.  We love the variety of snacks they offer.  Haven't tried any of the baked goods.  We did try one of the dinners for of our our lunches (some coated baked chicken breast) and were a bit disappointed.  However, the ribs looked redunk and had us drooling over them.Again, these are pricey sandwiches but well worth it for us.  Plus the VIP program is a nice incentive (although I wish they offered it to be used at all the locations instead of building up your purchases at only once location...you get enrolled in a separate account at each location).

<review# 840,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/15/2012,7/24/2012,29,248,6,11,4>Yay , im a fan is right!  So, coming from a brown person, this place is legit!Im very skeptical of indian restaurants- im used to 7/10 making a batch of "curry" and serving that gravy with everything, so, at these places- Paneer Tikka masala has the same sauce as chicken tikka masala. Then, they add some butter to it and then make it butter chicken.- Very low, very cheap.  This is NOT ONE OF THESE PLACES. So, im happy and im a fan!Food- very good! I went there a few weeks ago, but i can still remember our order- chicken tikka masala and butter chicken, yum! Food here is made to your level of spiciness ( is that even a word?)- the server will ask you if you want it - mild, medium or hot. Many indian food virgins dont realize that they can alter the hotness to their taste. Service- Average. Ive been there twice- first time it was phenomenal, second time, kinda scant. Even though our waiter sometimes was out of sight, i could always grab someone else to help, so it wasn't too shabby. Menus were well written- they have the generic indian dishes and dishes are explained pretty well. Food is standard prices for and indian place $$- so cant complain too much there.Decor- Very pretty. It has a nice indian rainforest theme going. The hostess is dressed very elegant in indian clothes- it looks like shes going to a wedding, everyday. I also appreciated the cleanliness. Oh, yes, i did notice something ( cause im nosy like that). I saw a waiter drop something into a plate he was carrying ( this was while he was coming out of the kitchen). He instantly put that plate aside, went in, and bought the guy a fresh new one. This was important to me because no one was watching, he did it all on his own, which is definitely noteworthy in my book :) So, coming from NJ, a state filled with brown people, i can say that Monsoon surpasses tons of places ive been to! It is most definitely worth the visit!

<review# 843,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,6/28/2012,7/21/2012,88,68,,5,5>It's a different vibe when you arrive at the Public House. The restaurant is located where the old Magnolia Restaurant on Colley Avenue in Norfolk.  When you enter through the doors of Public House you'll notice the host/hostess station on your right and then the massive amount of space in front of you decked out in wooden flooring with a few barrels spaced out to place drinks for a standing room only crowd.  My first thought is that I like the idea that there is an open space with just enough tables to have those who want to enjoy a sit down dinner. Billing itself as a gastropub the space opens itself up for people getting off work to enjoy a cold one or a nice cocktail to unwind and possibly share some small talk about work gripes, sports team bragging rights, or just some comic relief.  The specials are written on a chalkboard and upon your first visit you may need to look around the room to find them.  They also have a beer list on a chalkboard with their unique selection of lagers and ales.  As you head further to the back into the other space they have in the restaurant you'll find a few pool tables and another bar area for smoking patrons. A unique layout that works and I haven't seen anywhere else in Hampton Roads.The menu at Public House is an offering of classic favorites with a different spin. Childhood favorites like tater tots get a new look as Bacon Wrapped Tater Tots made daily served with a Chipotle Ketchup dipping sauce.  Some of their other offerings include your choice between Blue Collar or White Collar Mac & Cheese with your choice of toppings like Chicken, Bangers (Sausage), and Fried Shrimp to name a few.  My favorite so far is the Braised Boneless Short Rib with Mashed Potatoes, Asparagus and a Parmesan Crisp. It was so flavorful and tender and the presentation was very nice for only $15.  I've also had for dessert their take on a Moon Pie which is more than enough for 2 people let alone one.  They make it with homemade chocolate chip cookies dipped in chocolate and with marshmallow fluff and it is everything you'd want in a Moon Pie and more.The things I like about Public House are that it's whimsical in it's menu/bar offerings yet delivers on taste with generous portions. The staff are characters there that embody the idea the restaurant is trying to present which I see as laid back, not pretentious and easy going with just enough edge to make it stand out.   It can even be seen in their bathrooms with some of their "artwork." Take a look for yourself, you'll be quite amused.  Thank you Public House for making food we know and have grown up eating that much better with a playful creativity and good flavor!
<review# 844,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,2/27/2012,7/19/2012,46,196,,5,2>I had some extra time this morning, and an empty stomach, so I pulled out my iphone and yelped breakfast.  This place came up and I was a mile away.  I will pass up a fast food joint in second to support a locally owned venue.  I was alone so sat at the counter with a perfect view of the kitchen right in front of me.  I ordered water, 2 poached eggs and an english muffin ($3.29 total).  As much as I want to give this place 5 star, I can't.  I watched oatmeal made with fast cooking Quaker and boiled water.  I would have rather seen steel cut oats (which take a very long time but taste better).  I would have preferred to see my poached eggs cooked in vinegar laced boiling water.  They were made in one of those little pans you put water in and top with the insert to drop the egg in, therefore it's steamed eggs not poached.  All that aside it's a good, made to order, inexpensive meal.  AND, it's local, which gave it 4 rather than 3 stars.  Keep these guys in business.

<review# 848,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/28/2012,7/15/2012,21,104,,1,1>I've eaten lunch at Sorabol a few times with my husband and friends.  The restaurant has never been super busy the days I've gone.  Their lunch menu items were all under $10 (mostly $7.95) and had a decent variety of Korean dishes.  Their kimchi jjigae and sundubu jjigae (kimchi and tofu soups, respectively) were generous and well seasoned, but were both boiling hot to the point that I burned my tongue.  Their complimentary banchan (side dishes) were tasty...definitely better than other local Korean places I've checked out.  I haven't ordered any Korean meat dishes so I can't comment on those, but everything else we've ordered has been good.I've had the same waitress every time, and she's very friendly.  The decor and ambiance are a little dated but fine, and the bathrooms are clean.  Sorabol is on my list of regular lunch destinations.

<review# 858,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,1/25/2012,7/4/2012,2,15,,3,3>Amazing restored theater from 1945. I love the comfortable seating and private tables where you phone in your food order from your table. This truly is a Gem of Old Town Portsmouth. The movie 35MM screen is a huge 41 foot wide and the THX sound system is outstanding.   The food is decent but for the overall experience it is one of the most amazing movie venues you will see in North America. You will need to get to the theater early to purchase seats and than return later that evening for the show which really is the only inconvenience.    This is not a multiplex so only one Movie is showing at the theater. There are a number of cool old shops on the street the Commodore is located and nice old Churches and other architectural buildings of Old P-Town. Hope you enjoy this venue as much as we have each time.

<review# 865,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/26/2012,6/27/2012,61,127,,10,4>I couldn't be more excited about Fruitive! This is exactly what Va Bch needs- healthy food to go. They have a small bar & a few tables (indoor & outdoor) for dine in, but it's primarily to-go. It's not as quick as a fast food restaurant, but anything worth eating takes a bit more time. At Fruitive they have healthy smoothies (not the crappy fake fruit ones like other restaurants), juices, salads, acai bowls, wraps, & sandwiches. <review# 868,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,6/15/2012,6/24/2012,15,43,,2,2>Mmmmmm...baseball. I dare say, at the risk of being trampled on, that my experiences here have been more enjoyable than my first class seats at any of the major league parks I have been to...and as a previous season ticket holder that says ALOT!! First off...where else can you get the best seats in the house for $12-15? Seriously...second row...I could chat with the players if I wanted to. I personally feel that the minor leagues often offers better ball than the majors since these guys are fighting for something, so I won't review anymore on that. In all my time going to games, I have never had an usher offer to wipe off my seat, or offer me sunblock, until I came here. I believe my usher's name was Art, but I will double check tomorrow and update, since I will yet again be back. Before tonight, I had only been to one game since we just moved here, but Art remembered me (really?? One guest out of 8000++??). I even said this to him tonight...I have never has such great customer service at a ball park!!  I ran up in between innings to grab a cup-o-wine (which comes in two sizes!), and waited to return to my seat at a break. I was informed that that wasn't necessary here, versus the big leagues, but I did anyways. And this may seem like a silly point, unless you have lived in Cali, but the vendors DO come down to the seats offereing beer. That is a plus if you have ever been to an Angels game...booooooo. Now, if you are going to complain about the price of food or drinks, then bring your own, because it seem that here you can. Yes, alcoholic beverages are in the $5.50-10 range, on par with the majors, but nobody is forcing you to drink! You are getting  cheap seat goodiness, big league-like playing (yes, you will see Miguel Tejada and like players), friendly employees...so suck up the price of stuff! And come on guys...tip them! They are doing you a service...you don't NEED that pretzel...the poor guys is sweating his butt off over charcoal! Give him a dollar!

<review# 874,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/21/2012,6/18/2012,29,127,2,4,3>I have a huge soft spot for this place. My entire family practically worked here (Mom as a guide, Aunt in the admin office, Grandma in the restaurant) way back in the day so I spent a good chunk of my childhood in this place.It is truly beautiful here and very peaceful. I'm sure that other botanical gardens are probably more impressive, but I'm a Norfolk kid and I love this place. This is one of Norfolk's true treasures.Their butterfly garden is awesome... they literally land right on you!They offer tons of classes and workshops in addition to a children's camp in the summer that gives them something fun to do while also learning about nature. They usually open little exhibits here and there during the summer months also (Storybook Houses and Themed Playgrounds). They host the Azalea Festival which is a big deal in Norfolk! During the winter, the Garden of Lights is a very entertaining and of course a tradition for most locals!An awesome place to bike, walk, picnic, bring the kids or go on a date! :)

<review# 880,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,2/10/2012,6/12/2012,134,156,,7,2>There aren't many tobacco shops in Virginia Beach, especially ones dedicated solely to the sale of cigars! Emerson's has an incredible selection of smokes and accessories, all of which are more than reasonably priced. I honestly don't see the markup here. They do a phenomenal job of pricing and selecting the merchandise. The walk in humidor is stocked with a range of cigars covering all price points... they also regularly mark down cigars so there's always some type of sale going on. The premium cigars boast the most impressive price tag, certainly some of the cheapest I've ever seen. Humidification is on point too--right at that sweet spot where they're not too dry but not too moist either. Directly to the back of the shop is a lounge area. Seating about 7 - 10 people comfortably, this little haven offers a nice size flat screen and a wi-fi hot spot! The store itself is actually pretty big too, so there's more than enough room to smoke while viewing the products in the shop... no smoking in the humidor though (just to clarify because some shops/bars are ok with it). Customer service was great. I went in looking for the Xikar desktop lighter which they were out of, but they did check their other locations. Though they didn't have it I was referred to their website which is very informative. Aside from the sale of tobacco and accessories, they also offered amazing deals similar to those in the store. You can also stay up to date on various events throughout the year. With several different locations all throughout the Hampton Roads area, I plan to check out all of their locations. Hopefully they only get better.

<review# 897,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/19/2012,5/25/2012,12,61,,1,1>When it comes to Sushi you have got to try Ninja.. I've been to about 3/4 of the Sushi joint's around the greater Hampton roads area and this one, while seemingly small, packs great service, delicious sushi and a welcome atmosphere.  This was my first trip to Ninja (and def not my last) - the hospitality of the staff was excellent! the sushi chef greeted me and presented me with a complimentary 2-pc roll atop a small lettuce bed topped with spicy sauce and packed with delicious ingredients.  As most know, when presented with the Chef's specialty roll you do not question the contents, you merely enjoy the taste.  They have a full bar and beers on tap, i had the Shock Top with traditional orange.  For sushi i enjoyed 2 rolls - Rock & Roll and Earthquake.  Both served quickly and adorned with a display on each that complemented the sushi it's self.  Overall Ninja Sushi (tucked in the corner of the Harbor View area shopping complex) is my 2nd favorite place to quench my sushi appetite.  Very highly recommended for lunch or dinner.  They also have Teppanyaki/Hibachi style dining located on the opposite end of the restaurant which seemed to be an exciting show.  I'll definitely be back to visit Ninja in Harbor View!!

They were totally packed. Every table was full, and there were a few people waiting to be seated.  I think that was due to the recent Groupon, and the 25 cent beers.  But even still, the service was really fast.  Food was rolling out of the kitchen without much of a wait at all. It was very close to a 5 star review for me.  If I go back again and have the same great experience, I will definitely upgrade the rating.

<review# 905,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/9/2012,5/15/2012,6,16,,2,2>Taste is a local treasure and a gourmet's paradise. It is a market-deli with sophisticated offerings and a casual atmosphere. Take-out, eat-in, and food and drink for entertaining.Since they've moved into the old Bazemores' market on Hampton Boulevard (from the Ghent location), they've expanded their menu, grocery selections, deli offerings, and so much more. They've also included enough tables to accommodate the large number of patrons who want to dine in.The food is delicious and the menu selections are original and tailored to the local vibe. Each of the menu items are named for local neighborhoods and well-known areas. They offer fairly regular wine-tastings, feature local artists' work, and include various local goods in their shop (beer, meat, gelato, pastries and cakes, etc.). The House dressing is one of Taste's original masterpieces and a required substitute for mustard or mayo on your first visit. The "Pair Two" option is a great way to sample a couple items and narrow down a daunting menu on your first visit, as well. Everything here is pricey, and you can expect to wait a bit for your lunch to be prepared, but you're paying for something special.
