<review# 908,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,5/9/2012,5/12/2012,6,7,8,10,7>For years, ( YEARS! ), I've been complaining to my wife that we hadn't found a truly good coffee shop in Hampton Roads. Though I happen to be the true coffee lover in our marriage, I mostly just complained about the lack of good coffee shops, whereas Emily, in typical fashion, actually decided to do something about it and found out about Cafe Stella, so we decided to come check it out on a Saturday, and it did not disappoint. I have a "mild" caffeine addiction and a strong appreciation for a good cuppa joe. I drink strong black coffee, drip and/or Americano, about 24-32 oz/day, with maybe a touch of sugar and NO milk or cream or other bull-crap, and I drink it for the caffeine, the aroma and the taste. As an experimental nuclear physicist, my work requires 100% mental exertion 99% of the time and occasional night shifts, so at any given instant, my blood coffee content is well over the legal limit, if there were such a thing. It is in this context that you should interpret my review of Cafe Stella. On my first visit to Cafe Stella with my wife and her mother, I decided to go with a standard cup of drip coffee, because a) that is what I always drink and b) if a coffee joint can't be bothered to make a good standard drip cup, why should I take anything else that they do seriously? Well, of all the coffees to which my life's trajectory has led in the past 10 years or so, I distinctly remember approximately 3-4 places; Bosworth's in building 7 on the campus of MIT, Four Beans in Batavia, IL, a joint whose name I can't remember in Salt Lake City, and almost every cup of coffee I had in Seattle. I can now unequivocally state that Cafe Stella will be among the handful of great coffee experiences that I remember 10 years from now. I will not attempt to describe in words the quality of the roast and the brew of the cup(s) of coffee I had on my first of many visits to Cafe Stella. I will simply let our collective reaction to the quality of this coffee do the talking:1) We immediately decided to buy two cans of whole beans; the owner was highly enthusiastic about his offerings and allowed us to "smell test" each roast; all were excellent. 2) Cafe Stella's beans immediately replaced what we were drinking at home.3) We immediately bought a Krups burr grinder and started storing the whole beans in sealed airtight containers in the dark, grinding exactly enough for each pot we brewed just before brewing. 4) Emily, who was not a regular coffee drinker before, now looks forward to the freshly-ground, freshly-brewed coffee from Cafe Stella every morning, elevating her love of coffee to almost the same level as mine. Finally, I must note that the solitary one-star review below actually reflects positively on Cafe Stella, because it shows that Cafe Stella doesn't feel the need to pander to the lowest common denominator of customer that treats the coffee shop as low-rent office space by spending only a few bucks or worse while occupying the space all day. Moreover, Emily has gone back several times to buy more beans and try more drinks (and food) has been nothing but thrilled by the level of attention and service and macaroons she received. So in summary, you should respect my coffee authori-tah, because I have a Ph.D. from MIT, and Cafe Stella serves by far the best coffee I've ever found in Hampton Roads, and probably the best coffee you've ever had. Therefore, if you know what good coffee tastes like or would like to learn, you should go here. Emily also wants you to know that they have a good selection of organic loose leaf teas (if that is your thing).
<review# 909,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/6/2012,5/11/2012,88,68,,4,4>You would never know it from the outside, but Il Giardino Ristorante on the Oceanfront in Virginia Beach is quite the restaurant on the inside. This restaurant has been around for decades and with good reason. The decor when you enter the restaurant is nice with a real nod to nature with live plants a tree and ambient lighting strung up throughout. They also have a center area in the dining room with a slicer dedicated to cutting fresh prosciutto di Parma for one of their appetizers. The bar area features tvs and a piano bar. I've been here twice and can say the food is well prepared. The first time I got a 3 course meal for $20 which consisted of calamari for an appetizer, Chicken Sorrentino for a main course, and their Napoleon for dessert. All 3 were great. The attention to detail could be seen from the first plate when they served the calamari with a lemon wrapped in cheesecloth to prevent seeds from falling on the plate. The Chicken Sorrentino was a nice sized portion which was a pleasant surprise being that when there's usually a deal like this some restaurants skimp on the size. None of that here!  The finale was a Napoleon which was layers of whipped cream between sheets of puff pastry. The pastry was light as a pillow while the cream was nice, dense and not overly sweet.  There are plenty of Italian restaurants in the area and this one does have dishes that are pricey which reflect the quality of ingredients they use. If you're looking for a place to take a date out to or just wanna have a nice family outing this is a good place to head to.

(I did the math before hand and planned on using the $5.00 off since it would be a bigger discount, she suggested the same thing.) All in all, I did like the place, I thought it was a little pricey...but her hospitality and the coupons made up for it. :)

<review# 925,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,10/26/2011,4/23/2012,144,389,,6,3>This was our first visit to Cozzy's Comedy Club. We attended both the early, and late show that Rich Vos put on, on Saturday, the 22nd of October.I had gone to the club about a week prior to order tickets, and I had my first look around. It's a small club, seating about 140 people. It is tightly laid out, giving the comedians an closeness to the audience that you do not see in larger clubs. We arrived, early on show night, and were given a table at the back side of the main seating area. I chose this seat, as having had seen Rich Vos on several occasions, I was well aware that he worked the audience during his show.We ordered off of the menu, prior to the show. The XYL ordered Fish and Chips and I ordered the Nachos platter (having read of it in a previous review of the club).The wife's order was good, though the fish was on the small side. It was cooked thoroughly, and her food was hot to order. My nacho platter was huge. Piled with grated cheese (and I believe nacho cheese sauce was poured into the middle as well). Peppers, chili, sour cream, lettuce and tomatos. I was not able to eat the entire order, even with having an hour to do so. We both ordered tea, sweetened. It was strong, and refreshing.Show time. The first show was sold out. Not a seat to be had. Two local warm up acts had appeared. Both put on good sets, though the middle act, had the line of the night, with his reasoning for being fat. (Paraphrased)" I am fat. I was fat as a kid. My mother's uterus smelled like cake". Rich Vos took the stage next, and for about one hour and 15 minutes he moved back and forth from bits to crowd work. We stayed at the club, and talked with Vos, waiting for the second show.Alas, the second show was poorly attended. We went from about 140 attendee's to about 18. Though Vos made some comments about canceling the second show, he went on, and killed instead. He spent the show, brutally working the crowd. And, instead of going through the motions, or cutting the show time short, he worked the crowd for, again, over an hour and fifteen minutes. He is a true professional.Knowing better, our foursome (myself, the XYL, @CardinalMcGee, @lillivonschtupp) stayed in the back, and tried to keep our of the line of fire. Except for the Vegan budday (@lillivonschtupp). Who repeatedly tried to draw his attention to us (and getting a SHAAAAAAAAADDDDDD YUP from Vos), with her withering commentary.As we were Opie and Anthony Show fans, our table kept getting the show references that Vos kept throwing in, which seemed to fly over the heads of others. We howled with laughter.Despite a poorly attended second show, @RichVos put on a better second show, working the crowd, that kept feeding him with one lines, and commentary, that he took and ran with.Our first trip to Cozzy's Comedy Club. Decent food. Attentive servers. A friendly and concerned staff. Thoroughly enjoyable. Hopefully Rich Vos will return to the club in a couple of months. He is a hard working Comedian, who does not disappoint. And, had he walked down to Shawl's, he could have sold his dryer door...I am giving a 4 for the club and atmosphere. 5 for @Richvos and his performance. 3/4 for our food, with a 4 star over all rating. Highly recommended.@Removeyourhat
<review# 926,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,7/25/2011,4/22/2012,61,127,,6,2>I've been to Todd Jurich's several times since I wrote my initial review. Because they're brand new, they're still trying to perfect things & find what makes their customers happy. They got negative feedback about their burgers being expensive & served solo; so they've started adding a pickle & chips to their burger orders. Our server on Sat night (who was excellent) told us that they write their menus daily, so things constantly change as needed. It's nice to know that they're listening to customer suggestions. Also, they now have a separate daily specials menu. That's definitely the way to go! We had the beef carnitas on Sat night for an app & they were delicious! My husband had a bison burger (that was a special as well) & he said it was definitely the best burger he's ever had. Lastly, one of the bartenders told us that people sometimes complain about the service being slow, but people don't understand that there is an employee literally in the back grinding up fresh meat for every burger that is ordered... it's not fast food. I've been guilty of complaining about the wait time too, so that was a reality check! I'm still a fan!

<review# 932,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/13/2012,4/16/2012,23,17,2,6,3>My wife and I went to Aw Shucks last night for a dinner date. I was very surprised to find that the wait for an inside table was 25 minutes on a Thursday night. Thursday night? Who knew? Well, apparently everyone (including the mayor, I saw him walk out while we were eating). While we were waiting for a table outside to be cleaned one of the bistro tables in the waiting area lounge came open so I asked for that and the hostess said no problem. I already knew I was going to get the po boy sandwich before I got there, the only question was if it were to be oyster or shrimp. I like shrimp much better than oysters, but oysters are the specialty at this place so I was conflicted. Deeply conflicted, a true seafood crisis. The waitress solved my culinary dilemma by saying if I got the full instead of the half sandwich they could put oysters on one part and shrimp on the other. Brilliant! I requested extra remoulade to dip the fries in at the recommendation of another Yelper (thanks james b from VB!). Even though they were very busy the food came really fast. When our plates arrived I thought I would be bringing some of it home because there was so much food. First of all let me say that these were the best fried oysters I'd ever had, very large and breading was crispy but not too heavy. This sandwich was stuffed with enough seafood for two sandwiches! The tomato, lettuce, and coleslaw were all very fresh. And the remoulade was on the side. At first I had to clear some fries and oysters out of the way, so I dipped them in remoulade which was very good and spicy. There are seriously more oysters than you can possibly handle in the sandwich with all the other toppings, but I gave it a go anyway. I slowed down a bit when I ran out of sweet tea (I wasn't upset, our waitress looked to be handling about half the restaurant and she was amazing!), but just grabbed a sip of my wife's water and kept mowing through that hoagie of seafood and dripping (Louisiana style, of course) remoulade goodness. I started with the oyster side, and then proceeded to the shrimp side. I have to say that the oyster wins hands down. So next time I can just get the half oyster po boy. To compare, I had the shrimp po boy at Surfrider in Greenbrier not long ago. Those shrimp looked like they were the frozen variety that you heat up in the toaster oven. And the oysters, wow so awesome!My wife had the crabcake sandwich, after verifying that it came with fries. Yes, the fries are that good! Anyway, the crabcake was at least an inch thick, breaded and deep fried and very good. Or so she says, because I didn't get any of it! That's ok, I was too busy with my own sandwich to even think about it. And I will say that normally I don't get oysters, fried or otherwise and partly because they really don't look appetizing to me. But I will at this place! As a matter of fact I might not be able to have a po boy anywhere else.  Seriously! Aw Shucks, I think I love ya!

<review# 937,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,4/4/2012,4/11/2012,22,14,,4,2>Love this place!  I was so happy to stumble upon the farmers market and this little ice cream joint!  The best thing about it is that it's an independently owned shop.  All the ice cream is made in the store, and the owner is more than proud to tell you about all of her flavors. Ice cream is usually made with milk with 20%+ fat.  They get their milk from a dairy in Pennsylvania and it contains 11% fat so it's a bit lighter then the ice cream you're used to.I had the Mexican Coffee ice cream and I must say I've never tasted anything quite like it before.  Yes, the prices may be slightly more than you're used to, but you're paying for the piece of mind that comes with supporting a local business and all-natural ingredients combined with a passion for ice cream!

<review# 940,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,3/17/2012,4/7/2012,74,230,1,4,3>We are huge pizza fans in our home but for one reason or another had never tried Y Not.  So, we decided to give it a try on a recent Friday night while over in the Greenbrier area.  First off, the place inside was quite nice.  They had a cool little bar area off to the right (that got quite loud as NSU knocked off Mizzou!!) with the dining room to the left and a big dessert case on display as you walk by to get to your table.  I am not sure how anyone resists dessert after seeing the stuff they had, which we will discuss shortly.  When we were seated, we were immediately greeted by our server, Paul.  Paul was a lot of fun and a pretty good server.  Very personable and outgoing.  We enjoyed the service.  We ordered some cheddar bacon fries as an appetizer and they were pretty good.  The fries were crispy and hot.  It was a good start to our meal.  For dinner, my oldest son ordered mac and cheese, the youngest ordered a ham and cheese sandwich, my wife and I split a small half cheese/half pepperoni pizza, and I got a slice of sicilian with meatball, as well.  The mac and cheese and sub were both well received.  No complaints from the kids.  My wife and I were split on the pizza we, well, split.  The wife thought the pizza was only OK, though she thought the crust was very good and done perfectly.  I thought the pizza was good.  It wasn't the best pizza we've had but it was light, thin, and cooked just right.  I enjoyed it.  The Sicilian slice was really good.  Really really good.  I had been on a search for good Sicilian and for me, this qualified.  Not too much sauce, lots of cheese, and thick and crispy crust.  The meatballs on the pizza were outstanding.  I only ate a few bites of the Sicilian and am actually looking forward to heating it up in a bit for dinner tonight!  Dessert was a strange adventure.  The boys had black and white cookies.  I can honestly say that I had, to this point, never had a black and white cookie.  So, I had no idea what to expect.  It was actually more like a thin cake covered in half chocolate and half vanilla (I guess) frosting.  The boys liked the white side, I preferred the black side.  I would go back for one again.  My wife ordered a brownie that turned out to be the biggest disappointment of the night.  It was bad.  I am not sure how one makes a bad brownie but none of the four of us liked it.  It's sitting on my kitchen counter as I type this.  We were hoping maybe time would help the poor thing.  But, probably not.  Overall, it was a good experience and I can definitely see us returning here again.  The food was good and there is enough variety on the menu to try some other things......just not that darn brownie!

Yes I know... deep breath... steady yourself... ok back to the review... The burger was frickin sacrilicious. It's served on a pretzel bun and comes with the standard garnishments. FYI it's only prepared 2 ways. Medium Well or Well Done. Our server Britney was excellent and checked back on us regularly, keeping the drinks full and making sure our meal was ok. I found the entire staff very personable. With Woody's being so close to work I can see myself becoming a regular. Give them a try, I don't think you'll be disappointed.

<review# 944,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,5/19/2011,3/30/2012,122,469,,7,2>What I like about Nana, compared to other sushi restaurants in the area (YoYo and Koi) is the atmosphere and quality of their food. YoYo's service sucks and Koi is very basic, nothing original or creative on their menu.  Is Nana a bit more expensive? Sure, but they're the only local sushi restaurant with a happy hour that has $5 apps and even cheaper beer and sake. No other sushi restaurants in the area offer specials, which I think is crazy, so you end up spending about the same for better quality. Nana's owners are great, very hospitable and friendly, and the service is always top-notched. They also have a great wine list for a japanese restaurant. Try the tuna pizza for an app and the sparking fuji apple sake!
<review# 945,isUSA=TRUE,4.0,11/20/2011,3/29/2012,121,170,3,10,6>Uncle's Farm is the newest addition to the Newport News Korean Grocery scene.  Warwick Blvd., in particular, has been the home to a number of them - past, present, and probably future, as well.  It was an impromptu visit that worked out all the same.The strip mall is new as is Uncle's Farm.  As I drove by, the name caught my eye.  Initially, I wondered if it was a farmer's market of some kind, but after further review, there was no mistaking that it was a Korean grocery store - there were a number of pictures and Korean characters on the window that immediately give it away.  The door was open just enough to give passers-by a peak inside, as well.The store is new and super clean.  There are the ubiquitous Korean items - rice, kimchi, fresh veggies, and so on.  I was in the market for rice and settled on a Korean Brand, Khee Chun; it was less than $13.00 - a bargain, in my opinion.  Also, purchased a large bottle of Korean Citron Tea.  It looks like marmalade, but a dollop mixed in hot water make a tasty hot drink.  Of course, I plan to make some citron tea, but truth be known, it makes a mean mixed drink as well. For my Japanophiles, it's a Yuzu jam.For all of you who want to venture into Uncle's Farm, info is written mostly in Korean.  I don't read Korean well, but know enough about Korean food and its preparation.  The clerk/owner is very helpful and can help you with any questions you might have. Loved Uncle's Farm and hope to pay them another visit soon.  I only wish they would have set up shop on the Southside.

<review# 948,isUSA=TRUE,5.0,10/10/2011,3/26/2012,69,446,6,35,9>Sprinter Bus has saved me! A friend recommended them to me but at the time I was already booked with Coach88 (see review).  So I promised myself next time I would take the Sprinter Bus. I am writing this review from the bus right now because there is FREE WIFI! Also, I have had my own seat on the trip to NY and now on the trip back, which is very nice; I'm quite happy to not be in a friggin packed bus. The driver is friendly and *bonus* has a mic system where he actually announces things like arrival time and rest stop instructions (imagine that). The Bus has been on time and I love their organized system of seating. Free bottle of water with every trip! $40 one way, $70 round trip. It's a few bucks more expensive than the average China Town Bus but it is WELL WORTH IT. Also drop off location is very convenient. Only a few blocks from the 34th street subway and the N,Q,R trains. Double super bonus: Buy 5 rides and the 6th is free! Triple Diple Sunshine Bonus: the bathroom is spotless AND smells nice.
